lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Naturalisation: knowledge of language and society
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Sch 1 of the British Nationality Act 1981 amended by this subsection).

core:comment.core:para: Sub-ss (1), (2): (in relation to England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland): 1 November 2005: see SI 2005/2782, art 3(1). Sub-ss (1), (2): (in relation to the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man): 6 May 2006: see SI 2005/2782, art 3(2). Sub-ss (3), (4): 6 July 2004: see SI 2004/1707, art 2.

Definitions ‘United Kingdom’: British Nationality Act 1981, s 50 ‘Great Britain, Northern Ireland and the Islands, taken together (the Islands are defined in that same section as ‘the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man’).

Paragraph 1(1)(c) of Sch 1 to the British Nationality Act 1981 (BNA 1981) requires that applicants for naturalisation must have sufficient knowledge of English, Welsh or Scots Gaelic. During the passage of this Act, Ministers stated that they wished to enforce this requirement more consistently than in the past (Hansard Standing Committee E, 30 April 2002 Col 18).

This section introduces a new requirement for naturalisation: applicants must have ‘sufficient knowledge of life in the United Kingdom’. As sub-s (4) makes clear, to satisfy this test applicants for naturalisation could be required by regulations to undertake a specific course of study and to pass an examination.
Note that the section deals only with applicants for naturalisation not for registration as a British citizen.

This section should be viewed in the light of the introduction of citizenship in the National Curriculum taught in schools from September 2002 and links are further emphasised by the appointment of Sir Bernard Crick, who worked on the citizenship curriculum, to chair an advisory group on the new tests.

(2) Para 2(e) of Sch 1 to the BNA 1981 provides for waiver of the language test requirement if the Secretary of State considers that ‘because of the applicant''s age or physical or mental condition it would be unreasonable to expect him to fulfil it’. This subsection ensures that the same power of waiver will also apply for new test of sufficient knowledge of life in the United Kingdom.
(3) and (4) Section 41 of the BNA 1981 provides a broad and general regulation-making power, which did not, prior to this section, make any specific mention of the language test.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Naturalisation: spouse of citizen
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Paragraphs 3 and 4 of Schedule 1 to the British Nationality Act 1981 (c 61) (requirements for naturalisation as British citizen: spouse of citizen) shall be amended as follows—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in paragraph 3(e) for “requirement specified in paragraph 1(1)(b)” substitute “requirements specified in paragraph 1(1)(b), (c) and (ca)”, and
(b)in paragraph 4(c) omit “and (e)”.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)Paragraphs 7 and 8 of that Schedule (requirements for naturalisation as British overseas territories citizen: spouse of citizen) shall be amended as follows—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in paragraph 7(e) for “requirement specified in paragraph 5(1)(b)” substitute “requirements specified in paragraph 5(1)(b) and (c)”, and
(b)in paragraph 8(c) omit “and (e)”.

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘British overseas territories citizen’: British Overseas Territories Act 2002 ss 1 and 2; BNA 1981, s 50(1) and Sch 6 as amended by that Act; Interpretation Act 1978, Sch 1.

This section extends the language requirement in para 1(1)(c) of Sch 1 to the British Nationality Act 1981 (BNA 1981; see note to s 1) to those applying for naturalisation as spouses of British Citizens or of British overseas territories citizens. Previously, spouses were not required to satisfy this test. Spouses of British Citizens will also be required to satisfy the new test of ‘sufficient knowledge of life in the United Kingdom’ for which provision is made in s 1 (see note above).

Paragraphs 3 and 4 of Sch 1 to the BNA 1981 refer back to s 6(2) of that Act, which is concerned with ‘a person of full age and capacity who on the date of the application is married to a British citizen’. Thus no provision is made for unmarried partners.

(2)(a) Paragraph 5(1)(c) of Sch 1 to the BNA 1981 is the requirement to satisfy the language test. This sub-paragraph removes the exemption of spouses of British Overseas Territories citizens from the test.

(2)(b) Now that spouses of British overseas territories citizens are required to satisfy the language test, provision is made by this subsection for them to benefit from the powers of the Secretary of State to waive the language requirement or to exempt people from it, under para 6(e) of Sch 1 to the BNA 1981.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Citizenship ceremony, oath and pledge
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: Schedule 1 (which makes provision about citizenship ceremonies, oaths and pledges) shall have effect.

core:comment.core:para: 1 January 2004 (except in relation to any application for registration or naturalisation made before that date): see SI 2003/3156, arts 2(a), 3, 4.
See note to Sch 1.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Deprivation of citizenship
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)(Sections 40 and 40A of the British Nationality Act 1981 are substituted by this subsection).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (2)(Section 2A of the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997 inserted by this subsection.)

core:comment.core:para: 1 April 2003: see SI 2003/754, art 2(1), Sch 1; for transitional provisions in relation to sub-ss (2), (3) above, see art 3(2), Sch 2, para 5 thereto.

Definitions ‘British overseas territories citizen’: British Overseas Territories Act 2002, ss 1 and 2; BNA 1981, s 50(1) and Sch 6; Interpretation Act 1978, Sch 1. ‘British Overseas citizen’: BNA 1981, s 50(1). ‘British National (Overseas)’: BNA 1951, s 50(1). ‘British protected person’: BNA 1951, s 50(1). ‘British overseas territory’: British Overseas Territories Act 2002, s 1; BNA, 1981 s 50(1) and Sch 6 as amended. ‘British subject’: BNA 1981, s 51 and see BNA 1981, Pt 4. ‘United Kingdom’: BNA 1981, s 50. ‘Great Britain, Northern Ireland and the Islands, taken together (the Islands are defined in that same section as ‘the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man’).

The main change effected by this section is that by virtue of sub-s (2) of s 40 it is now possible for those born British to be deprived of their citizenship. However, because sub-s (4) requires that deprivation under that paragraph cannot be made where this would leave the person stateless, only those holding dual nationality will be affected by this new provision. An interesting question thus arises as to the relationship between this section and s 6 (see note thereto) which removes the exemption of nationality functions from the general prohibition on discrimination contained in the Race Relations Act 1976 (as amended by the Race Relations (Amendment) Act 2000), and now replaced by the Equality Act 2010. All those affected will be British nationals, but will hold another nationality, which could give rise to arguments that the section is discriminatory in its effect, although Ministers stated that the intention behind the section was to remove an unjustified distinction between those registered or naturalised as British, and those who acquired British nationality by birth (Hansard HL Report, 10 October 2002, Vol 639, No 184, Col 502).
For the first time, a right of appeal against deprivation of citizenship has been provided, see new s 40A of the BNA 1981 inserted by this section.

(1) The phrase in new s 40(2), ‘seriously prejudicial to the vital interests’, is taken from the European Convention on Nationality (Strasbourg, 6 September 1997) which Ministers indicated during the passage of the Act that it was their intention to ratify. The phrase is not defined in the Convention.

Section 40(6) means that the new s 40 has retrospective effect only in cases where nationality has been obtained by fraud, false representation or concealment (as set out in s 40(2)); cases which could have resulted in deprivation of nationality under the old s 40 of the BNA 1981. The new powers set out in s 40(2) do not therefore have retrospective effect.

New s 40A provides, for the first time, a right of appeal against deprivation of citizenship. The old s 40 provided only a right to an inquiry and for the Secretary of State to appoint a committee of inquiry. The appeal is to an immigration judge of the First-tier Tribunal in the first instance, with a right to seek leave to appeal to the Immigration Appeals Tribunal on a point of law and thence to seek leave to appeal to the Court of Appeal or the Court of Session. In national security cases, there is provision for the appeal to be heard by the Special Immigration Appeals Commission (SIAC).
New s 40A(6) provides that a deprivation order may not be made until any appeal has been finally determined, or the time for appealing has expired.

(4) This subsection means that the new provisions can only be used in respect of events occurring before commencement if those events would also have founded a deprivation of citizenship under the old s 40. Thus the powers in new s 40(2) to deprive those born British of their citizenship do not have retrospective effect. Those naturalised or registered as British could still be deprived of their citizenship under the new s 40(2) but only on the grounds set out in the old s 40(3), which can be broadly summarised as disloyalty to the sovereign; unlawful communication with the enemy, or a sentence of imprisonment in any country of more than 12 months, within five years of registration or naturalisation.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Resumption of citizenship
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Sections 10(1) and (2), 22(1) and (2) of the British Nationality Act 1981 amended by this subsection words “, if a woman,” shall cease to have effect).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent in relation to applications made after 7 November 2002 and applications made, but not determined, by 7 November 2002 (s 162(3)).
Definitions ‘British overseas territories citizen’: British Overseas Territories Act 2002 ss 1 and 2; BNA 1981, s 50(1) and Sch 6 as amended by that Act; Interpretation Act 1978, Sch 1.

Section 10 of the British Nationality Act 1981 (BNA 1981) deals with registration following renunciation of citizenship of the United Kingdom and colonies and s 22 of that Act deals with the right to registration replacing the right to resume citizenship of the United Kingdom and colonies. Under ss 10(1) and 22(1) only women were entitled to register under these sections on the basis that they had been married before commencement of that Act to a person entitled to register as a British citizen by virtue of an appropriate qualifying connection (whether or not the spouse was still alive). The effect of this section is to give men the same entitlement. Discrimination is removed by giving men the (superior) rights previously enjoyed only by women. Spouses of both sexes of British or British overseas territories citizens who renounced that British or British overseas territories citizenship before commencement of the BNA 1981, but still fulfil the qualifying requirements, have the right to regain the citizenship renounced.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Nationality decision: reasons and review
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Section 44(2) and (3) of the British Nationality Act 1981 (c 61) (no requirement to give reasons for discretionary decision, and no right of appeal) shall cease to have effect.
(2)Section 1(5) of the British Nationality (Hong Kong) Act 1990 (c 34) (no requirement to give reasons for discretionary decision, and no right of appeal) shall cease to have effect.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002 on Royal Assent (section 162(2)(b)).

Under this section the Secretary of State has a duty to give reasons for decisions in all nationality cases. In 1997 the then Home Secretary announced that reasons would be given in nationality cases, and that has been the normal practice since then. This section places that practice on a statutory footing.

Only the parts of the sections in question that relate to the duty to give reasons are repealed. There is still no right of appeal against naturalisation or registration decisions. However, the effect of the changes is that judicial review of such a decision can be brought on all the judicial review grounds, not merely on the basis that the decision was ultra vires.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Citizenship: registration
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: In paragraph 3(1)(b) of Schedule 2 to the British Nationality Act 1981 (application by person born in United Kingdom or overseas territory for registration as citizen: age requirement) the words “had attained the age of ten but” shall cease to have effect.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent, in relation to applications made on or after a date to be appointed by the Secretary of State by order and applications made, but not determined, by the date so appointed (s 162(4)).

Definitions “overseas territory”: see British Overseas Territories Act 2002, s 1; BNA 1981 s 50(1) and Sch 6 as amended. “United Kingdom”: BNA 1981, s 50 ‘Great Britain, Northern Ireland and the Islands, taken together (the Islands are defined in that same section as ‘the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man’).

This section removes the minimum age restriction of ten years for those seeking to acquire British Citizenship or British overseas territories citizenship by registration on the grounds that they were born stateless in the United Kingdom, or in a British Overseas territory. Thus stateless children born in the UK or in a British Overseas territory can become citizens after just five years, subject to provisions on time spent outside the UK during that period. This provision is not, however, yet in force. For the liability of such children to removal, see s 73.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Legitimacy of child
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)(Subsections (9), (9A)—(9C) of section 50 of the British Nationality Act 1981 substituted by this subsection).
(2)(Section 3(6) of the British Nationality Act 1981 amended by this subsection).
(3)(Section 17(6) of the British Nationality Act 1981 amended by this subsection).
(4)(Section 47 of the British Nationality Act 1981 amended by this subsection).
(5)(Schedule 2 the British Nationality Act 1981 amended by this subsection).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002 in relation to a child born on or after 1 July 2006: see SI 2006/1498. Section 50(9A)(b)-(c) has been amended by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act 2008.

Section 50(9) of the BNA 1981 states that ‘subject to s 47, the relationship of father and child shall be taken to exist only between a man and any legitimate child born to him’. Section 47 made provision for children legitimated (according to the law of their place of birth) by the marriage of their parents subsequent to their birth. Illegitimate children did not have fathers as far as the BNA 1981 was concerned. The effect of this section is to allow those proved to be fathers, by DNA testing or otherwise, to be recognised as the fathers of their illegitimate children for nationality purposes. Other differences in the treatment of legitimate and illegitimate children for nationality purposes are removed, as set out below.
As to the tests to be applied, the government stated during the passage of the Act that:

core:blockquote.core:para: our expectation in most cases will be that, where the child was not born during the continuance of a marriage and the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Act does not apply, paternity will be proved by DNA evidence. Our intention is to adapt, for this purpose, the non-statutory scheme which has for many years operated successfully in the entry clearance context…, where a requirement to produce DNA evidence would be inappropriate, for example, where the alleged father had died…other evidence such as judicial declarations of paternity would need to be considered …there will need to be some flexibility in the application of the prescribed requirements
core:blockquote.core:credit: (Hansard HL Report, 8 July 2002, Vol 637, No 165, Col 546, Lord Bassam of Brighton).

core:comment.core:para: (2) Section 3(6)(c) of the BNA 1981 meant that there was no relationship for nationality purposes between a British father and his illegitimate child. Section 17(6)(c) made similar provision where the father was a British overseas territories citizen. With the removal of the exclusion of this relationship, the need for the whole of ss 3(6) and 17(6) falls away, as all children are to be treated in the same way.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Right of abode: certificate of entitlement
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may by regulations make provision for the issue to a person of a certificate that he has the right of abode in the United Kingdom.
(2)The regulations may, in particular—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)specify to whom an application must be made;
(b)specify the place (which may be outside the United Kingdom) to which an application must be sent;
(c)provide that an application must be made in [accompanied by specified information];
(d)provide that an application must be accompanied by specified documents;
(f)specify the consequences of failure to comply with a requirement under any of paragraphs [(a) to (d)] above;
(g)provide for a certificate to cease to have effect after a period of time specified in or determined in accordance with the regulations;
(h)make provision about the revocation of a certificate.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The regulations may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)make provision which applies generally or only in specified cases or circumstances;
(b)make different provision for different purposes;
(c)include consequential, incidental or transitional provision.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)The regulations—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(b)shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)(Section 3(9)(b) of the Immigration Act 1971 amended by this subsection where words “issued by or on behalf of the Government of the United Kingdom certifying that he has such a right of abode” shall cease to have effect).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (b)(Section 33(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 amended by this subsection wg=here definition “certificate of entitlement” substituted).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)Regulations under this section may, in particular, include provision saving, with or without modification, the effect of a certificate which—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)is issued before the regulations come into force, and
(b)is a certificate of entitlement for the purposes of sections 3(9) and 33(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 as those sections have effect before the commencement of subsection (5) above.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-ss 10(1) to (4) and (6), 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2) (c)). Sub-s (5) to be appointed: see s 162(1).

Sub-s (2): in para (c) words “accompanied by specified information” in square brackets substituted by the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006, s 50(5). Date in force: 5 November 2007: see SI 2007/3138, art 2(i). Sub-s (2): para (e) repealed by the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006, ss 52(7), 61, Sch 2, para 4(a), Sch 3. Date in force: 2 April 2007: see SI 2007/1109, arts 4, 5, Schedule. Sub-s (2): in para (f) words “(a) to (d)” in square brackets substituted by the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006, s 52(7), Sch 2, para 4(b). Date in force: 2 April 2007: see SI 2007/1109, art 4.
Definitions ‘certificate of entitlement’: sub-s 5(b), amending s 33(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (IA 1971). ‘Right of abode’: IA 1971, s 2.

The section makes provision for the issue of certificates of entitlement to a right of abode to be the subject of regulations. Prior to the enactment of this section, only the level of fee and the procedure for appealing a refusal were regulated.

(5)(b) The insertion of a new definition of ‘certificate of entitlement’ into the IA 1971 will make it possible to define what is, and what is not, a valid certificate by means of the regulations made under this section, subject to the provisions of sub-s (6) protecting existing certificates.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: British citizenship: registration of certain persons without other citizenship
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 4B of the British Nationality Act 1981 inserted by this subsection).
(Section 14(1) of the British Nationality Act 1981, in paragraph (d) for ‘section 5’ there shall be substituted “section 4B or 5”).

core:comment.core:para: 30 April 2003: see SI 2003/754, art 2(1), Sch 1.

On 5 March 2002 the special quota voucher scheme, whereby British Overseas citizens could apply for a voucher to come to the UK and thus build up length of stay for nationality purposes, was abolished without warning. British overseas territories citizens, holders of a nationality which gave them no right of abode in any country, were left without the possibility of acquiring a right of abode in the UK.

This section goes some way toward addressing this situation. British Overseas Citizens, British protected persons and British subjects meeting the requirements of this clause have the right to register as British citizens. They will be British Citizens by descent (see subs (5)).

See also the British Overseas Territories Act 2002, which provides for British overseas territories citizens to become British Citizens, either on commencement of s 3 of that Act, or by subsequent registration (s 4 of the that Act, inserting a new s 4A into the BNA 1981.

(1) The date of 4 July 2002 in the new s 4B(2)(c) of the BNA 1981 is chosen because it is the date upon which this new provision was announced. Action or inaction before that date is irrelevant to the right to register under the new s 4B. After that date, those who have another nationality do not have a right to register if they can retain that nationality. It should be remembered that this section does not prohibit the Secretary of State exercising his discretion in those cases covered by new s 4B(2)(c). Section 4B has been amended by Borders, Citizenship and Immigration Act 2009, s 44 from 13 January 2010 to include British Nationals (Overseas).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: British citizenship: registration of certain persons born between 1961 and 1983
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 4C of the British Nationality Act 1981 inserted by this section)
(Section 14(1)(d) of the British Nationality Act 1981, in paragraph (d) after the words “section 4B” (as substituted by section 12(2) of this Act) there shall be inserted “, 4C”).

core:comment.core:para: 30 April 2003: see SI 2003/754, art 2(1), Sch 1.

This section goes some way toward eliminating discrimination in naturalisation law. Prior to 1983, only fathers could transmit their British nationality to children born in wedlock outside the UK. Mothers could not. On 6 February 1979 a policy was introduced to register the children born outside the UK to British mothers as long as the children were still under 18. The discrimination did not affect children born after 1983, as s 2 of the BNA 1981 came into force on 1 January 1983, providing for such children to be born British by descent.

Not everyone who was eligible took advantage of the concession, which applied only during their minority. This provision essentially placed the old concession on a statutory footing: those who were minors when the concession came into force (ie those born after 7 February 1961) could now apply to register as British citizens. They would be British citizens by descent (sub-s (2)).

Discrimination on the face of the statute persisted, for those born to British mothers before 7 February 1961 had not been given a right to register and remain disadvantaged in comparison to those born to British fathers. However, s 4C was amended by the Borders, Citizenship and Immigration Act 2009, s 45 from 13 January 2010 so that children born before 7 February 1961 could also avail themselves of the entitlement to registration

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Hong Kong
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: A person may not be registered as a British overseas territories citizen under a provision of the British Nationality Act 1981 (c 61) by virtue of a connection with Hong Kong.

core:comment.core:para: 1 January 2004 (except in relation to any application for registration or naturalisation made before that date): see SI 2003/3156, arts 2(b), 3, 4.
Definitions ‘British overseas territories citizen’: British Overseas Territories Act 2002, ss 1 and 2; BNA 1981, s 50(1) and Sch 6 as amended; Interpretation Act 1978, Sch 1.
In substance this section re-enacts s 42(6) of the BNA 1981. It prevents registration as a British Overseas Territories citizen on the basis of a connection with Hong Kong.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Repeal of spent provisions
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: Schedule 2 (which repeals spent provisions) shall have effect.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(e)).
See Note to Sch 2.

This part provides for the establishment of new centres, called accommodation centres, where asylum-seekers would live for part, or all, of the time taken to determine their claims. There is also power (see notes to ss 23(3) and 23(5)), to accommodate people who are not asylum seekers in the centres, using the powers in s 4 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (IAA 1999). Most of Part 2 has not, however, been brought into force, and it seems unlikely that this expensive project will ever come to fruition.

The government envisages that asylum seekers will first go through the process of induction provided for by s 70, then pass into self-contained centres, where all facilities would be on site and asylum interviews and, in most cases, appeals, will be conducted on site. Possible locations so far identified have all been in remote rural locations and planning applications have been submitted. The government stated during the passage of the Act that it intended to pilot some four such centres, holding a total of 3,000 men, women and families, in the first instance. Unaccompanied minors will not go into centres. It appears highly unlikely that the pilot will commence before late 2004 and even then the majority of asylum-seekers will remain outside the centres, provided for by the National Asylum Support Service (NASS), and the system established under Pt 4 of the IAA 1999 and modified by Part 3 of this Act.

The overall effect of this Part, reinforced by the amendments to Pt 4 of the IAA 1999 effected by Pt 3 of this Act, is to strengthen the links between support and immigration control. The distinction between a residence restriction imposed under Sch 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 and a condition of support, or compliance with arrangements made for support is, for most practical purposes, removed.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Establishment of centres
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may arrange for the provision of premises for the accommodation of persons in accordance with this Part.
(2)A set of premises provided under this section is referred to in this Act as an “accommodation centre”.
(3)The Secretary of State may arrange for—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the provision of facilities at or near an accommodation centre for sittings of adjudicators appointed for the purpose of Part 5 in accordance with a determination … under paragraph 2 of Schedule 4;
(b)the provision of facilities at an accommodation centre for the taking of steps in connection with the determination of claims for asylum (within the meaning of section 18(3)).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002: Royal Assent (s 162(2)(f)).
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: subs (2). ‘claim for asylum’: s 18(3).
Sub-s (3): in para (a) words omitted repealed by the Constitutional Reform Act 2005, s 146, Sch 18, Pt 2. Date in force: 3 April 2006: see SI 2006/1014, art 2(a), Sch 1, paras 29, 30(b).
This section provides the broad and general power to establish the centres. The Secretary of State can run them directly, or contract them out, see s 17.
(3) Pt 5 and Sch 4 deal with adjudicators hearing asylum appeals.

This includes both claims under the United Nations Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees of 1951 and claims under Article 3 of the European Convention on Human Rights. This parallels the support system established under Pt 6 of the IAA 1999, see in particular s 94 of that Act, as amended.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Support for destitute asylum-seeker
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may arrange for the provision of accommodation for a person in an accommodation centre if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the person is an asylum-seeker or the dependant of an asylum-seeker, and
(b)the Secretary of State thinks that the person is destitute or is likely to become destitute within a prescribed period.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State may make regulations about procedure to be followed in respect of the provision of accommodation under this section.
(3)The regulations may, in particular, make provision—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)specifying procedure to be followed in applying for accommodation in an accommodation centre;
(b)providing for an application to be combined with an application under or in respect of another enactment;
(c)requiring an applicant to provide information;

(d)specifying circumstances in which an application may not be considered (which provision may, in particular, provide for an application not to be considered where the Secretary of State is not satisfied that the information provided is complete or accurate or that the applicant is co-operating with enquiries under paragraph (e));
(e)about the making of enquiries by the Secretary of State;
(f)requiring a person to notify the Secretary of State of a change in circumstances.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Sections 18 to 20 define the following expressions for the purpose of this Part—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)asylum-seeker,
(b)dependant, and
(c)destitute.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions “accommodation centre”: s 16 (2). “Claim for asylum”: s 18(3). “Dependant”: s 20. “Destitute”: s 19(1).

The provisions of this section closely reflect those of s 95 of the IAA 1999, as amended by this Act. Ministers stated during the passage of this Act that they did not anticipate that the procedure for applying for support would be vastly different from that now in operation in relation to Pt 6 of the IAA 1999 (see Hansard Standing Committee E, 9 May 2002, Col 120, Angela Eagle MP, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). Indeed, a single application may suffice for both purposes, given that under s 51 of this Act it is for the Secretary of State, not the applicant, to determine which form of support will be offered. For existing applications, see the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/704), reg 3 as amended, most recently by the Asylum Support (Amendment) (No 3) Regulations 2002, SI 2002/3110.

(1) The Secretary of State may provide accommodation directly or contract this function out. By the definition in s 18(1)(a) a person under 18 is not an asylum-seeker for the purposes of this part. Thus unaccompanied children cannot be placed in the centres. The dependant children of adult asylum-seekers, however, can.
Subsection 1(b) means that accommodation can be provided before the person is destitute. This mirrors the provision in s 95(1) of the IAA 1999.
(3) These regulation-making powers closely follow those set out in Sch 8 of the IAA 1999, see especially para 12 of that Schedule.

Although not expressly stated, it is anticipated that subs (3)(c) is designed to allow a person to make an application for support without specifying whether s/he wishes to be accommodated in an accommodation centre or otherwise supported by NASS. The choice of provision would then fall to the Secretary of State. See s 22, whereby supporting an asylum seeker in an accommodation centre is made one of the ways in which the Secretary of State may provide support under s 95 of the IAA 1999.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Asylum-seeker: definition
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)For the purposes of this Part a person is an ‘asylum-seeker’ if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)he is at least 18 years old,
(b)he is in the United Kingdom,
(c)a claim for asylum has been made by him at a place designated by the Secretary of State,
(d)the Secretary of State has recorded the claim, and
(e)the claim has not been determined.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)A person shall continue to be treated as an asylum-seeker despite subsection (1)(e) while—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)his household includes a dependent child who is under 18, and
(b)he does not have leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A claim for asylum is a claim by a person that to remove him from or require him to leave the United Kingdom would be contrary to the United Kingdom''s obligations under—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees done at Geneva on 28th July 1951 and its Protocol, or
(b)Article 3 of the Convention for the Protection of Human Rights and Fundamental Freedoms agreed by the Council of Europe at Rome on 4th November 1950.

core:comment.core:para: 8 January 2003 for the purpose of ss 55(9), 70(3), and para 17(1)(b) of Sch 3; 10 February 2003 for the purpose of s 71(5), and 26A(2) of the IA 1971 (all SI 1/2003).
Definitions ‘asylum-seeker’: sub-s (1). ‘Claim for asylum’: sub-s (2). ‘Dependent’: s 20. ‘Determined’: s 21(3).

This section closely follows s 94 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (IAA 1999), as amended by s 44 of this Act. There is no distinction on the face of the statutes between those who can be supported within and outside centres.
(1)(a) Unaccompanied children do not fall within this definition.
1(b) This requirement is new.
(1)(c) See also s 113(1), where a similar definition is used, and the note thereto.

(2) As with new s 94(3A) of the IAA 1999, inserted by s 44 of this Act, provision is made for families with children to continue to be supported until they are recognised as refugees, or granted other leave, or until they leave the country.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Destitution: definition
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Where a person has dependants, he and his dependants are destitute for the purpose of this Part if they do not have and cannot obtain both—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)adequate accommodation, and
(b)food and other essential items.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)Where a person does not have dependants, he is destitute for the purpose of this Part if he does not have and cannot obtain both—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)adequate accommodation, and
(b)food and other essential items.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In determining whether accommodation is adequate for the purposes of subsection (1) or (2) the Secretary of State must have regard to any matter prescribed for the purposes of this subsection.
(4)In determining whether accommodation is adequate for the purposes of subsection (1) or (2) the Secretary of State may not have regard to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)whether a person has an enforceable right to occupy accommodation,
(b)whether a person shares all or part of accommodation,
(c)whether accommodation is temporary or permanent,
(d)the location of accommodation, or
(e)any other matter prescribed for the purposes of this subsection.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)The Secretary of State may by regulations specify items which are or are not to be treated as essential items for the purposes of subsections (1) and (2).
(6)The Secretary of State may by regulations—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)provide that a person is not to be treated as destitute for the purposes of this Part in specified circumstances;
(b)enable or require the Secretary of State in deciding whether a person is destitute to have regard to income which he or a dependant of his might reasonably be expected to have;

(c)enable or require the Secretary of State in deciding whether a person is destitute to have regard to support which is or might reasonably be expected to be available to the person or a dependant of his;

(d)enable or require the Secretary of State in deciding whether a person is destitute to have regard to assets of a prescribed kind which he or a dependant of his has or might reasonably be expected to have;
(e)make provision as to the valuation of assets.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘dependant’: s 20. ‘Destitute’: subs (1). ‘Prescribed’: s 39(1).

This section echoes s 95 of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 44 of this Act, and the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/704), as amended. The wording of the definition of destitution has been amended to replace ‘essential living needs’ with ‘food and other essential items’. The Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department, Angela Eagle, MP stated:

core:blockquote.core:para: There is no change in policy whatever implied in the change in wording of the definition of destitution […] We intend to use the definition in the new Act when in reaches the statute book in exactly the same way that we do the one in the 1999 Act […]

core:comment.core:para: (1) and (2) See ss 95(2) and 95(3) of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 44(6) of this Act.
(3) and (4) See ss 95(4) and 95(5) of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 44(6) of this Act.
(5) See s 95(5) of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 44(6) of this Act.
(6) See s 95(7) of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 44(6) of this Act. Ministers said of this subsection during the passage of the Act:

core:blockquote.core:para: The power reflects an existing provision in Schedule 8 to the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999. The asylum support regulations made under that Act specify the circumstances which are likely to be equally applicable for accommodation centres […] we anticipate following a similar approach for accommodation centres
core:blockquote.core:credit: (Hansard HL Report 10 July 2002, Vol 637, No 137, Col 735, Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Dependant: definition
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: For the purposes of this Part a person is a “dependant” of an asylum-seeker if (and only if) that person—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)is in the United Kingdom, and
(b)is within a prescribed class.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘asylum-seeker’: s 18(1). ‘Prescribed’: s 39(1).

In the original s 94 of the IAA 1999, a dependant was defined to include a spouse, and any dependant child under 18 of the applicant or spouse, with further categories to be specified in regulations. Further categories were specified in reg 2 of the Asylum Support Regulations 2002 (SI 2000/704). The wording of s 94 has been amended by s 44(3) of this Act and, as with this section, all definitions of dependency are left to regulations.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Sections 17 to 20: supplementary
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies for the purposes of sections 17 to 20.
(2)The Secretary of State may inquire into and decide a person''s age.
(3)A claim for asylum shall be treated as determined at the end of such period as may be prescribed beginning with—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the date on which the Secretary of State notifies the claimant of his decision on the claim, or
(b)if the claimant appeals against the Secretary of State’s decision, the date on which the appeal is disposed of.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)A notice under subsection (3)(a)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must be in writing, and
(b)if sent by first class post to the claimant’s last known address or to the claimant’s representative, shall be treated as being received by the claimant on the second day after the day of posting.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)An appeal is disposed of when it is no longer pending for the purpose of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)Part 5 of this Act, or
(b)the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997 (c 68).

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘disposed of’: sub-s (5). ‘Pending’: s 104(1); Special Immigration Appeals Act 1997, s 7A.
See s 94 of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 44 of this Act. This section makes parallel provision for accommodation centres.

(1) This subsection provides a power, not a duty. In practice, if a person subsequently applies to a local authority for support under the Children Act 1989 or the equivalent provisions for Scotland and Northern Ireland (see s 47, inserting a new s 122 into the IAA 1999) and the local authority, applying its own assessment procedures, disagrees with the Secretary of State, the Home Office may be persuaded to follow the local authority’s conclusion. There remains however a risk of principal applicants, or dependants, falling between two stools and being unable to access support from those supporting children because of being deemed an adult, and of those supporting adults because of being deemed a child.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, s 95
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The Secretary of State may provide support under section 95 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (destitute asylum-seeker) by arranging for the provision of accommodation in an accommodation centre.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘asylum-seeker’: s 18(1). ‘Accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Destitute’: s 19.

Given this provision, it is unclear why it was felt necessary to set out in ss 17–21 the tests for accommodating people in an accommodation centre, rather than allow them to be covered by the main regulations made under s 95 of the IAA 1999. There is no difference in primary legislation between the tests that can be imposed by regulations made under ss 17–21 and those that can be made by regulations under s 95 of the IAA 1999. See note to s 44.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Person subject to United Kingdom entrance control
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A residence restriction may include a requirement to reside at an accommodation centre.
(2)In subsection (1) “residence restriction” means a restriction imposed under—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)paragraph 21 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (temporary admission or release from detention), or
(b)paragraph 2(5) of Schedule 3 to that Act (control pending deportation).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Where a person is required to reside in an accommodation centre by virtue of subsection (1) the Secretary of State must arrange for the provision of accommodation for the person in an accommodation centre.
(4)But if the person is required to leave an accommodation centre by virtue of section 26 or 30 he shall be treated as having broken the residence restriction referred to in subsection (1).

(5)The Secretary of State may provide support under section 4 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (persons subject to entrance control) (including that section as amended by section 49 of this Act) by arranging for the provision of accommodation in an accommodation centre.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘residence restriction’: sub-s (2).

At first sight, sub-ss (1) and (2) of this section appear otiose, for the powers under the IA 1971 are sufficient to allow the Secretary of State to impose a residence restriction, without the addition of these subsections. One possible explanation is that by virtue of these subsections the residence restriction could simply state that a person should reside in an accommodation centre, without specifying the precise address. See also s 71, which extends powers to impose residence restrictions.

(2) Paragraph 21(2) of Sch 2 to the IA 1971 contains a power to impose residence restrictions on those liable to detention under that Schedule. Paragraph 2(5) of Sch 3 to that Act contains a power to impose residence restrictions on those released from detention pending deportation. The latter class of people, if they have no dependent children, are unlikely to qualify as ‘asylum-seekers’ under s 17, see note to sub-ss (3) and (5).

(3) This subsection places the Secretary of State under a duty to accommodate those who are obliged by a residence restriction to reside in an accommodation centre. There is no mention of the person’s having to satisfy any test of destitution or having to be an asylum seeker. Potential conflicts with s 17 are resolved by sub-s (5): such persons can be accommodated using the powers set out in s 4 of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 49 of this Act, which does not contain any test of destitution, and does not require those accommodated to be asylum-seekers. Note also that s 4 does not require the persons accommodated to be over 18. Accommodation centres could accommodate unaccompanied under 18s; the limitation upon this is effected by a definition of an asylum-seeker in s 18 not by any general provision applying to all centres.
See Schedule 3 which limits the categories of those who can be supported under s 4.

(4) Section 26 provides for the withdrawal of support where an asylum seeker has committed an offence by virtue of s 35, or failed to comply with directions to travel under ss 17 or 24. Further circumstances in which support can be withdrawn may be specified in regulations made under s 26(2). Section 30 provides for conditions of residence to be imposed upon those residing in centres. The overall effect of this section is to turn conduct necessary to avoid s 35 offences, and compliance with directions to travel and with the conditions under which support is provided, into forms of residence restriction. If breach results in being made to leave the centre, the person will thereby have breached the residence restriction and be liable to arrest under the IA 1971, Sch 2, para 24, and to detention. Support and immigration control are nowhere more closely linked than by this provision.

(5) See also note to sub-s (3). Section 4 of the IAA Act 1999 provides a power to accommodate those on temporary admission, released from immigration detention, on bail from immigration detention or, as a consequence of the amendments effected by s 49 of this Act, asylum seekers whose claims have been rejected. Thus accommodation centres need not be used wholly, or even mainly, for those with outstanding applications for asylum, or indeed those who have at any stage made a claim for asylum. The centres could be used for other categories of immigrants.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Provisional assistance
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)If the Secretary of State thinks that a person may be eligible for the provision of accommodation in an accommodation centre under section 17, he may arrange for the provision for the person, pending a decision about eligibility, of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)accommodation in an accommodation centre, or
(b)other support or assistance (of any kind).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)Section 99 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (provision of support by local authority) shall have effect in relation to the provision of support for persons under subsection (1) above as it has effect in relation to the provision of support for asylum-seekers under sections 95 and 98 of that Act.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Local authority’: IAA 1999, s 94(1).

Mirrors s 98 of the IAA 1999 whereby temporary support may be provided pending the determination of an application for support. Section 98 of the IAA 1999 was operated by contracting with voluntary sector agencies to provide accommodation and support during this period, in what became known as ‘emergency accommodation’. The periods spent in emergency accommodation had been anticipated to be a few days, but in practice were many months in many cases. Under this section, the person need not be accommodated in a different type of accommodation prior to the decision on the application for support, but could go straight to the accommodation centre. However, see s 70 on the initial induction process

(2) Section 99 of the IAA 1999 empowers local authorities to contract with the Secretary of State to provide support under Part 6 of that Act. By this subsection, local authorities would be able to contract with the Secretary of State to provide accommodation, either in accommodation centres or outside, for those waiting in a decision on an application for support. See also s 38, which provides a general power to local authorities to contract with the Secretary of State to run accommodation centres

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Length of stay
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may not arrange for the provision of accommodation for a person in an accommodation centre if he has been a resident of an accommodation centre for a continuous period of six months.
(2)But—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)subsection (1) may be disapplied in respect of a person, generally or to a specified extent, by agreement between the Secretary of State and the person, and

(b)if the Secretary of State thinks it appropriate in relation to a person because of the circumstances of his case, the Secretary of State may direct that subsection (1) shall have effect in relation to the person as if the period specified in that subsection were the period of nine months.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Section 51 is subject to this section.
(4)The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (1) or (2)(b) so as to substitute a shorter period for a period specified.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Resident’: s 27.

This section places a maximum time limit of nine months on the time that a person may spend in one or more accommodation centres. Six months is to be the norm, under sub-s (1). Those accommodated in centres can elect to stay longer (s 25(1)(a)). The Secretary of State can force a person to stay longer than six months, but never for more than nine months (s 25(1)(b)) if the Secretary of State thinks this appropriate in the circumstances of the individual case.
Regulations under this section are made subject to the affirmative procedure in parliament by s 39(5).

(1) The time limit will still bite even if a person is moved from one centre to another. However, nothing in this subsection appears to prohibit a person''s spending an aggregate of more, perhaps much more, than six (or nine, see s 25(2)(b)) months in a centre, providing that this is interspersed with periods outside a centre.
(2)(a) In summary, a person can elect to stay for more than six months. This section does not appear to be subject to the nine months long stop provided for in sub-s (2)(b).

(2)(b) The reference is to the circumstances of the case, rather than to exceptional circumstances During the passage of the Act, Ministers gave as an example of people who might stay more than six months: those due to receive a determination shortly after the six month period had expired (see Hansard HC Report, 5 November 2002, Vol 392, No 201 Col 151, Beverley Hughes MP, Minister for Citizenship and Immigration).

(3) Section 51 is concerned with ensuring that a person cannot chose the form of support s/he receives. By this subsection, a person retains the right to chose to leave an accommodation centre after nine months, or six months if sub-s (2)(b) has not been applied in his/her case.
(4) Note that the periods cannot be lengthened, only shortened.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Withdrawal of support
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may stop providing support for a person under section 17 or 24 if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the Secretary of State suspects that the person or a dependant of his has committed an offence by virtue of section 35, or
(b)the person or a dependant of his has failed to comply with directions of the Secretary of State as to the time or manner of travel to accommodation provided under section 17 or 24.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State may by regulations specify other circumstances in which he may stop providing support for a person under section 17 or 24.

(3)In determining whether or not to provide a person with support or assistance under section 17 or 24 of this Act or section 4, 95 or 98 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (asylum-seeker) the Secretary of State may take into account the fact that—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)he has withdrawn support from the person by virtue of this section or section 30(4) or (5), or
(b)circumstances exist which would have enabled the Secretary of State to withdraw support from the person by virtue of this section had he been receiving support.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)This section is without prejudice to section 103 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (appeal against refusal to support).

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.

Subsection (1) gives the Secretary of State a power to ‘stop providing support’ in the circumstances set out in sub-s (1) and in regulations made under sub-s (2). Subsection (3) deals with the effect of a ‘withdrawal’ of support on future applications. However, any gap left by the difference in wording appears to be bridged by sub-s 3(b), whereby the question of whether the person was actually in receipt of support at the time of the event that could lead the Secretary of State to stop providing support, is made irrelevant. It remains an open question whether the gap has been bridged entirely.
Compare the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/704), as amended, reg 20: “Suspension or discontinuation of support”.

(1)(a) The offence need not have been committed; it suffices that the Secretary of State suspects that it has been committed. Contrast reg 20(1)(b) of the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 which refers to the Secretary of State having ‘reasonable grounds to suspect’.
A person in this situation may not already be in receipt of support, see general note above. On offences, see note to s 35.

(1)(b) Failure to travel to a centre at the time and date appointed can result in the denial of further support. Contrast reg 20(1)(b) of the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 which refers to the Secretary of State having ‘reasonable grounds to suspect’ that the person has failed to travel ‘without reasonable excuse’.
A person in this situation may not already be in receipt of support, see general note above.

(3) This subsection will only impact upon those who have been accommodated or offered accommodation in accommodation centres, because the relevant provisions under which support can have been withdrawn (s 30(4) or (5)) relate to the provision of support in accommodation centres. Under both s 4 and Pt 6 of the IAA 1999 the Secretary of State has a power, not a duty, to provide support. This subsection means that in deciding whether to exercise that power, he can take into account the reasons for a previous withdrawal of support.

(4) A person from whom support is withdrawn under this section retains their right of appeal to an asylum-support adjudicator under s 103 of the IAA Act 1999. The effect of sub-s (3) in relation to the appeal is left unclear. Can the Secretary of State plead having taken into account a previous withdrawal of support, as provided for under sub-s (3), in defending the refusal of support before the adjudicator, or must the adjudicator simply determine whether the person is a destitute asylum-seeker whom the Secretary of State has power to support?

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Resident of centre
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: A reference in this Part to a resident of an accommodation centre is a reference to a person for whom accommodation in the centre is provided—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)under section 17,
(b)by virtue of section 22,
(c)by virtue of section 23, or
(d)under section 24.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2).

By this section all those accommodated in centres are subject to the same regime, whether they are destitute asylum-seekers who have applied for accommodation under s 17; those for whom support under s 95 of the IAA 1999 is provided in an accommodation centre by virtue of s 22 of this Act; those confined to an accommodation centre by a residence restriction in accordance with s 23; those accommodated under s 4 of the IAA 1999 in an accommodation centre by the operation of s 23 or those accommodated in a centre pending the determination of their application for support under s 24.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Manager of centre
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: A reference in this Part to the manager of an accommodation centre is a reference to a person who agrees with the Secretary of State to be wholly or partly responsible for the management of the centre.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Resident’: s 27.

Ministers noted during the passage of the Act that this person could be ‘a member of staff of a private sector or non-governmental organisation contracted to operate an accommodation centre. Alternatively, the centre manager may be a civil servant’ (Hansard, Standing Committee E, 7 May 2002, Col 94, Angela Eagle MP, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). Regulations under s 30(2)(b) could give the manager power to impose conditions of residence.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Facilities
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may arrange for the following to be provided to a resident of an accommodation centre—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)food and other essential items;
(b)money;
(c)assistance with transport for the purpose of proceedings under the Immigration Acts or in connection with a claim for asylum;
(d)transport to and from the centre;
(e)assistance with expenses incurred in connection with carrying out voluntary work or other activities;
(f)education and training;
(g)facilities relating to health;
(h)facilities for religious observance;
(i)anything which the Secretary of State thinks ought to be provided for the purpose of providing a resident with proper occupation and for the purpose of maintaining good order;
(j)anything which the Secretary of State thinks ought to be provided for a person because of his exceptional circumstances.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State may make regulations specifying the amount or maximum amount of money to be provided under subsection (1)(b).
(3)The Secretary of State may arrange for the provision of facilities in an accommodation centre for the use of a person in providing legal advice to a resident of the centre.

(4)The Secretary of State shall take reasonable steps to ensure that a resident of an accommodation centre has an opportunity to obtain legal advice before any appointment made by an immigration officer or an official of the Secretary of State for the purpose of obtaining information from the resident to be used in determining his claim for asylum.
(5)The Secretary of State may by order amend subsection (1) so as to add a reference to facilities which may be provided.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Resident’: s 27.

The list is exhaustive. However, Ministers noted during the passage of the Act that the list deals only with facilities that cannot be funded under statutory powers contained in other legislation (Hansard, Standing Committee E, 9 May 2002, Col 171 per Angela Eagle MP, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). The list is extremely broad, see especially sub-ss (1)(a)(i) and (f), and there is power to add to it under sub-s (5).
(1)(a) The definition ‘food and other essential items’ is substituted into s 95 of the IAA 1999 by s 44 of this Act, replacing the original ‘essential living needs’.

(1)(c) While on its face this subsection is broad enough to cover travel to a legal representative, Ministers indicated during the passage of the Act that were such travel necessary, they would expect it to be funded by the Legal Services Commission under its existing powers (Hansard HL Report, 10 July 2002, Vol 637, No 167, Col 779, Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Office).
(1)(f) For education of children see ss 36 and 37.

(3) and (4) During the passage of the Act, the government were urged to include ‘access to legal advice’ among the facilities listed. They declined to do so, arguing that legal advice was provided by the LCD, through the Legal Services Commission, and that the list in subs (1) was not concerned with facilities that could be made available under other powers. They introduced subs (3) instead. This did not satisfy those arguing for access to legal advice to be included in the list and therefore the government subsequently introduced what is now subs (4). Ministers insisted throughout the passage of the Act that it was their intention that residents of an accommodation centre should have access to legal advice, including legal advice on-site; their concern was that the imposition of a duty might present opportunities for delay on the part of the person accommodated. The meaning of reasonable steps will fall to be determined by a court. Ministers stated that they would not always delay an interview to give an asylum-seeker the opportunity to obtain legal representation, but it will be for the courts to determine whether the failure to delay was reasonable in an individual case (Hansard HL Report, 9 October 2002, Vol 639, No 183, Col 398, Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). Paragraph 91 of the Explanatory Notes to the Act glosses sub-s (4) as requiring the Secretary of State ‘to take reasonable steps to ensure that a resident has an opportunity to obtain legal advice before the appointment made for his substantive interview’. Such a reading would appear to be an unwarranted restriction upon the scope of the sub-s which on its face covers any interview the purpose of which is to obtain information relevant to the determination of the application for asylum.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Conditions of residence
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may make regulations about conditions to be observed by residents of an accommodation centre.
(2)Regulations under subsection (1) may, in particular, enable a condition to be imposed in accordance with the regulations by—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the Secretary of State, or
(b)the manager of an accommodation centre.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A condition imposed by virtue of this section may, in particular—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require a person not to be absent from the centre during specified hours without the permission of the Secretary of State or the manager;
(b)require a person to report to an immigration officer or the Secretary of State.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)If a resident of an accommodation centre breaches a condition imposed by virtue of this section, the Secretary of State may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require the resident and any dependant of his to leave the centre;
(b)authorise the manager of the centre to require the resident and any dependant of his to leave the centre.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)If a dependant of a resident of an accommodation centre breaches a condition imposed by virtue of this section, the Secretary of State may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require the resident and any dependant of his to leave the centre;
(b)authorise the manager of the centre to require the resident and any dependant of his to leave the centre.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)Regulations under this section must include provision for ensuring that a person subject to a condition is notified of the condition in writing.

(7)A condition imposed by virtue of this section is in addition to any restriction imposed under paragraph 21 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control of entry to United Kingdom) or under paragraph 2(5) of Schedule 3 to that Act (control pending deportation).
(8)A reference in this Part to a condition of residence is a reference to a condition imposed by virtue of this section.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Manager’: s 28. ‘Resident’: s 27.

Note that under sub-s (2) both the Secretary of State and the manager of the centre (see s 28) have power to impose conditions. However, only the Secretary of State has the power to withdraw support for a breach of conditions, under s 26, or authorise the manager to require the resident and dependants to leave under sub-ss 30(4) or (5).
Regulations under this section are made subject to the affirmative procedure in parliament by s 39(5).
(3) Compare para 21(2B) of Sch 2 to the IA 1971.

(7) The effect of this subsection is that the conditions imposed do not replace those imposed under Sch 2 of the IA 1971. Those conditions can still be imposed. By operation of s 23 (see note thereto) where a breach of conditions results in a decision that the asylum-seeker must leave the accommodation centre, it will be treated as a breach of any residence conditions obliging the asylum-seeker to reside in the centre.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Financial contribution by resident
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A condition of residence may, in particular, require a resident of an accommodation centre to make payments to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the Secretary of State, or
(b)the manager of the centre.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State may make regulations enabling him to recover sums representing the whole or part of the value of accommodation and other facilities provided to a resident of an accommodation centre if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)accommodation is provided for the resident in response to an application by him for support,
(b)when the application was made the applicant had assets which were not capable of being realised, and
(c)the assets have become realisable.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In subsection (2) “assets” includes assets outside the United Kingdom.
(4)An amount recoverable by virtue of regulations made under subsection (2) may be recovered—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)as a debt due to the Secretary of State;
(b)by another prescribed method (which may include the imposition or variation of a residence condition).

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Assets’: see sub-s (3). ‘Manager’: s 28. ‘Resident’: s 27.
(4)(b): See IAA 1999, Sch 2, para 21 for the types of residence restriction that can be imposed. It is unclear how any of these could constitute a method of recovering a sum of money.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Tenure
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A resident of an accommodation centre shall not be treated as acquiring a tenancy of or other interest in any part of the centre (whether by virtue of an agreement between the resident and another person or otherwise).
(2)Subsection (3) applies where—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the Secretary of State decides to stop arranging for the provision of accommodation in an accommodation centre for a resident of the centre, or
(b)a resident of an accommodation centre is required to leave the centre in accordance with section 30.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Where this subsection applies—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the Secretary of State or the manager of the centre may recover possession of the premises occupied by the resident, and
(b)the right under paragraph (a) shall be enforceable in accordance with procedure prescribed by regulations made by the Secretary of State.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Any licence which a resident of an accommodation centre has to occupy premises in the centre shall be an excluded licence for the purposes of the Protection from Eviction Act 1977 (c 43).
(5)The following shall be inserted after section 3A(7A) of the Protection from Eviction Act 1977 (disapplication of section 3: Part VI of Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33))—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(7B)Section 32 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (accommodation centre: tenure) provides for a resident’s licence to occupy an accommodation centre to be an excluded licence”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)The following shall be inserted after section 23A(5A) of the Rent (Scotland) Act 1984 (c 58) (excluded tenancies and occupancy rights)—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(5B)Nothing in section 23 of this Act applies to a resident’s occupancy of an accommodation centre provided under section 16 or 24(1)(b) of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (‘resident’ being construed in accordance with section 27 of that Act)”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (7)In this section a reference to an accommodation centre includes a reference to premises in which accommodation is provided under section 24(1)(b).

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Resident’: s 27. ‘Manager’: s 28.

A person in an accommodation centre will not be treated as acquiring a tenancy or interest in any part of the centre and any licence the person has will, by sub-s (4), be an excluded licence for the purposes of the Protection from Eviction Act 1977. The effect of this is that the Secretary of State can recover possession from a person without obtaining a court order.
(7) Those provided with accommodation pending the determination of their application for support, whether in an accommodation centre or not, will be subject to all the provisions of this section.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Advisory Groups
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State shall appoint a group (to be known as an Accommodation Centre Advisory Group) for each accommodation centre.
(2)The Secretary of State may by regulations—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)confer functions on Advisory Groups;
(b)make provision about the constitution and proceedings of Advisory Groups.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Regulations under subsection (2)(a) must, in particular, provide for members of an accommodation centre''s Advisory Group—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)to visit the centre;
(b)to hear complaints made by residents of the centre;
(c)to report to the Secretary of State.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)The manager of an accommodation centre must permit a member of the centre''s Advisory Group on request—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)to visit the centre at any time;
(b)to visit any resident of the centre at any time, provided that the resident consents.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)A member of an Advisory Group shall hold and vacate office in accordance with the terms of his appointment (which may include provision about retirement, resignation or dismissal).
(6)The Secretary of State may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)defray expenses of members of an Advisory Group;
(b)make facilities available to members of an Advisory Group.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Manager’: s 28. ‘Resident’: s 27.

Of the name ‘Advisory Groups’, the government stated during the passage of the Act ‘We felt it was important to differentiate between accommodation centres and removal centres […]. But beyond that, we have based the functions of the advisory groups very much on the model for visiting committees’ (Hansard HL Report 9 July 2002, Vol 637, No 166, Col 831, Lord Bassam of Brighton).

lnb-leg:heading.core:title: General
lnb-leg:heading.lnb-leg:para1: Section 34 provided for the appointment of a Monitor of Accommodation Centres, but was deleted by the UK Borders Act 2007.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Ancillary provisions
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The following provisions of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) shall apply for the purposes of this Part as they apply for the purposes of Part VI of that Act (support for asylum-seeker)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 105 (false representation),
(b)section 106 (dishonest representation),
(c)section 107 (delay or obstruction),
(d)section 108 (failure of sponsor to maintain),
(e)section 109 (offence committed by body),
(f)section 112 (recovery of expenditure),
(g)section 113 (recovery of expenditure from sponsor),
(h)section 124 (corporation sole), and
(i)section 127 (redirection of post).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In the application of section 112 a reference to something done under section 95 or 98 of that Act shall be treated as a reference to something done under section 17 or 24 of this Act.
(3)In the application of section 113 a reference to section 95 of that Act shall be treated as a reference to section 17 of this Act.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (1)(h) on Royal Assent, 7 November 2002. Sub-ss (1)(a)–(g), (i), (2), (3) to be appointed.

The provisions listed in sub-ss (1)(a) to (1)(d) all deal with criminal offences, by the supported person or by a third party, and the provision mentioned in subs (1)(e) deals with such offences when committed by a body corporate. The provisions listed in sub-ss (1)(f) and (1)(g) empower the Secretary of State to recover sums spent on support, whether from the supported person or a third party. Subsection (1)(h) applies the section making the Secretary of State a corporation sole for the purpose of exercising support functions. Subsection (1)(i) applies the Section allowing the Secretary of State to seek information about the redirection of post.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Education: general
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)For the purposes of section 13 of the Education Act 1996 (c 56) (general responsibility of [local authority]) a resident of an accommodation centre shall not be treated as part of the population of a [local authority’s] area.
(2)A child who is a resident of an accommodation centre may not be admitted to a maintained school or a maintained nursery (subject to section 37).
(3)But subsection (2) does not prevent a child’s admission to a school which is—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a community special school or a foundation special school, and
(b)named in a statement in respect of the child under section 324 of the Education Act 1996 (c 56) (special educational needs).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In subsections (2) and (3)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)“maintained school” means a maintained school within the meaning of section 20(7) of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998 (c 31) (definition), and
(b)“maintained nursery” means a facility for nursery education, within the meaning of section 117 of that Act, provided by a [local authority].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)The following shall not apply in relation to a child who is a resident of an accommodation centre (subject to section 37)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 86(1) and (2) of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998 (parental preference),
(b)section 94 of that Act (appeal),
(c)section 19 of the Education Act 1996 (education out of school),
(d)section 316(2) and (3) of that Act (child with special educational needs to be educated in mainstream school), and
(e)paragraphs 3 and 8 of Schedule 27 to that Act (special education needs: making of statement: parental preference).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)The power of the [First-tier Tribunal or the Special Educational Needs Tribunal for Wales] under section 326(3) of the Education Act 1996 (appeal against content of statement) is subject to subsection (2) above.

(7)A person exercising a function under this Act or the Education Act 1996 shall (subject to section 37) secure that a child who is a resident of an accommodation centre and who has special educational needs shall be educated by way of facilities provided under section 29(1)(f) of this Act unless that is incompatible with—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)his receiving the special educational provision which his learning difficulty calls for,
(b)the provision of efficient education for other children who are residents of the centre, or
(c)the efficient use of resources.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (8)A person may rely on subsection (7)(b) only where there is no action—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)which could reasonably be taken by that person or by another person who exercises functions, or could exercise functions, in respect of the accommodation centre concerned, and
(b)as a result of which subsection (7)(b) would not apply.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (9)An accommodation centre is not a school within the meaning of section 4 of the Education Act 1996 (definition); but—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)[Part 1 of the Education Act 2005 (school inspections)] shall apply to educational facilities provided at an accommodation centre as if the centre were a school (for which purpose a reference to the appropriate authority shall be taken as a reference to the person (or persons) responsible for the provision of education at the accommodation centre),
(b)section 329A of the Education Act 1996 (review or assessment of educational needs at request of responsible body) shall have effect as if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)an accommodation centre were a relevant school for the purposes of that section,
(ii)a child for whom education is provided at an accommodation centre under section 29(1)(f) were a registered pupil at the centre, and
(iii)a reference in section 329A to the responsible body in relation to an accommodation centre were a reference to any person providing education at the centre under section 29(1)(f), and
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (c)section 140 of the Learning and Skills Act 2000 (c 21) (learning difficulties: assessment of post-16 needs) shall have effect as if an accommodation centre were a school.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (10)Subsections (1), (2) and (5) shall not apply in relation to an accommodation centre if education is not provided for children who are residents of the centre under section 29(1)(f).
(11)An expression used in this section and in the Education Act 1996 (c 56) shall have the same meaning in this section as in that Act.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (1): words “local authority” and “local authority’s” in square brackets substituted by SI 2010/1158, art 5(1), Sch 2, Pt 2, para 51(1), (2)(a). Date in force: 5 May 2010: see SI 2010/1158, art 1. Sub-s (4): in para (b) words “local authority” in square brackets substituted by SI 2010/1158, art 5(1), Sch 2, Pt 2, para 51(1), (2)(b).
