Date in force: 5 May 2010: see SI 2010/1158, art 1. Sub-s (6): words “the Special Educational Needs Tribunal for Wales” in square brackets substituted by SI 2008/2833, art 9(1), Sch 3, para 197. Date in force: 3 November 2008: see SI 2008/2833, art 1(1). Sub-s (9): in para (a) words “Part 1 of the Education Act 2005 (school inspections)” in square brackets substituted by the Education Act 2005, s 61, Sch 9, para 30. Date in force (in relation to England): 1 September 2005: see SI 2005/2034, art 4. Date in force (in relation to Wales): 1 September 2006: see SI 2006/1338, art 3, Sch 1.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Education: special cases
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies to a child if a person who provides education to residents of an accommodation centre recommends in writing to the [local authority] for the area in which the centre is that this section should apply to the child on the grounds that his special circumstances call for provision that can only or best be arranged by the authority.
(2)A [local authority] may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)arrange for the provision of education for a child to whom this section applies;
(b)disapply a provision of section 36 in respect of a child to whom this section applies.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In determining whether to exercise a power under subsection (2) in respect of a child a [local authority] shall have regard to any relevant guidance issued by the Secretary of State.
(4)The governing body of a maintained school shall comply with a requirement of the [local authority] to admit to the school a child to whom this section applies.

(5)Subsection (4) shall not apply where compliance with a requirement would prejudice measures taken for the purpose of complying with a duty arising under section 1(6) of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998 (c 31) (limit on infant class size).

(6)A [local authority] may not impose a requirement under subsection (4) in respect of a school unless the authority has consulted the school in accordance with regulations made by the Secretary of State.

(7)In the case of a maintained school for which the [local authority] are the admission authority, the authority may not arrange for the admission of a child to whom this section applies unless the authority has notified the school in accordance with regulations made by the Secretary of State.
(8)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)“maintained school” means a maintained school within the meaning of section 20(7) of the School Standards and Framework Act 1998 (definition), and
(b)an expression which is also used in the Education Act 1996 (c 56) shall have the same meaning as it has in that Act.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Maintained school’: sub-s (8); School Standards and Framework Act 1998, s 20(7). ‘Resident’: s 27.
Amendment Sub-ss (1)–(4), (6), (7): words “local authority” in square brackets substituted by SI 2010/1158, art 5(1), Sch 2, Pt 2, para 51(1), (3). Date in force: 5 May 2010: see SI 2010/1158, art 1.

See note to s 36. This section deals with ‘special cases’ rather than the formula ‘special education needs’ used in s 36(3). Children with special education needs can be admitted to ‘special schools’. Children whose cases are ‘special cases’ can be admitted to mainstream schools. This does not remove the possibility that a child could both have special education needs and be a special case, and thus could be eligible for education in either a special school or a mainstream school. Under sub-s (2) an LEA can disapply any part of s 36, including the part relating to special education needs, save insofar as limitations are placed upon this by the Education Act 1996.
See also ss 40 and 41.

(1) This subsection was amended at a very late stage in the passage of the Act (House of Lords Consideration of Commons Amendments and Reasons, 6 November 2002 – the Bill received Royal Assent on 7 November 2002) with the addition of the words from ‘on the grounds that’ to the end of the subsection. See general note to s 36.
(3) The LEA is under a duty to ‘have regard to’ guidance issued by the Secretary of State (for the Home Office) but this is not binding on the authority.
(4) Schools are placed under a duty to provide a place for the children who are residents of an accommodation centre, subject to sub-s (5) below.
(5) The duty imposed by sub-s (4) is qualified to the extent that it is lifted where compliance would prejudice measures taken for the purpose of complying with the limit of infant class sizes.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Local authority
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A local authority may in accordance with arrangements made by the Secretary of State—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)assist in arranging for the provision of an accommodation centre;
(b)make premises available for an accommodation centre;
(c)provide services in connection with an accommodation centre.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In particular, a local authority may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)incur reasonable expenditure;
(b)provide services outside its area;
(c)provide services jointly with another body;
(d)form a company;
(e)tender for or enter into a contract;
(f)do anything (including anything listed in paragraphs (a) to (e)) for a preparatory purpose.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In this section “local authority” means—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a local authority within the meaning of section 94 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33), and

(b)a Northern Ireland authority within the meaning of section 110 of that Act and an Education and Library Board established under Article 3 of the Education and Libraries (Northern Ireland) Order 1986 (SI 1986/ 594 (NI 3)).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002 on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(h)).
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2). ‘Local authority’: sub-s (3); IAA 1999, ss 94 and 110; Art 3 of the Education and Libraries (Northern Ireland) Order 1986 (SI 594/1986).

Compare IAA 1999, s 99, and see also s 60 of this Act. Under those sections, local authorities already have broad powers to contract with the Secretary of State to provide support for asylum seekers. The powers are supplemented by this section, which ensures that local authorities are able to contract with the Secretary of State to run, or assist in running, accommodation centres.
(2)(a) This subsection is sufficiently broad to allow local authorities in one area to run accommodation centres in another, potentially distant, area.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: “Prescribed”: orders and regulations
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)In this Part “prescribed” means prescribed by the Secretary of State by order or regulations.
(2)An order or regulations under this Part may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)make provision which applies generally or only in specified cases or circumstances (which may be determined wholly or partly by reference to location);
(b)make different provision for different cases or circumstances;
(c)include consequential, transitional or incidental provision.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)An order or regulations under this Part must be made by statutory instrument.
(4)An order or regulations under any of the following provisions of this Part shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 17,
(b)section 19,
(c)section 20,
(d)section 21,
(e)section 26,
(f)section 29,
(g)section 31,
(h)section 32,
(i)section 33,
(j)section 37,
(k)section 40, and
(l)section 41.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)An order under section 25 or regulations under section 30 may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.
Definitions ‘prescribed’: sub-s (1).

The section deals with the extensive regulation-making powers under this Part of the Act. Orders or regulations made under sub-s (4) are subject to the negative procedure in parliament, whereby they become law unless an objection is raised; orders and regulations governed by subs (5) are subject to the affirmative procedure, whereby parliament must expressly approve them.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Scotland
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may not make arrangements under section 16 for the provision of premises in Scotland unless he has consulted the Scottish Ministers.
(2)The Secretary of State may by order make provision in relation to the education of residents of accommodation centres in Scotland.
(3)An order under subsection (2) may, in particular—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)apply, disapply or modify the effect of an enactment (which may include a provision made by or under an Act of the Scottish Parliament);
(b)make provision having an effect similar to the effect of a provision of section 36 or 37.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (1): Royal Assent, 7 November 2002: Sub-ss (2), (3): to be appointed.
Definitions ‘accommodation centres’: s 16(2).

Immigration is a power reserved to the Westminster parliament; community care and other support functions are devolved powers, as is education. The government have taken the view since the passage of Part 6 of the IAA 1999 that support for asylum-seekers falls within ‘immigration’ and this has never been tested in the Scots courts. This section encroaches further into the powers of the Scots parliament, allowing Westminster to ‘apply, disapply or modify’ the effect of any enactment by the Scots parliament. While there is an obligation under subs (1) to consult with the Scots ministers before establishing an accommodation centre in Scotland, there is no equivalent obligation to consult before disapplying or modifying enactments of the Scots Parliament in relation to education.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Northern Ireland
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may not make arrangements under section 16 for the provision of premises in Northern Ireland unless he has consulted the First Minister and the deputy First Minister.
(2)The Secretary of State may by order make provision in relation to the education of residents of accommodation centres in Northern Ireland.
(3)An order under subsection (2) may, in particular—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)apply, disapply or modify the effect of an enactment (which may include a provision made by or under Northern Ireland legislation);
(b)make provision having an effect similar to the effect of a provision of section 36 or 37.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (1): Royal Assent, 7 November 2002. Sub-ss (2), (3): to be appointed.
Definitions ‘accommodation centre’: s 16(2).
Similar provisions to those made under s 40 in respect of Scotland, see notes thereto.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Wales
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The Secretary of State may not make arrangements under section 16 for the provision of premises in Wales unless he has consulted the National Assembly for Wales.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent.

The obligation to consult the National Assembly for Wales prior to establishing an accommodation centre in Wales, parallels the provisions made in ss 40(2) and 41(2) in respect of Scotland and Northern Ireland. Subsections (2) and (3) of ss 40 and 41 find no echo in this section, because the relevant enactments already emanate from Westminster, rather than from the National Assembly for Wales.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Asylum-seeker: form of support
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may make an order restricting the application of section 96(1)(b) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (support for asylum-seeker: essential living needs)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in all circumstances, to cases in which support is being provided under section 96(1)(a) (accommodation), or
(b)in specified circumstances only, to cases in which support is being provided under section 96(1)(a).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)An order under subsection (1)(b) may, in particular, make provision by reference to—

Under s 95 of the IAA 1999 asylum seekers can elect to seek accommodation and support from the Home Office, or to find their own accommodation and ask the Secretary of State to provide support for living needs. This section provides a power to amend s 96 of the IAA 1999 so that the Secretary of State would no longer be able to provide ‘support only’ but would in all cases where support was offered, offer accommodation as part of the package. Those who had access to accommodation would not, by the wording of s 95(2) of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 44 of this Act, fail the destitution test in s 1999 on this ground. The type of support offered would be affected by this section, rather than eligibility for any support at all. See s 45 for amendments to s 96 of the IAA 1999.

This section amends ss 94 and 95 of the IAA 1999, which form the basis of the Home Office National Asylum Support Service (NASS) support scheme for asylum seekers. The amendments do not make huge changes in the operation of the support scheme, but any potential benefits of simplification are largely cancelled out by piecemeal version of the amendments and the failure to consolidate.

(2) The new requirement in sub-s (2)(b) that the asylum-seeker must be in the United Kingdom is new, and may be a consequence of the introduction of appeals from abroad in asylum cases under Pt 5 of this Act.
The other new requirement, mirroring s 113(1) in Pt 5 of this Act, is that a claim for asylum must be made at a designated place. See note to that section.

(3) The definition of ‘dependant’ is now left wholly to regulations. Spouses and dependant children were previously stated on the face of s 94(1) to be dependants and further categories of dependant were prescribed under reg 2 of the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/704), as amended. See also s 20.

(4) Ministers stated during the passage of the Act that they were reviewing the prescribed period, which stands at 28 days (see eg Hansard HL Report 24 October 2002, Vol 639, No 193, Col 1445, Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department; for the 28 day period see the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/704), as amended, reg 7).

Section 94 of the IAA 1999 provides that an appeal is disposed of on the date when it is no longer pending for the purposes of the Immigration Acts. This was a reference to the definition of pending in s 58(5) of that Act. Section 58 of the IAA 1999 is repealed by this Act. Section 104 of this Act, which replaces it, gives a definition of ‘pending’ in relation to appeals under s 82(1) of that Act. While this will in time cover all the appeal rights that could be being exercised by applicants for asylum support, it requires some creative reading to read s 104 as the definition to which s 94(4) of the 1999 Act refers. There is also the danger of a hiatus following repeal of s 58 because this would mean that there was no definition of ‘pending’ applicable to those applicants for support who had appealed under the 1999 Act.

Under s 58 of the 1999 Act, judicial review of the adjudicator''s decision to refuse the appeal, or the IAT''s refusal of leave to appeal, did not fall within the definition of a pending appeal. However, under s 104(2) an appeal will be treated as pending while it is the subject of a statutory review under s 101(2) and, by operation of s 94(4) of the 1999 Act, will not have been ‘disposed of’ for support purposes.
The claim for asylum is, by virtue of the amendments, treated as determined only for the purposes of s 94(1) and not for Pt 6 as a whole.

New subs 4(3A) of the IAA 1999 largely re-enacts sub-ss 94(5) and (6), repealed by subs (5) herein. Matters not picked up in sub-s (3A) are covered by other amendments to s 94 effected by this section. Families with children under 18 continue to be eligible for NASS support until either the claim is successful, or they leave the country. Note that the position of such families in relation to community care legislation is altered by Sch 3 to that Act. Under that schedule, while children can continue to receive support under community care legislation, including s 17 of the Children Act 1989, while in the country and under 18, adults who are ‘failed asylum-seekers’ within the meaning of para 6 of that schedule, are not eligible for such support under such provisions. Support for the child of a ‘failed asylum seeker’ under, for example, s 17 of the Children Act 1989, cannot, under the terms of the Schedule, extend to the parents. See note to Sch 3.
(5) See note to sub-s (4) above.

(6) See s 45 for amendments to s 96(1)(b) of the IAA 1999: the Secretary of State now has power to provide ‘food and other essential items’ rather than to provide for the ‘essential living needs’ of the supported asylum seeker. Similarly in this section, the reference to ‘essential living needs’ in the original s 96 is replaced with a reference to ‘food and other essential items’.
The powers in sub-s (7) place matters previously to be dealt with in regulations made under Sch 8 of the IAA 1999, in particular under paras 2 and 6, on the face of the statute.
(7) See note to s 19(6).

This section replaces s 122 of the IAA 1999. While it makes some changes to the section, the overall effect is to restate s 122 in clearer terms.

See note to s 44(4) of this Act, inserting a new s 94(3A) into the IAA 1999. This has the effect, previously achieved by s 94(5) of the IAA 1999, of ensuring that asylum-seeking families with children can continue to receive NASS support until the claim for asylum is successful or until they leave the country.

As with the old s 122, the new version ensures that there is a duty upon the Secretary of State to support families with children under 18. As with the previous version of s 122, the intention is that the family look first to the Secretary of State (NASS) for support, not to the duties of local authorities under the Children Acts.

A change from the old version of s 122(1) is that the duty to support a family kicks in when the family applies for support. However, while a local authority approached in the first instance, cannot point to an extant duty of the Secretary of State to support the family it can, under s 122(3)(c), refer the family to the Secretary of State for support. See note to s 17.

Under sub-s 122(2) the Secretary of State can offer the family accommodation in an accommodation centre, or in the NASS system outside the centres. The duty to provide support extends to the family as a whole, not just to the children.

The drafting of sub-s 122(3) goes some way to clearing up a confusion that existed under the old version of the section: what happens when a family does not immediately take up the Secretary of State''s offer of support? Subsection 122(3)(a) makes clear that a local authority is only prevented from supporting the family while the Secretary of State''s offer of support remains open in respect of that family. The previous version of the section did not deal with an offer of support remaining open and thus appeared to leave families in limbo if, for whatever reason, they did not at once accept the offer of support. Paragraph 127 of the Explanatory Notes to the Act envisages that were an offer of support withdrawn, sub-s 122(6) will apply in the same way as it would apply were support withdrawn.
The provision in sub-s 122(5) to disapply sub-s (3), re-enacts that found in the old sub-s 122(11).

Subsection 122(6) re-enacts the old sub-ss 122(8) and (9). The duty under the new sub-s 122(2) is to offer support, and, it would appear, as described above, to keep that offer open. This does not protect a supported family from losing their support, for example because they have breached the conditions under which support was provided (see s 50). Such a family is not free to apply to any local authority in the country, but must remain in the area where they were placed (and to which, for example, they were dispersed) by the Secretary of State.

Subsection 122(6) should be read with Sch 3 to this Act. See note to s 44(4). Where the adults in the family, subsequent to losing support from the Secretary of State, become ‘failed asylum seekers’ within the meaning of para 6 of that Schedule, the local authority loses its power to support them. See also note to Sch 3.

Definitions ‘asylum-seeker’: sub-s 44(2) amending the IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Local authority’: IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Voluntary organisation’: IAA 1999, s 167(1).

Unaccompanied children who seek asylum do not fall with the support scheme established by Part 6 of the IAA 1999 and amended by this Part (see note to s 44(2)). Instead they continue to be supported by local authorities under the Children Acts. This section deals with central government funding in respect of such children and removes the need for a special report in respect of such payment, under the Local Government Finance Act 1988.

Section 110 of the IAA 1999 empowers the Secretary of State to pay local authorities where they have incurred, or will incur, expenditure in supporting adult asylum-seekers and any dependants. A grant regime also exists so that the Secretary of State can make payments to local authorities supporting unaccompanied children. Provision was made in 2001 for payments made under that regime to take account of the additional costs of supporting children under s 20 of the Children Act 1989, which tends to have greater cost implications than support under s 17 of that Act. Subsection 48(a) places the grant regime for unaccompanied children within the s 110 framework.

Section 111 of the IAA 1999 is less detailed than s 110 but the overall effect is to provide a similar power as is provided for payments to local authorities under s 110 in respect of payments to voluntary organisations. Subsection 48(b) allows similar grants to be made in respect of support provided to unaccompanied children. Note that there already exist schemes whereby the Secretary of State funds voluntary organisations to work with unaccompanied asylum-seeking children; the best known being the Home Office funding for the Refugee Council’s Unaccompanied Children’s Panel.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Failed asylum-seeker
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)(Subsections (2)-(4) inserted at end of s 4 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 by this subsection).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent, (s 162(2)(n)).
Definitions ‘asylum-seeker’: sub-s (4)(a); s 44(2) amending the IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Claim for asylum’: sub-s (4)(b); IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Dependant’: sub-s (4); s 44(3) amending the IAA 1999, s 94(1).

The original s 4 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 empowered the Secretary of State accommodate, or to arrange for the accommodation of, those on temporary admission, and those either released, or bailed, from immigration detention, whether or not they were, or had been, asylum seekers. The section did not cover all failed asylum seekers; the amendments effected by this section ensure that it now does. Thus, for example, a person who applied for asylum while they had extant leave to enter or remain in the UK, and was neither on temporary admission nor a former detainee, would not have qualified for support under the old s 4, but does qualify for support under s 4 as amended by this section.

This section must be read with Sch 3, whereby powers to accommodate certain groups who would otherwise be eligible for s 4 support are curtailed, notably in respect of failed asylum-seekers and persons unlawfully in the UK who have failed to cooperate with removal directions. Provision is made within the schedule for temporary support pending travel for those falling within these categories. See also s 71, which allows residence restrictions to be imposed on those who applied for asylum while they had extant leave. Such people could be required to reside in s 4 accommodation.

This is a new power to use the support provisions to shore up immigration control, although residence at a particular address could already have been made a condition of support under the old s 95 of the IAA 1999. See also s 23 for further links between provisions of immigration control and support and s 71 for an extension of the powers to impose residence restrictions.

(2) The provision mirrors that made under sub-s (1)(b), but in respect of support provided by local authorities. Schedule 9 of the IAA 1999 deals with support from local authorities under the ‘interim scheme’ (see note to s 45(4)). There is no provision to mirror that made under sub-s (1)(a) in respect of support provided by local authorities.

(b)regard one of those matters as conclusive;

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force.

As far as the asylum-seeker is concerned, this section might be better entitled ‘No choice of form of support’, for the effect is to arrogate the choice of the form of support to be provided to the Secretary of State.

See s 53 on rights of appeal, inserting new ss 103, 103A and 103B into the IAA 1999. New s 103(4) makes clear that there is no right of appeal against a withdrawal of support under either s 17 of this Act or s 95 of the IAA 1999 where support is replaced immediately by support under the other provision. It would appear that the effect of this section, read with the oddly worded s 103(2), is that rights of appeal are similarly curtailed where the application is for support under one of these two sections; this is refused, and support is offered under the other section. But see note to s 17 for the likelihood that a single application will cover support under both sections. The more difficult question is the effect of an offer of support under s 4 of the IAA 1999. Nothing in s 103 of the IAA 1999 as amended suggests that support under s 4 ousts the right of appeal to an adjudicator against a refusal of support.
2(b) See s 49 amending s 4 of the IAA 1999. This section refers to s 94 by its previous name, which is no longer correct.

2(c) Note that temporary support under s 24(1) of this Act, and s 98 of the IAA 1999, can only be provided until a decision is made as to whether to provide support under s 17 of this Act or s 95 of the IAA 1999, or to refuse support altogether.

(3)(a) Ministers emphasised during the debates in parliament that although personal circumstances need not prove determinative of the decision as to which form of support to provide, there is no ban on taking them into account, and the government intends to do so. (See for example Hansard HL Report, 15 July 2002, Vol 637, No 170, Col 1001, Lord Bassam of Brighton).

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: Section 52 on the backdating of benefit for refugees was repealed by the Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc.) Act 2004.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Asylum-seeker: appeal against refusal to support
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The following shall be substituted for section 103 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (asylum support appeal)—

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Appeals: general
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies where a person has applied for support under—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 95,
(b)section 17 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002, or
(c)both.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The person may appeal to an adjudicator against a decision that the person is not qualified to receive the support for which he has applied.
(3)The person may also appeal to an adjudicator against a decision to stop providing support under a provision mentioned in subsection (1).
(4)But subsection (3) does not apply—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)to a decision to stop providing support under one of the provisions mentioned in subsection (1) if it is to be replaced immediately by support under the other provision, or
(b)to a decision taken on the ground that the person is no longer an asylum-seeker or the dependant of an asylum-seeker.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)On an appeal under this section an adjudicator may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require the Secretary of State to reconsider a matter;
(b)substitute his decision for the decision against which the appeal is brought;
(c)dismiss the appeal.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)An adjudicator must give his reasons in writing.

(7)If an appeal under this section is dismissed the Secretary of State shall not consider any further application by the appellant for support under a provision mentioned in subsection (1)(a) or (b) unless the Secretary of State thinks there has been a material change in circumstances.
(8)An appeal under this section may not be brought or continued by a person who is outside the United Kingdom.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Appeals: location of support under section 95
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may by regulations provide for a decision as to where support provided under section 95 is to be provided to be appealable to an adjudicator under this Part.
(2)Regulations under this section may provide for a provision of section 103 to have effect in relation to an appeal under the regulations with specified modifications.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Appeals: travelling expenses
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The Secretary of State may pay reasonable travelling expenses incurred by an appellant in connection with attendance for the purposes of an appeal under or by virtue of section 103 or 103A”.

core:comment.core:para: Not yet in force. But it has been amended by SI 2008/2833 to substitute ‘First-tier Tribunal’ for ‘adjudicator’.
Definitions ‘adjudicator’: IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Asylum-seeker’: s 44(2) amending IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Dependant’: s 44(3) amending IAA 1999. s 94(1).

This section replaces s 103 of the IAA 1999 with new ss 103, 103A and 103B. The majority of the provisions are unchanged, or amended only insofar as is necessary to make reference to the new power to support asylum seekers, in accommodation centres, contained in s 17 of this Act. The adjudicator''s decision is no longer expressly stated to be final (as was the case in the old s 103(6)) but no provision for further appeals from that decision is made.

The new sub-s 103(3) prevents those whose support in accommodation centre is withdrawn, but immediately replaced by support outside a centre, or vice versa, from appealing that decision. See note to s 51.
Subsection 103(4)(b) is new. A person who contends that the decision that they are no longer an asylum-seeker has been taken in error can challenge this only by judicial review.

New s 103B replaces the previous s 103(9) of the IAA 1999, re-enacts with modifications the old s 103(9) of that Act. During the passage of the Act, Ministers stated that the policy was to pay travel expenses (see Hansard Standing Committee E 14 April 2002, col 223, Rosie Winterton MP, Parliamentary Secretary LCD).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Withholding and withdrawal of support
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: Schedule 3 (which makes provision for support to be withheld or withdrawn in certain circumstances) shall have effect.

core:comment.core:para: 8 December 2002, for the purpose of enabling subordinate legislation to be made under it; 8 January 2003 in full (Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (Commencement No 1) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2811)).

See Note to Sch 3 and see the Withholding and Withdrawal of Support (Travel Assistance and Temporary Accommodation) Regulations 2002 (SI 2002/3078), into force 8 January 2003, which give effect to this section.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Late claim for asylum: refusal of support
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may not provide or arrange for the provision of support to a person under a provision mentioned in subsection (2) if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the person makes a claim for asylum which is recorded by the Secretary of State, and
(b)the Secretary of State is not satisfied that the claim was made as soon as reasonably practicable after the person''s arrival in the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The provisions are—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)sections 4, 95 and 98 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (support for asylum-seeker, &c), and
(b)sections 17 and 24 of this Act (accommodation centre).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)An authority may not provide or arrange for the provision of support to a person under a provision mentioned in subsection (4) if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the person has made a claim for asylum, and
(b)the Secretary of State is not satisfied that the claim was made as soon as reasonably practicable after the person''s arrival in the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)The provisions are—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 29(1)(b) of the Housing (Scotland) Act 1987 (c 26) (accommodation pending review),
(b)section 188(3) or 204(4) of the Housing Act 1996 (c 52) (accommodation pending review or appeal), . . .
(c)section 2 of the Local Government Act 2000 (c 22) (promotion of well-being))[, and
(d)section 1 of the Localism Act 2011 (local authority’s general power of competence)].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)This section shall not prevent—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the exercise of a power by the Secretary of State to the extent necessary for the purpose of avoiding a breach of a person''s Convention rights (within the meaning of the Human Rights Act 1998 (c 42)),
(b)the provision of support under section 95 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) or section 17 of this Act in accordance with section 122 of that Act (children), or

(c)the provision of support under section 98 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 or section 24 of this Act (provisional support) to a person under the age of 18 and the household of which he forms part.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)An authority which proposes to provide or arrange for the provision of support to a person under a provision mentioned in subsection (4)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must inform the Secretary of State if the authority believes that the person has made a claim for asylum,
(b)must act in accordance with any guidance issued by the Secretary of State to determine whether subsection (3) applies, and
(c)shall not be prohibited from providing or arranging for the provision of support if the authority has complied with paragraph (a) and (b) and concluded that subsection (3) does not apply.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (7)The Secretary of State may by order—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)add, remove or amend an entry in the list in subsection (4);
(b)provide for subsection (3) not to have effect in specified cases or circumstances.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (8)An order under subsection (7)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)may include transitional, consequential or incidental provision,
(b)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(c)may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (9)For the purposes of this section ‘claim for asylum’ has the same meaning as in section 18.

(10)A decision of the Secretary of State that this section prevents him from providing or arranging for the provision of support to a person is not a decision that the person does not qualify for support for the purpose of section 103 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (appeals).
(11)This section does not prevent a person''s compliance with a residence restriction imposed in reliance on section 70 (induction).

core:comment.core:para: 8 January 2003 (The Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (Commencement No 1) Order 2002 (SI 2811 /2002)).

Sub-s (4): in para (b) word omitted repealed by SI 2012/961, art 2, Sch 1, paras 2, 3(a). Date in force: 28 March 2012: see SI 2012/961, art 1(2). Sub-s (4): para (d) and word “, and” immediately preceding it inserted by SI 2012/961, art 2, Sch 1, paras 2, 3(b). Date in force: 28 March 2012: see SI 2012/961, art 1(2).
Definitions ‘claim for asylum’: sub-s (9), see also s 18(3). ‘Convention Rights’: Human Rights Act 1998, s 1. ‘Residence restriction’: s 70(2).

See the Asylum Support (Amendment) (No 3) Regulations 2002 (SI 2002/3110), into force 8 January 2002. The regulations amend the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/704) to give effect both to this section and to s 57. See also note to s 57.

Under this section and the regulations that give effect to it, people who have not proved to the satisfaction of the Secretary of State that they claimed asylum ‘as soon as reasonably practicable’ have no entitlement to support, save insofar as provided for by sub-s (5) or insofar as they can bring themselves within the provisions of community care legislation not mentioned in sub-s (4). Save in the limited circumstances mentioned, no provision is made for support while the question of the timeliness of the application is disputed (see note to sub-s (2)). The dispute may be lengthy, for sub-s (10) bars an appeal to an Asylum Support Adjudicator, leaving judicial review as the only route of challenge to a decision.

The schedule to the Withholding and Withdrawal of Support Regulations 2002 amends the application form in the schedule to the Asylum Support Regulations 2000, inserting a number of questions about the date of arrival in the United Kingdom and the timing of the application for support which go both to this section and to s 57. The new questions do not address the practicability of having claimed earlier, or to the reasons for the delay.

Ministers indicated during the passage of the Act that guidance would be issued dealing with the operation of this section (see for example Hansard HL Report 17 October 2002, Vol 639, No 189, Col 981, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department, The Lord Filkin).

Note that the section refers to the asylum-seeker and not to dependants, although a dependant can be the main applicant for support purposes. This raises the question of whether, where the principal applicant was deemed not to have claimed as soon as reasonably practicable, a dependant could still make an application for support.

(1) The Secretary of State has no power to support an applicant until the applicant has satisfied him that the claim was made as soon as reasonably practicable, placing the burden of proof on the applicant. Ministers gave examples during the debates in parliament of when a claim would be taken to have been made ‘as soon as reasonably practicable’. Examples of acceptable reasons for delay given during the debates included severe physical illness (Hansard HL Report, 17 October 2002, Vol 639, No 189, Col 979, Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department); the effects of torture or inhumane treatment trauma arising from torture (ibid); ‘genuine and honest errors’ about the correct way to claim (Hansard HL Report 24 October 2002, Vol 639, No 193, Col 1472, Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). Ministers stated that all claims made at port would be deemed to have been made as soon as reasonably practicable (ibid).

(2) Note that the prohibition extends to support under s 94 of the IAA 1999 (see note to s 49) and under the provisions of s 24 of this Act and s 98 of the IAA 1999, which allow temporary support to be provided while a claim for support is determined.
(3) It is the Secretary of State, not the local authority, who must be satisfied of the timeliness of the claim. However, see sub-s (6).

(4) This is far from being an exhaustive list of the community care provisions under which asylum seekers can receive support. It can be contrasted with, for example, the list of provisions in sub-ss 45(5) to (7), in s 46, and in para 1 of Sch 3. Thus asylum seekers who qualify for support under community care legislation because of their special needs, remain eligible for such support. (See R (on the application of Westminster City Council) v National Asylum Support Services
[2002] UKHL 38 , [2002] 4 All ER 654 ). See note to sub-s (7).

(5) Under sub-s (5)(a) support can be provided to avoid a breach of rights under the European Convention on Human Rights. The power to provide support in these circumstances is given to the Secretary of State, rather than to local authorities. The parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights, commenting on the clause that became s 55, stated:

core:blockquote.core:para: ‘… we find it hard to envisage circumstances in which a person could be destitute within the meaning of the Bill and yet not suffer a violation of rights under Articles 3 and/or 8’. (JCHR, 23rd Report of the Session 2001–2002, HL Paper 176; HC 1255).

core:comment.core:para: See also the case of Q, described in the general note to this section. The effect of sub-s (5)(b) is that the Secretary of State retains the duty imposed by s 122 of the IAA 1999 (as amended by s 47 of this Act) to support families with children. Under sub-s (5)(c) families with children can also receive temporary support while their eligibility for support is determined.

(6) While sub-s (3) requires that the Secretary of State be satisfied that an asylum-seeker has claimed asylum as soon as reasonably practicable, sub-s (6)(b) admits the possibility of local authorities applying the test to an individual case, with or without the benefit of guidance issued by the Secretary of State. The obligation to notify the Secretary of State that the person has made a claim for asylum is however independent of the decision to provide support.

(7) and (8) Subsection (7)(a) makes provision for flexibility in the treatment of classes of cases. It allows the Secretary of State to extend by order, subject to the approval of parliament (see subs (8)), the prohibition on local authorities providing support under community care legislation to legislation other than that mentioned in sub-s (4), or he can by order allow support to be provided under the legislation listed therein. In addition, by sub-s (7)(b), he can by order give local authorities the power to provide support in certain classes of case. The provision is broad enough to allow him to make special provision for individual cases, although this would have to be done by order.

(9) See note to s 18. A claim for asylum is defined therein as a claim that removal would be a breach of the United Kingdom''s obligations under the 1951 United Nations Convention relating to the status of refugees, or that it would be a breach of the UK''s obligations under Article 3 of the ECHR; this corresponds to the definition given in s 94 of the IAA 1999.

(10) There is no right of appeal to an asylum support adjudicator against a refusal on the basis that a claim has not been made as soon as reasonably practicable. Instead the only recourse is an application for judicial review; but the applicant will not receive support while this application is pending unless s/he falls within the provisions of sub-s (5) or can obtain support under community care legislation. It is therefore anticipated that attempts will be made to expedite judicial reviews under this section, as happened in the case of Q, see general note to this section, or to rely on subs (5) in seeking directions from the court that the Secretary of State must provide support.
(11) See note to s 70. The residence restriction can be imposed for up to 14 days.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Provision of support by local authority
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Section 99 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (provision of support by local authority) shall be amended as follows.
(2)In subsection (1)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)after “local authority” insert “or Northern Ireland authority”, and
(b)at the end add “or 98”.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)For subsections (2) and (3) substitute—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(2)Support may be provided by an authority in accordance with arrangements made with the authority or with another person.
(3)Support may be provided by an authority in accordance with arrangements made under section 95 only in one or more of the ways mentioned in section 96(1) and (2)”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In subsection (4)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)for “A local authority” substitute “An authority”, and
(b)at the end add “or 98”.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)In subsection (5)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)for “a local authority” substitute “an authority”, and
(b)in paragraph (b) for “bodies who are not local authorities” substitute “other bodies”.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (see s 162(2)(p)).
Definitions ‘local authority’: IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Northern Ireland authority’: s 60(2) amending IAA 1999, s 94(1).

Under s 99 of the IAA 1999 local authorities can contract with the Home Office to deliver accommodation, food and other essential items under s 95 of that Act. The section extends those powers so that local authorities can also contract with the Home Office to provide temporary support, support until the outcome of the application for support is determined, under s 98 of the IAA 1999, or to provide the accommodation centres to be established under Pt 3 of this Act.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Application for support: false or incomplete information
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: At the end of paragraph 12(c) of Schedule 8 to the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (asylum-seeker support: procedure: disregarding of application) there shall be inserted “(which may, in particular, provide for an application not to be entertained where the Secretary of State is not satisfied that the information provided is complete or accurate or that the applicant is co-operating with enquiries under paragraph (d))’”.

core:comment.core:para: 8 December 2002 (Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (Commencement No 1) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2811)).

See the Asylum Support (Amendment) (No 3) Regulations 2002 (SI 3110/2002), into force 8 January 2002. The regulations amend the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 704/2000) to give effect both to this section and to s 55. Regulation 2 of SI 3110/2002 substitutes a new reg 3(4) into SI 704/2000, which provides that the Secretary of State may not entertain an application for support where it is not made in accordance with reg 3(3) or ‘where the Secretary of State is not satisfied that the application is complete or accurate or that the applicant is co-operating with enquiries made under regulation (5)’. Regulation 3(3) of SI 704/2000 requires that the application be made in writing, in English, on the form in the schedule to the regulations. Regulation 3(5) of those regulations is broadly drafted, stating that ‘The Secretary of State may make further enquiries of the applicant about any matter connected with the application’.

The schedule to SI 3110/2002 amends the application form to include questions about when and how a person came to the UK, how they have supported themselves since arrival, and when and where they made the claim for asylum.
Examining what is now s 57, the parliamentary Joint Committee on Human Rights said:

core:quoted-listitem.core:para: The power to make regulations under Schedule 8 to the 1999 Act is directed to regulating the provision of support to asylum seekers... In the context of the Schedule, it seems likely to us that regulations concerning further enquiries to be made by the Secretary of State... would have to be directed to enquiries concerned with matters set out in paragraphs 2 to 11. They must be related to the provision of support…

…we consider it at least to be possible that any attempt to use paragraph 12 to withhold support from a person because they have not provided information unrelated to their personal circumstances would be unlawful; it would amount to the use of a power for an extraneous or improper purpose. (23rd Report of the Session 2001–2002, HL Paper 176; HC 1255).

core:comment.core:para: The government refuted this suggestion, stating ‘When and how a person arrives in the United Kingdom is crucial to whether we can be satisfied whether he is destitute’ (Hansard 24 October 2002, Vol 639, No 193, Lord Filkin Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). The matter has yet to be tested in the courts.

While s 55 expressly bars an appeal to an asylum support adjudicator, no equivalent provision appears in s 57 and it remains to be tested whether the refusal to entertain an application will be held to trigger a right of appeal to an asylum support adjudicator under s 103 of the IAA 1999 as amended by s 53 of this Act.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Voluntary departure from United Kingdom
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A person is a “voluntary leaver” for the purposes of this section if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)he is not a British citizen or an EEA national,
(b)he leaves the United Kingdom for a place where he hopes to take up permanent residence (his “new place of residence”), and
(c)the Secretary of State thinks that it is in the person''s interest to leave the United Kingdom and that the person wishes to leave.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State may make arrangements to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)assist voluntary leavers;
(b)assist individuals to decide whether to become voluntary leavers.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The Secretary of State may, in particular, make payments (whether to voluntary leavers or to organisations providing services for them) which relate to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)travelling and other expenses incurred by or on behalf of a voluntary leaver, or a member of his family or household, in leaving the United Kingdom;
(b)expenses incurred by or on behalf of a voluntary leaver, or a member of his family or household, on or shortly after arrival in his new place of residence;
(c)the provision of services designed to assist a voluntary leaver, or a member of his family or household, to settle in his new place of residence;
(d)expenses in connection with a journey undertaken by a person (with or without his family or household) to prepare for, or to assess the possibility of, his becoming a voluntary leaver.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In subsection (1)(a) ‘EEA national’ means a national of a State which is a contracting party to the Agreement on the European Economic Area signed at Oporto on 2nd May 1992 (as it has effect from time to time).
(5)The following provisions of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) shall cease to have effect—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 29 (contributions to expenses of persons returning abroad), and
(b)section 31(d) (expenses).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(q)).
Definitions ‘EEA national’: sub-s (4). ‘New place of residence’: subs (1)(b). ‘Voluntary leaver’: sub-s (1).
Subsection (5) repeals ss 29 and 31(2) of the IA 1971, which provided narrower powers to assist immigrants to leave the UK and is replaced by this new section.

(1) The exclusion of EEA nationals in sub-s (1)(a) is a new provision, not found in s 29 of the IA 1971. However, see Sch 3, para 8, where there is power to assist these nationals to leave the UK in the circumstances set out in the Schedule.
(2) The powers contained in this subsection are new and have no equivalent in the Immigration Act 1971.

(3) The powers contained in sub-s (3)(b) to (d) are new and have no equivalent in the IA 1971. Existing schemes are run by Refugee Action, an NGO, and the International Organisation of Migration. This subsection will enable payments to be made directly to such organisations.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: International projects
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may participate in a project which is designed to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)reduce migration,
(b)assist or ensure the return of migrants,
(c)facilitate co-operation between States in matters relating to migration,
(d)conduct or consider research about migration, or
(e)arrange or assist the settlement of migrants (whether in the United Kingdom or elsewhere).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In particular, the Secretary of State may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)provide financial support to an international organisation which arranges or participates in a project of a kind described in subsection (1);
(b)provide financial support to an organisation in the United Kingdom or another country which arranges or participates in a project of that kind;
(c)provide or arrange for the provision of financial or other assistance to a migrant who participates in a project of that kind;

(d)participate in financial or other arrangements which are agreed between Her Majesty’s Government and the government of one or more other countries and which are or form part of a project of that kind.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)“migrant” means a person who leaves the country where he lives hoping to settle in another country (whether or not he is a refugee within the meaning of any international Convention), and
(b)“migration” shall be construed accordingly.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Subsection (1) does not—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)confer a power to remove a person from the United Kingdom, or
(b)affect a person’s right to enter or remain in the United Kingdom.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002: Royal Assent (s 162(2)(r)).
Definitions ‘migrant’: sub-s (3)(b). ‘Migration’: sub-s (3)(b).

See also s 58, which provides complementary powers. The section provides broad powers to fund projects across the whole field of international migration, although debates during the passage of the Act focused on the possibility of establishing a ‘resettlement’ scheme under which persons recognised as refugees overseas, by the UK immigration service or others (for example the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees—UNHCR) could travel to the UK to live here as refugees under the UK’s protection. UNHCR’s policy on resettlement is set out in their Resettlement Handbook available from UNHCR.

In debates during the passage of the Act the government indicated that the UK’s resettlement scheme was expected to start in 2003 and to cater initially for around 500 people (see eg Hansard HL Report, 24 October 2002, Vol 639, No 193, Cols 1479–1480, Lord Bassam of Brighton).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Northern Ireland authorities
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)In section 110(9) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (support: payment to local authority: Northern Ireland authority) after paragraph (b) there shall be added—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: “; or
(c)a Health and Social Services trust established under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1991 (SI 1991/194 (NI 1)”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In section 94(1) of that Act (support: interpretation) after the definition of “local authority” there shall be inserted—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: “Northern Ireland authority’ has the meaning given by section 110(9)”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 1/2003).
Definitions ‘local authority’: IAA 1999, s 94(1). ‘Northern Ireland authority’: subs (2) amending the IAA 1999, ss 94(1) and 110(9).

Section 110 of the IAA 1999 allows the Secretary of State to make payments to local authorities for the support of asylum seekers (see note to s 48). Under the IAA 1999 this power did not extend to Northern Ireland, because the NASS support scheme did not operate there. This section gives Northern Ireland authorities the same powers as local authorities in other parts of the UK to contract with the Home Office to provide support to asylum seekers.
(1) For the existing powers of Health and Social Services Boards in Northern Ireland to contract with the Home Office, see IAA 1999 s 110(9)(b).
(2) See the IAA 1999 s 99(3) for powers to make payments to the Northern Ireland Executive.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Repeal of spent provisions
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The following provisions of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 shall cease to have effect—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 96(4) to (6) (which relate to a provision about support for asylum-seekers which has been repealed by order), and
(b)section 166(4)(e) (order under section 96(5): procedure).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(s)).

These provisions all relate to the scheme whereby asylum seekers received most of their support not in cash, but in vouchers in accordance with s 96(3) of the IAA 1999. In December 2001 the Secretary of State for the Home Department exercised the powers contained in s 98(5) of that Act to repeal s 96(3) and vouchers were abolished. The need for the provisions repealed by this section fell away.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Detention by Secretary of State
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A person may be detained under the authority of the Secretary of State pending—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a decision by the Secretary of State whether to give directions in respect of the person under [section 10 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (removal of persons unlawfully in the United Kingdom) or] paragraph 10, 10A or 14 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control of entry: removal), or
(b)removal of the person from the United Kingdom in pursuance of directions given by the Secretary of State under any of those [provisions].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)Where the Secretary of State is empowered under section 3A of [the Immigration Act 1971] (powers of Secretary of State) to examine a person or to give or refuse a person leave to enter the United Kingdom, the person may be detained under the authority of the Secretary of State pending—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the person’s examination by the Secretary of State,
(b)the Secretary of State’s decision to give or refuse the person leave to enter,
(c)a decision by the Secretary of State whether to give directions in respect of the person under paragraph 8 or 9 of Schedule 2 to that Act (removal), or
(d)removal of the person in pursuance of directions given by the Secretary of State under either of those paragraphs.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A provision of Schedule 2 to that Act about a person who is detained or liable to detention under that Schedule shall apply to a person who is detained or liable to detention under this section: and for that purpose—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a reference to paragraph 16 of that Schedule shall be taken to include a reference to this section,
[(aa)a reference in paragraph 18B of that Schedule to an immigration officer shall be read as a reference to the Secretary of State,]
(b)a reference in paragraph 21 of that Schedule to an immigration officer shall be taken to include a reference to the Secretary of State, and
(c)a reference to detention under that Schedule or under a provision or Part of that Schedule shall be taken to include a reference to detention under this section.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In the case of a restriction imposed under paragraph 21 of that Schedule by virtue of this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a restriction imposed by an immigration officer may be varied by the Secretary of State, and
(b)a restriction imposed by the Secretary of State may be varied by an immigration officer.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (7)A power under this section which is exercisable pending a decision of a particular kind by the Secretary of State is exercisable where the Secretary of State has reasonable grounds to suspect that he may make a decision of that kind.

(8)At the end of section 11(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (person not deemed to have entered United Kingdom while detained, &c) there shall be inserted “or section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002”.

(9)In section 24(1)(e) of the Immigration Act 1971 (offence: failure to comply with restriction) for “or to an immigration officer” there shall be substituted “, to an immigration officer or to the Secretary of State”.
(10)In the Mental Health Act 1983 (c 20)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)at the end of section 48(2)(d) (detained persons susceptible to transfer for mental treatment: immigration) there shall be added “or under section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (detention by Secretary of State)”, and
(b)in the heading of section 53 (supplemental provision) the reference to the Immigration Act 1971 becomes a reference to the Immigration Acts.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (11)In the Mental Health (Scotland) Act 1984 (c 36)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)at the end of section 71(2)(c) (detained persons who may be transferred to hospital for mental treatment) there shall be added “or under section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (detention by the Secretary of State)”, and

(b)at the end of section 74(1)(b) (further provision about such persons) there shall be added “or under section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (detention by the Secretary of State)”.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (12)In the Mental Health (Northern Ireland) Order 1986 (SI 1986/595 (NI 4))—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)at the end of Article 54(2)(d) (detained persons susceptible to transfer for mental treatment: immigration) there shall be added “or under section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (detention by Secretary of State)”, and
(b)in the heading of Article 59 (supplemental provision) the reference to the Immigration Act 1971 becomes a reference to the Immigration Acts.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (13)Section 53 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (bail) shall be amended as follows—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)at the end of subsection (1) add “or under section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002”, and
(b)at the end of subsection (3)(a) add “or under section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002”.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (14)In section 147 of that Act (detention centres: interpretation) at the end of the definition of “detained persons” there shall be inserted “or under section 62 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (detention by Secretary of State);”.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (1): in para (a) words from “section 10 of” to “United Kingdom) or” in square brackets inserted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 1, para 3(1), (2)(a)(i).
