lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Control of entry to United Kingdom, etc: use of force
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: In paragraph 17(2) of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control of entry, &c: person liable to detention: use of force) for “if need be by force” there shall be substituted “if need be by reasonable force”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 1/2003).

During the passage of the Act, the government were under pressure to insert the word ‘reasonable’ into what is now subs 64(4). They were opposed to doing so, arguing that this was implied. When they agreed to do so, they decided that they would also insert the word into para 17(2) in order to make clear that immigration and police officers exercising their powers under this paragraph are under the same obligations as detainee custody officers to use reasonable force when entering premises for the purposes of search and detention.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Escorts
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Paragraphs (3–(5) inserted after paragraph 17(2) of Sch 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 by this subsection),

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 1/2003).

Definitions ‘detainee custody officer’: subs (5); IA 1971, Sch 2, para 17(5) as inserted by this section; IAA 1999, s 147. ‘Certificate of authorisation’: IAA 1999, s 147. ‘Search’: subs (5); IA 1971, Sch 13, para 2(1)(a).

The IAA 1999 made provision for detainee custody officers, certified persons empowered to exercise certain detention and escort functions. Detainee custody officers have the power to search a detained person. Thus the word ‘search’ in the new sub-para 17(4) of Sch 2 to the IA 1971 refers to the search of a detained person, not of premises or other people on the premises. It is broad enough to authorise strip searches. The detainee custody officer can only enter the premises where an immigration or police officer holding a search warrant makes such an entry. Ministers emphasised during the passage of the Act that detainee custody officers would always be accompanied on the premises by immigration or police officers (see for example Hansard Standing Committee E, 14 May 2002, Col 242, Rosie Winterton MP, Parliamentary Secretary, LCD). It is therefore unclear in what circumstances detainee custody officers themselves will be using the power given them by the new sub-para 17(4) inserted by this section power to enter premises, if necessary by reasonable force.

The detainee custody officer is the only person with power to strip search a person on the premises. Immigration and police officers, who, unlike detainee custody officers, have to act in accordance with the PACE (Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984) Codes of Practice, would have to take the person to a police station or other authorised location to conduct such a search. See also ss 74 and 153.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Detention centres: custodial functions
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)(Subsection (5) of s 154 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 substituted by this subsection).
(2)(Paragraph 8 of Sch 11 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 inserted by this subsection).
(3)(Paragraph 9 of Sch 12 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 inserted by this subsection).

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 1/2003).
Definitions ‘detainee custody officer’: IAA 1999, s 147. ‘Prisoner custody officer’: IAA 1999, s 147. ‘Custodial functions’: IAA 1999, s 147.

Section 154(5) of the IAA 1999 allowed the Secretary of State to confer the functions of detainee custody officers on prison officers or prisoner custody officers where he considered it necessary to do so. Subsection (1) of this section removes the need for any consideration of necessity. Subsections (2) and (3) ensure that references to detainee custody officers detailing their powers and duties in Schs 11 and 12 to the IAA 1999 will also apply to prison officers and prisoner custody officers on whom the functions of detainee custody officers have been conferred under this section.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Detention centres: change of name
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)In section 147 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (Part VIII: interpretation)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the definition of “detention centre” shall cease to have effect, and
(b)the following shall be inserted after the definition of “prisoner custody officer”—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: ‘‘removal centre” means a place which is used solely for the detention of detained persons but which is not a short-term holding facility, a prison or part of a prison;”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In the provisions listed in subsection (3) (and any relevant headings)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)for the words “detention centre” there shall be substituted the words ‘removal centre’, and
(b)for the words “detention centres” there shall be substituted the words ‘removal centres’.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The provisions are—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in section 147 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (Part VIII: interpretation), the definitions of “contracted out detention centre”, “contractor”, “custodial functions”, “detention centre contract”, “detention centre rules”, and “directly managed detention centre”,
(b)section 148 of that Act (management of centre),
(c)sections 149 and 150 of that Act (contracting out),
(d)section 151 of that Act (intervention by Secretary of State),
(e)section 152 of that Act (visiting committee),
(f)section 153 of that Act (rules),
(g)section 155 of that Act (custodial functions),
(h)section 157 of that Act (short-term holding facility),
(i)section 158 of that Act (disclosure of information),
(j)section 159 of that Act (power of constable),
(k)Schedule 11 to that Act (detainee custody officer),
(l)Schedule 12 to that Act (procedure at detention centre),
(m)Schedule 13 to that Act (escort),
(n)section 141(5)(e) and (6) of that Act (fingerprinting),
(o)section 5A(5A) of the Prison Act 1952 (c 52) (Chief Inspector of Prisons), and
(p)paragraph 13 of Schedule 4A to the Water Industry Act 1991 (c 56) (disconnection).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)A reference in an enactment or instrument to a detention centre within the meaning of Part VIII of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) shall be construed as a reference to a removal centre within the meaning of that Part.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 1/2003).
Definitions ‘removal centre’: sub-s (1)(b), amending IAA 1999, s 147.

The title of this section explains its content; in all cases and for all purposes detention centres are renamed removal centres. It is perhaps bizarre that this section did not come into force on Royal Assent, given that in practice the name ‘removal centre’ was from the start being used by the Home Office rather than ‘detention centre’. The change is limited to a change of name and while it may imply a shift in emphasis, does not effect any change in the nature and function of the establishments renamed.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Construction of reference to person liable to detention
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies to the construction of a provision which—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)does not confer power to detain a person, but
(b)refers (in any terms) to a person who is liable to detention under a provision of the Immigration Acts.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The reference shall be taken to include a person if the only reason why he cannot be detained under the provision is that—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)he cannot presently be removed from the United Kingdom, because of a legal impediment connected with the United Kingdom’s obligations under an international agreement,
(b)practical difficulties are impeding or delaying the making of arrangements for his removal from the United Kingdom, or
(c)practical difficulties, or demands on administrative resources, are impeding or delaying the taking of a decision in respect of him.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)This section shall be treated as always having had effect.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(t))

The clause that became this section was originally introduced into parliament without subs (1)(a) and under the title ‘Liability to detention: interpretation’. There was widespread concern that it massively extended existing powers to detain. The wording was changed to reflect what Ministers stated to be the intention behind the clause: to ensure that the Home Office had power to grant temporary admission in cases where removal could not be effected. Mr Justice Crane held in R (on the application of Huez) v Secretary of State for the Home Department
[2002] EWHC 1597 (Admin) , [2002] All ER (D) 339 (Jul) that because in such circumstances removal was not ‘pending’ within the meaning of the s 4(2) and paras 8, 16 and 21 of the IA 1971, there was no power to detain and therefore no power to grant temporary admission. One consequence was that there was no power to make people in this position subject to the conditions, such as restrictions on employment or reporting obligations, that can be attached to temporary admission. Huez and Khadir were Iraqi Kurds. It had been held that they did not qualify for refugee status because they could live in safety in the Kurdish Autonomous Area of Iraq, but there was no means of getting them there. Mr Justice Crane held that in the circumstances, consideration should be given to a grant of Exceptional Leave to Remain. But this was reversed by the Court of Appeal in R (on the application of Khadir) v Secretary of State for the Home Department
[2003] EWCA Civ 475 , holding that Mr Khadir was indeed to be regarded as being on temporary admission, and that it was not appropriate to grant Exceptional Leave.

The effect of the clause as amended is to ensure that those in the position of Huez and Khadir can be granted temporary admission. Conditions and restrictions can be imposed upon such admission. The conceptual difficulty arises where the person breaches those conditions or restrictions: if the rationale for this section is that such persons cannot be detained then breach of conditions or restrictions cannot be backed by the threat of detention, save insofar as this is consequential upon ‘criminal liability’, following conviction for an offence, see note to sub-s (3)).

(2)(a)) The description of one legal obligation, for the examples given during the debates included art 3 of the ECHR, incorporated into UK law by the Human Rights Act 1998, as a ‘legal impediment’ to the exercise of another, is a surprising departure.

(3) Ministers stated that the government intended that the retrospective effect of the provision would not operate to create criminal liability under s 24(1)(e) of the IA 1971 for a breach of restrictions on temporary admission imposed under para 21 of Sch 2, or para 2(5) of Sch 3 to the IA 1971, retrospectively made legal by the coming into force of this section. They stated: ‘Criminal liability would however, arise if a person whose restrictions had been validated by this clause failed to comply with such restrictions without a reasonable excuse after the clause comes into force’ (Hansard HL Report, 10 October 2002, Vol 639, No 184, Cols 457–458, Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). However, the House of Lords Select Committee on the Constitution said of the clause ‘9. …although it was not intended to impose criminal liability retrospectively its plain words make it obvious that it could well have that effect’ (7th Report of the Session 2001–2002, HL Paper 173, 22 October 2002). No further elucidation of the term ‘criminal liability’ was given; if it means liability for detention consequent upon breach of the restriction, then this appears wholly at variance with the assurances given by the government, that the section would in no way extend their power to detain (see above). The discussion centred on criminal liability, but the government would of course rely on this section if faced with civil damages claims from persons detained in the same circumstances as Huez and Khadir prior to the coming into force of this section.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Bail
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies in a case where an immigration officer not below the rank of chief immigration officer has sole or shared power to release a person on bail in accordance with—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a provision of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control of entry) (including a provision of that Schedule applied by a provision of that Act or by another enactment), or
(b)section 9A of the Asylum and Immigration Appeals Act 1993 (c 23) (pending appeal from Immigration Appeal Tribunal).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In respect of an application for release on bail which is instituted after the expiry of the period of eight days beginning with the day on which detention commences, the power to release on bail—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)shall be exercisable by the Secretary of State (as well as by any person with whom the immigration officer’s power is shared under the provision referred to in subsection (1)), and
(b)shall not be exercisable by an immigration officer (except where he acts on behalf of the Secretary of State).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In relation to the exercise by the Secretary of State of a power to release a person on bail by virtue of subsection (2), a reference to an immigration officer shall be construed as a reference to the Secretary of State.

(4)The Secretary of State may by order amend or replace subsection (2) so as to make different provision for the circumstances in which the power to release on bail may be exercised by the Secretary of State and not by an immigration officer.
(5)An order under subsection (4)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)may include consequential or transitional provision,
(b)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(c)may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)The following provisions of Part III of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (Bail) shall cease to have effect—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)sections 44 to 52 (routine bail hearings),
(b)section 53(5) (bail under regulations to match bail under Part III), and
(c)section 55 (grants to advisory organisations).

core:comment.core:para: The most significant part of this section is subs (6), which repeals the provisions, never brought into force, providing for routine bail hearings, in Pt 3 of the IAA 1999. All that remains of Pt 3 are the powers contained in sub-s 53(1)–(4), (6) and (7) of the 1999 Act, providing powers to make regulations governing elective bail hearings, and the amendments to para 2 of Sch 3 to the IA 1971 effected by s 54 of the 1999 Act, which would allow those detained pursuant to a recommendation for deportation, or who are subject to a deportation order, to apply for bail. Subsections 53(1) to (4), (6) and (7) and s 54 were brought into force on 10 February 2003 (see Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (Commencement No 12) Order 2003 (SI 2003/2).

The provisions repealed include the general right to be released on bail previously contained in s 46, although regulations under what remains of s 53 could be used to provide for such a right in respect of elective bail hearings.

The rest of this section is concerned with giving the Secretary of State the same powers to grant bail to those detained under the IA 1971, Sch 2, para 16, as those already accorded to a Chief Immigration Officer. Compare the extension of the Secretary of State’s powers to detain under s 62.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Reporting restriction: travel expenses
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may make a payment to a person in respect of travelling expenses which the person has incurred or will incur for the purpose of complying with a reporting restriction.
(2)In subsection (1) “reporting restriction” means a restriction which—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)requires a person to report to the police, an immigration officer or the Secretary of State, and
(b)is imposed under a provision listed in subsection (3).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Those provisions are—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)paragraph 21 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (temporary admission or release from detention),
(b)paragraph 29 of that Schedule (bail), and
(c)paragraph 2 or 5 of Schedule 3 to that Act (pending deportation).

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(u)).
Definitions ‘reporting restriction’: sub-s (2).

Provides a power, although not a duty, to pay travel expenses of asylum-seekers travelling to comply with restrictions ordering them to report to a police or immigration officer. Note that under reg 9(4) of the Asylum Support Regulations 2000 (SI 2000/704) travel expenses cannot be paid as part of asylum support. The government gave provisional indications during debates as to how it expected the provision to operate. They did not anticipate paying expenses when the person was reporting to a place less than three miles from his/her home but exceptions would be made for the elderly, physically infirm and heavily pregnant (Hansard Standing Committee E, 14 May 2002, Cols 259–260, Rosie Winterton MP, Parliamentary Secretary, LCD); and they anticipated paying travel expenses for those in receipt of asylum support from the Home Office National Asylum Support Service (NASS) (Hansard, HL Report, 6 November 2002, Vol 640, No 201, Col 845, Lord Bassam of Brighton).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Induction
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A residence restriction may be imposed on an asylum-seeker or a dependant of an asylum-seeker without regard to his personal circumstances if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)it requires him to reside at a specified location for a period not exceeding 14 days, and
(b)the person imposing the residence restriction believes that a programme of induction will be made available to the asylum-seeker at or near the specified location.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In subsection (1) “residence restriction” means a restriction imposed under—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)paragraph 21 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (temporary admission or release from detention), or
(b)paragraph 2(5) of Schedule 3 to that Act (control pending deportation).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “asylum-seeker” has the meaning given by section 18 of this Act but disregarding section 18(1)(a),

“dependant of an asylum-seeker” means a person who appears to the Secretary of State to be making a claim or application in respect of residence in the United Kingdom by virtue of being a dependant of an asylum-seeker, and
“programme of induction” means education about the nature of the asylum process.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Regulations under subsection (3)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)may make different provision for different circumstances,
(b)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(c)shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)Subsection (6) applies where the Secretary of State arranges for the provision of a programme of induction (whether or not he also provides other facilities to persons attending the programme and whether or not all the persons attending the programme are subject to residence restrictions).
(6)A local authority may arrange for or participate in the provision of the programme or other facilities.
(7)In particular, a local authority may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)incur reasonable expenditure;
(b)provide services outside its area;
(c)provide services jointly with another body;
(d)form a company;
(e)tender for or enter into a contract;
(f)do anything (including anything listed in paragraphs (a) to (e)) for a preparatory purpose.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (8)In this section “local authority” means—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a local authority within the meaning of section 94 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33), and
(b)a Northern Ireland authority within the meaning of section 110 of that Act.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(v)).
Definitions ‘asylum seeker’: sub-s (3), with reference to s 18. ‘Dependant’: subs (3). ‘Local authority’: sub-s (8). ‘Programme of induction’: sub-s (3). ‘Residence restriction’: sub-s (2).

This section may be read as another example of the closer links being forged between the support and control processes. The IAA 1999 was operated so that asylum-seekers who applied for support went first to temporary or emergency accommodation (see s 98 of the IAA 1999) and then into accommodation under the support scheme established by Pt 6 of that Act. The time in emergency accommodation was spent waiting for the decision on the application for support, and was not integrated into the asylum process. Under this section, provision is made for an initial stage, which may involve residing in a particular location, following the application for asylum. Ministers spoke during the debate of ‘induction centres’ from which asylum seekers would go to accommodation centres established under Pt 2 of this Act, or to accommodation provided by the National Asylum Support Service (NASS) under Pt 6 of the IAA 1999, as amended by Pt 3 of this Act; although such centres would not necessarily be residential. There is no requirement however that induction take place immediately after the claim for asylum is made, and a residence restriction for the purposes of induction could be imposed upon people who had made their asylum claim some time before.
Asylum seekers who are not in receipt of support can be made to go through the programme of induction. See s 55(11).
(2) See s 71.

(3) Section 18(1)(a) requires that a person be over 18 to be considered an asylum-seeker. By removing that part of the definition, this section makes it possible for residence restrictions for the purposes of induction to be imposed upon unaccompanied minors seeking asylum. Ministers stated that unaccompanied minors should go through an induction process, but that this should be a separate process from that provided for adults (Hansard, Standing Committee E, 14 May 2002, Col 263, Angela Eagle MP, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Department). The Lord Filkin, Parliamentary Under-Secretary of State for the Home Office wrote to the charity Save the Children on 10 September 2002 stating ‘Unaccompanied Asylum-Seeking Children (‘UASC’) are specifically excluded from induction centres’ but this exclusion does not appear on the face of the statute.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Asylum–seeker: residence, &c restriction
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a person who makes a claim for asylum at a time when he has leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, and
(b)a dependant of a person within paragraph (a).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State or an immigration officer may impose on a person to whom this section applies any restriction which may be imposed under paragraph 21 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control of entry: residence, reporting and occupation restrictions) on a person liable to detention under paragraph 16 of that Schedule.
(3)Where a restriction is imposed on a person under subsection (2)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the restriction shall be treated for all purposes as a restriction imposed under paragraph 21 of that Schedule, and
(b)if the person fails to comply with the restriction he shall be liable to detention under paragraph 16 of that Schedule.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)A restriction imposed on a person under this section shall cease to have effect if he ceases to be an asylum-seeker or the dependant of an asylum-seeker.
(5)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “asylum-seeker” has the same meaning as in section 70,
“claim for asylum” has the same meaning as in section 18, and
“dependant” means a person who appears to the Secretary of State to be making a claim or application in respect of residence in the United Kingdom by virtue of being a dependant of another person.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)Regulations under subsection (5)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)may make different provision for different circumstances,
(b)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(c)shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).
Definitions ‘asylum-seeker’: sub-s (5), by reference to s 70. ‘Claim for asylum’: sub-s (5), by reference to s 18. ‘Dependant’: subs (5).

This section empowers the Secretary of State or an immigration officer to impose residence restrictions on those who have extant leave to enter or remain at the time of making their claim for asylum. It will now be possible to impose the same restrictions on such people as can be imposed on other asylum seekers under para 21 of Sch 2 to the IA 1971. Failure to comply with the conditions will make the person liable to detention, as are other asylum seekers who fail to comply with those conditions.

See s 62 for the increased powers of the Secretary of State (as opposed to immigration officers) to detain, and s 68 for the corresponding increased powers of the Secretary of State to release on bail.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Serious criminal
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies for the purpose of the construction and application of Article 33(2) of the Refugee Convention (exclusion from protection).
(2)A person shall be presumed to have been convicted by a final judgment of a particularly serious crime and to constitute a danger to the community of the United Kingdom if he is—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)convicted in the United Kingdom of an offence, and
(b)sentenced to a period of imprisonment of at least two years.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A person shall be presumed to have been convicted by a final judgment of a particularly serious crime and to constitute a danger to the community of the United Kingdom if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)he is convicted outside the United Kingdom of an offence,
(b)he is sentenced to a period of imprisonment of at least two years, and
(c)he could have been sentenced to a period of imprisonment of at least two years had his conviction been a conviction in the United Kingdom of a similar offence.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)A person shall be presumed to have been convicted by a final judgment of a particularly serious crime and to constitute a danger to the community of the United Kingdom if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)he is convicted of an offence specified by order of the Secretary of State, or
(b)he is convicted outside the United Kingdom of an offence and the Secretary of State certifies that in his opinion the offence is similar to an offence specified by order under paragraph (a).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)An order under subsection (4)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(b)shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)A presumption under subsection (2), (3) or (4) that a person constitutes a danger to the community is rebuttable by that person.
(7)A presumption under subsection (2), (3) or (4) does not apply while an appeal against conviction or sentence—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)is pending, or
(b)could be brought (disregarding the possibility of appeal out of time with leave).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (8)Section 34(1) of the Anti-terrorism, Crime and Security Act 2001 (c 24) (no need to consider gravity of fear or threat of persecution) applies for the purpose of considering whether a presumption mentioned in subsection (6) has been rebutted as it applies for the purpose of considering whether Article 33(2) of the Refugee Convention applies.
(9)Subsection (10) applies where—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a person appeals under section 82. . . of this Act or under section 2 of the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997 (c 68) wholly or partly on the ground [mentioned in section 84(1)(a) or (3)(a) of this Act (breach of the United Kingdom’s obligations under the Refugee Convention), and]
(b)the Secretary of State issues a certificate that presumptions under subsection (2), (3) or (4) apply to the person (subject to rebuttal).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (10)The . . . Tribunal or Commission hearing the appeal—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must begin substantive deliberation on the appeal by considering the certificate, and

(b)if in agreement that presumptions under subsection (2), (3) or (4) apply (having given the appellant an opportunity for rebuttal) must dismiss the appeal in so far as it relies on the ground specified in subsection (9)(a).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(10A)Subsection (10) also applies in relation to the Upper Tribunal when it acts under section 12(2)(b)(ii) of the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007.]
(11)For the purposes of this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)“the Refugee Convention” means the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees done at Geneva on 28th July 1951 and its Protocol, and
(b)a reference to a person who is sentenced to a period of imprisonment of at least two years—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)does not include a reference to a person who receives a suspended sentence (unless at least two years of the sentence are not suspended) [(unless a court subsequently orders that the sentence or any part of it is to take effect)],

[(ia)
does not include a reference to a person who is sentenced to a period of imprisonment of at least two years only by virtue of being sentenced to consecutive sentences which amount in aggregate to more than two years,]

(ii)includes a reference to a person who is sentenced to detention, or ordered or directed to be detained, in an institution other than a prison (including, in particular, a hospital or an institution for young offenders), and
(iii)includes a reference to a person who is sentenced to imprisonment or detention, or ordered or directed to be detained, for an indeterminate period (provided that it may last for two years).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Family
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The following shall be inserted after paragraph 10 of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control of entry: removal)—

Where directions are given in respect of a person under any of paragraphs 8 to 10 above, directions to the same effect may be given under that paragraph in respect of a member of the person’s family.”
(5)In paragraph 16(2) of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control of entry, &c: detention) for the words “8 to 10” there shall be substituted “8 to 10A”.

Repealed by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 1, para 7. Date in force: 20 October 2014: see SI 2014/2771, art 2(d), (e); for transitional provisions and savings see arts 9–11 and SI 2014/2928, art 2.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Exemption from deportation
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Section 7 of the Immigration Act 1971 (existing residents exempt from deportation) shall be amended as follows.
(2)Subsection (1)(a) (which is redundant) shall cease to have effect.
(3)The following shall be substituted for subsection (1)(b)—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: “(b)shall not be liable to deportation under section 3(5) if at the time of the Secretary of State’s decision he had for the last five years been ordinarily resident in the United Kingdom and Islands;”.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Revocation of leave to enter or remain
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may revoke a person’s indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom if the person—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)is liable to deportation, but
(b)cannot be deported for legal reasons.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State may revoke a person’s indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the leave was obtained by deception,
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The Secretary of State may revoke a person’s indefinite leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom if the person, or someone of whom he is a dependant, ceases to be a refugee as a result of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)voluntarily availing himself of the protection of his country of nationality,
(b)voluntarily re-acquiring a lost nationality,
(c)acquiring the nationality of a country other than the United Kingdom and availing himself of its protection, or
(d)voluntarily establishing himself in a country in respect of which he was a refugee.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “indefinite leave” has the meaning given by section 33(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (interpretation),
“liable to deportation” has the meaning given by section 3(5) and (6) of that Act (deportation),
“refugee” has the meaning given by the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees done at Geneva on 28th July 1951 and its Protocol, and
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)A power under subsection (1) or (2) to revoke leave may be exercised—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in respect of leave granted before this section comes into force;
(b)in reliance on anything done before this section comes into force.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)A power under subsection (3) to revoke leave may be exercised—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in respect of leave granted before this section comes into force, but
(b)only in reliance on action taken after this section comes into force.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (2): paras (b), (c) repealed by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 1, para 3(1), (3)(a). Date in force: 20 October 2014: see SI 2014/2771, art 2(d), (e); for transitional provisions and savings see arts 9–11 and SI 2014/2928, art 2. lnb-leg:provision.core:title: No removal while claim for asylum pending
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)While a person''s claim for asylum is pending he may not be—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)removed from the United Kingdom in accordance with a provision of the Immigration Acts, or
(b)required to leave the United Kingdom in accordance with a provision of the Immigration Acts.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)“claim for asylum” means a claim by a person that it would be contrary to the United Kingdom''s obligations under the Refugee Convention to remove him from or require him to leave the United Kingdom, and
(b)a person’s claim is pending until he is given notice of the Secretary of State''s decision on it.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In subsection (2) “the Refugee Convention” means the Convention relating to the Status of Refugees done at Geneva on 28th July 1951 and its Protocol.
(4)Nothing in this section shall prevent any of the following while a claim for asylum is pending—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the giving of a direction for the claimant’s removal from the United Kingdom,
(b)the making of a deportation order in respect of the claimant, or
(c)the taking of any other interim or preparatory action.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)Section 15 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (protection from removal or deportation) shall cease to have effect.

core:comment.core:para: 1 April 2003: see SI 2003/754, art 2(1) Sch 1; for transitional provisons see art 3(2), Sch 2, para 1(2) thereto.
Definitions ‘claim for asylum’: subs (2). ‘Pending’: sub-s (2). ‘Refugee Convention’: sub-s (2).

This section largely re-enacts s 15 of the IAA 1999 (repealed by sub-s (5)), albeit with changes to the drafting. The change of substance is the express provision for the taking of ‘any other interim or preparatory action’ (see sub-s (4)(c)), ie action apart from the giving of removal directions or making of a deportation order, before the claim for asylum has been determined. Examples of such action given during debates included the completion of ‘a routine travel document application’ (Hansard HL Report, 17 July 2002, Vol 637, No 172, Col 1339, Lord Bassam of Brighton). This is a major departure from the rationale stated by Ministers at the time of the passage of the 1999 Act to underlie s 15 of that Act. The Lord Williams of Mostyn for the government said of that section ‘what we want is a sensible opportunity to provide both documents [a decision on the asylum claim and a deportation order] in the same envelope’ (Hansard HL Report Vol 605, No 136, Col 785). See also s 78 of this Act.

(2) Those arguing that their removal would be in breach of the ECHR are not protected by this section. However, the government indicated during debates that s 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998 provided the level of protection necessary in such cases (see Hansard Standing Committee E, 14 May 2002, Col 275, Rosie Winterton MP, Parliamentary Secretary LCD).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: No removal while appeal pending
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)While a person’s appeal under section 82(1) is pending he may not be—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)removed from the United Kingdom in accordance with a provision of the Immigration Acts, or
(b)required to leave the United Kingdom in accordance with a provision of the Immigration Acts.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In this section “pending” has the meaning given by section 104.
(3)Nothing in this section shall prevent any of the following while an appeal is pending—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the giving of a direction for the appellant''s removal from the United Kingdom,
(b)the making of a deportation order in respect of the appellant (subject to section 79), or
(c)the taking of any other interim or preparatory action.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)This section applies only to an appeal brought while the appellant is in the United Kingdom in accordance with section 92.

core:comment.core:para: 1 April 2003: see SI 2003/754, art 2(1), Sch 1; for transitional provisions see art 3(2), Sch 2, para 1(3) thereto.
Definitions ‘pending’: subs (2); s 104.

See note to s 77. Section 15 of the IAA 1999 made no provision for the period between refusal by the Secretary of State and the final determination of any appeal. Paragraph 10 of Sch 4 to the IAA 1999 made provision for a stay on removal directions while an appeal was pending. Provision is made in Sch 9 of this Act for the repeal of Sch 4 of the IAA 1999. This new section means that, subject to s 79 (see note to that section) all the steps that can be taken while an application for asylum is pending before the Secretary of State (see s 77) can also be taken subsequent to the Secretary of State''s refusal and while an appeal is pending, as defined in s 104 (see note thereto). The vulnerability of the person concerned to rapid removal or deportation as soon as the appeal is finally determined is thereby increased.
See para 20 of Sch 7, inserting a new s 2 into the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997, which provides for this section to have effect in relation to appeals to SIAC.
(4) See s 92 which makes provision for some appeals not to have suspensive effect. In such cases, the asylum-seeker would be outside the UK at the time of the appeal.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Restriction on removal of children and their parents etc]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)This section applies in a case where—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a child is to be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom, and
(b)an individual who—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)is a parent of the child or has care of the child, and
(ii)is living in a household in the United Kingdom with the child,
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued2: is also to be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom (a “relevant parent or carer”).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)During the period of 28 days beginning with the day on which the relevant appeal rights are exhausted—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the child may not be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom; and
(b)a relevant parent or carer may not be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom if, as a result, no relevant parent or carer would remain in the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The relevant appeal rights are exhausted at the time when—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)neither the child, nor any relevant parent or carer, could bring an appeal under section 82 (ignoring any possibility of an appeal out of time with permission), and
(b)no appeal brought by the child, or by any relevant parent or carer, is pending within the meaning of section 104.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Nothing in this section prevents any of the following during the period of 28 days mentioned in subsection (2)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the giving of a direction for the removal of a person from the United Kingdom,
(b)the making of a deportation order in respect of a person, or
(c)the taking of any other interim or preparatory action.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “child” means a person who is aged under 18;
references to a person being removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom are to the person being removed or required to leave in accordance with a provision of the Immigration Acts.]

core:comment.core:para: Inserted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 2. Date in force: 28 July 2014: see SI 2014/1820, art 3(a).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Deportation order: appeal
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A deportation order may not be made in respect of a person while an appeal under section 82(1) [that may be brought or continued from within the United Kingdom relating to] the decision to make the order—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)could be brought (ignoring any possibility of an appeal out of time with permission), or
(b)is pending.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In this section “pending” has the meaning given by section 104.
[(3)This section does not apply to a deportation order which states that it is made in accordance with section 32(5) of the UK Borders Act 2007.

(4)But a deportation order made in reliance on subsection (3) does not invalidate leave to enter or remain, in accordance with section 5(1) of the Immigration Act 1971, if and for so long as section 78 above applies.]

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (1): words “that may be brought or continued from within the United Kingdom relating to” in square brackets substituted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 4, paras 30, 32. Date in force: 28 July 2014: see SI 2014/1820, art 3(x), (cc). Sub-ss (3), (4): inserted by the UK Borders Act 2007, s 35(1), (2). Date in force (for certain purposes): 1 August 2008: see SI 2008/1818, art 2(a), Schedule. Date in force (for remaining purposes): to be appointed: see the UK Borders Act 2007, s 59(2).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Removal of asylum-seeker to third country
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The following shall be substituted for section 11 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (removal of asylum claimant under standing arrangements with member States)—

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Removal of asylum claimant under standing arrangement with member States
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)In determining whether a person in relation to whom a certificate has been issued under subsection (2) may be removed from the United Kingdom, a member State is to be regarded as—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a place where a person''s life and liberty is not threatened by reason of his race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group, or political opinion; and
(b)a place from which a person will not be sent to another country otherwise than in accordance with the Refugee Convention.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)Nothing in section 77 of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 prevents a person who has made a claim for asylum (“the claimant”) from being removed from the United Kingdom to a member State if the Secretary of State has certified that—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the member State has accepted that, under standing arrangements, it is the responsible State in relation to the claimant''s claim for asylum; and
(b)in his opinion, the claimant is not a national or citizen of the member State to which he is to be sent.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Subsection (4) applies where a person who is the subject of a certificate under subsection (2)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)has instituted or could institute an appeal under section 82(1) of the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (immigration appeal), and
(b)has made a human rights claim (within the meaning of section 113 of that Act).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)The person may not be removed from the United Kingdom in reliance upon this section unless—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the appeal is finally determined, withdrawn or abandoned (within the meaning of section 104 of that Act) or can no longer be brought (ignoring any possibility of an appeal out of time with permission), or
(b)the Secretary of State has issued a certificate in relation to the human rights claim under section 93(2)(b) of that Act (clearly unfounded claim).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)In this section “standing arrangements” means arrangements in force between two or more member States for determining which State is responsible for considering applications for asylum”.

core:comment.core:para: Repealed by the Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc) Act 2004, ss 33(3)(a), 47, Sch 4: in force 1 October 2004 (except in relation to a person subject to a certificate under the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, ss 11, 12 issued by the Secretary of State before that date): see SI 2004/2523, arts 2, 3, Sch.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Meaning of “the Tribunal”]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [In this Part “the Tribunal” means the First-tier Tribunal.]

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘seven year general qualification’: Courts and Legal Services Act 1990, s 71.
Substituted by SI 2010/21, art 5(1), Sch 1, paras 20, 22. Date in force: 15 February 2010: see SI 2010/21, art 1; for transitional provisions and savings see art 5(4), Sch 4, paras 14–18, 21 thereto.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Right of appeal to the Tribunal]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)A person (“P”) may appeal to the Tribunal where—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the Secretary of State has decided to refuse a protection claim made by P,
(b)the Secretary of State has decided to refuse a human rights claim made by P, or
(c)the Secretary of State has decided to revoke P’s protection status.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)For the purposes of this Part—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a “protection claim” is a claim made by a person (“P”) that removal of P from the United Kingdom—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)would breach the United Kingdom’s obligations under the Refugee Convention, or
(ii)would breach the United Kingdom’s obligations in relation to persons eligible for a grant of humanitarian protection;
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (b)P’s protection claim is refused if the Secretary of State makes one or more of the following decisions—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)that removal of P from the United Kingdom would not breach the United Kingdom’s obligations under the Refugee Convention;
(ii)that removal of P from the United Kingdom would not breach the United Kingdom’s obligations in relation to persons eligible for a grant of humanitarian protection;
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (c)a person has “protection status” if the person has been granted leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom as a refugee or as a person eligible for a grant of humanitarian protection;
(d)“humanitarian protection” is to be construed in accordance with the immigration rules;
(e)“refugee” has the same meaning as in the Refugee Convention.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The right of appeal under subsection (1) is subject to the exceptions and limitations specified in this Part.]

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Grounds of appeal]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)An appeal under section 82(1)(a) (refusal of protection claim) must be brought on one or more of the following grounds—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)that removal of the appellant from the United Kingdom would breach the United Kingdom’s obligations under the Refugee Convention;
(b)that removal of the appellant from the United Kingdom would breach the United Kingdom’s obligations in relation to persons eligible for a grant of humanitarian protection;
(c)that removal of the appellant from the United Kingdom would be unlawful under section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998 (public authority not to act contrary to Human Rights Convention).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)An appeal under section 82(1)(b) (refusal of human rights claim) must be brought on the ground that the decision is unlawful under section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998.
(3)An appeal under section 82(1)(c) (revocation of protection status) must be brought on one or more of the following grounds—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)that the decision to revoke the appellant’s protection status breaches the United Kingdom’s obligations under the Refugee Convention;
(b)that the decision to revoke the appellant’s protection status breaches the United Kingdom’s obligations in relation to persons eligible for a grant of humanitarian protection.]

core:comment.core:para: Substituted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 15(1), (4). Date in force: 20 October 2014: see SI 2014/2771, art 2(b); for transitional provisions and savings see arts 9–11 and SI 2014/2928, art 2.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Matters to be considered
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)An appeal under section 82(1) against a decision shall be treated by [the Tribunal] as including an appeal against any decision in respect of which the appellant has a right of appeal under section 82(1).

(2)If an appellant under section 82(1) makes a statement under section 120, [the Tribunal] shall consider any matter raised in the statement which constitutes a ground of appeal of a kind listed in section [84] against the decision appealed against.
(3)Subsection (2) applies to a statement made under section 120 whether the statement was made before or after the appeal was commenced.

(4)On an appeal under section 82(1). . . against a decision [the Tribunal] may consider . . . any matter which [it] thinks relevant to the substance of the decision, including . . . a matter arising after the date of the decision.
[(5)But the Tribunal must not consider a new matter unless the Secretary of State has given the Tribunal consent to do so.
(6)A matter is a “new matter” if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)it constitutes a ground of appeal of a kind listed in section 84, and
(b)the Secretary of State has not previously considered the matter in the context of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)the decision mentioned in section 82(1), or
(ii)a statement made by the appellant under section 120.]

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Place from which an appeal may be brought or continued]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)This section applies to determine the place from which an appeal under section 82(1) may be brought or continued.
(2)In the case of an appeal under section 82(1)(a) (protection claim appeal), the appeal must be brought from outside the United Kingdom if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the claim to which the appeal relates has been certified under section 94(1) or (7) (claim clearly unfounded or removal to safe third country), or
(b)paragraph 5(3)(a), 10(3), 15(3) or 19(b) of Schedule 3 to the Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc) Act 2004 (removal of asylum seeker to safe third country) applies.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: Otherwise, the appeal must be brought from within the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In the case of an appeal under section 82(1)(b) (human rights claim appeal) where the claim to which the appeal relates was made while the appellant was in the United Kingdom, the appeal must be brought from outside the United Kingdom if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the claim to which the appeal relates has been certified under section 94(1) or (7) (claim clearly unfounded or removal to safe third country) or section 94B (certification of human rights claims made by persons liable to deportation), or
(b)paragraph 5(3)(b) or (4), 10(4), 15(4) or 19(c) of Schedule 3 to the Asylum and Immigration (Treatment of Claimants, etc) Act 2004 (removal of asylum seeker to safe third country) applies.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: Otherwise, the appeal must be brought from within the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In the case of an appeal under section 82(1)(b) (human rights claim appeal) where the claim to which the appeal relates was made while the appellant was outside the United Kingdom, the appeal must be brought from outside the United Kingdom.
(5)In the case of an appeal under section 82(1)(c) (revocation of protection status)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the appeal must be brought from within the United Kingdom if the decision to which the appeal relates was made while the appellant was in the United Kingdom;
(b)the appeal must be brought from outside the United Kingdom if the decision to which the appeal relates was made while the appellant was outside the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)If, after an appeal under section 82(1)(a) or (b) has been brought from within the United Kingdom, the Secretary of State certifies the claim to which the appeal relates under section 94(1) or (7) or section 94B, the appeal must be continued from outside the United Kingdom.

(7)Where a person brings or continues an appeal under section 82(1)(a) (refusal of protection claim) from outside the United Kingdom, for the purposes of considering whether the grounds of appeal are satisfied, the appeal is to be treated as if the person were not outside the United Kingdom.

(8)Where an appellant brings an appeal from within the United Kingdom but leaves the United Kingdom before the appeal is finally determined, the appeal is to be treated as abandoned unless the claim to which the appeal relates has been certified under section 94(1) or (7) or section 94B.]

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Appeal from within United Kingdom: unfounded human rights or [protection] claim
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)The Secretary of State may certify a protection claim or human rights claim as clearly unfounded.]

(3)If the Secretary of State is satisfied that [a] claimant is entitled to reside in a State listed in subsection (4) he shall certify the claim under [subsection (1)] unless satisfied that it is not clearly unfounded.
(4)Those States are—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (i). . . and
[(k)the Republic of Albania,
(n)Jamaica,
(o)Macedonia,
(p)the Republic of Moldova, . . .
(s)Bolivia,
(t)Brazil,
(u)Ecuador,
(w)South Africa, and
(x)Ukraine]
[(y)India]
[(z)Mongolia,
(aa)Ghana (in respect of men),
(bb)Nigeria (in respect of men)]
[(cc)Bosnia-Herzegovina,
(dd)Gambia (in respect of men),
(ee)Kenya (in respect of men),
(ff)Liberia (in respect of men),
(gg)Malawi (in respect of men),
(hh)Mali (in respect of men),
(ii)Mauritius,
(jj)Montenegro,
(kk)Peru,
(ll)Serbia,
(mm)Sierra Leone (in respect of men)]
[(nn)Kosovo,
(oo)South Korea].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)The Secretary of State may by order add a State, or part of a State, to the list in subsection (4) if satisfied that—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)there is in general in that State or part no serious risk of persecution of persons entitled to reside in that State or part, and
(b)removal to that State or part of persons entitled to reside there will not in general contravene the United Kingdom’s obligations under the Human Rights Convention.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(5A)If the Secretary of State is satisfied that the statements in subsection (5) (a) and (b) are true of a State or part of a State in relation to a description of person, an order under subsection (5) may add the State or part to the list in subsection (4) in respect of that description of person.

(5B)Where a State or part of a State is added to the list in subsection (4) in respect of a description of person, subsection (3) shall have effect in relation to a claimant only if the Secretary of State is satisfied that he is within that description (as well as being satisfied that he is entitled to reside in the State or part).
(5C)A description for the purposes of subsection (5A) may refer to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)gender,
(b)language,
(c)race,
(d)religion,
(e)nationality,
(f)membership of a social or other group,
(g)political opinion, or
(h)any other attribute or circumstance that the Secretary of State thinks appropriate.]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(5D)In deciding whether the statements in subsection (5) (a) and (b) are true of a State or part of a State, the Secretary of State—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)shall have regard to all the circumstances of the State or part (including its laws and how they are applied), and
(b)shall have regard to information from any appropriate source (including other member States and international organisations).]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(6)The Secretary of State may by order amend the list in subsection (4) so as to omit a State or part added under subsection (5); and the omission may be—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)general, or
(b)effected so that the State or part remains listed in respect of a description of person.]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(6A)Subsection (3) shall not apply in relation to [a] claimant who—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)is the subject of a certificate under section 2 or 70 of the Extradition Act 2003 (c 41),
(b)is in custody pursuant to arrest under section 5 of that Act,
(c)is the subject of a provisional warrant under section 73 of that Act,
(d)is the subject of an authority to proceed under section 7 of the Extradition Act 1989 (c 33) or an order under paragraph 4(2) of Schedule 1 to that Act, or
(e)is the subject of a provisional warrant under section 8 of that Act or of a warrant under paragraph 5(1)(b) of Schedule 1 to that Act.]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1:
[(6B)
A certificate under subsection (1A) or (2) may not be issued (and subsection (3) shall not apply) in relation to an appeal under section 82(2)(d) or (e) against a decision relating to leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, where the leave was given in circumstances specified for the purposes of this subsection by order of the Secretary of State.]
(7)[The Secretary of State may certify a protection claim or human rights claim made by a person if]—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)it is proposed to remove the person to a country of which he is not a national or citizen, and
(b)there is no reason to believe that the person’s rights under the Human Rights Convention will be breached in that country.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (8)In determining whether a person in relation to whom a certificate has been issued under subsection (7) may be removed from the United Kingdom, the country specified in the certificate is to be regarded as—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a place where a person’s life and liberty is not threatened by reason of his race, religion, nationality, membership of a particular social group, or political opinion, and

(b)a place from which a person will not be sent to another country otherwise than in accordance with the Refugee Convention [or with the United Kingdom’s obligations in relation to persons eligible for a grant of humanitarian protection].

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: European Common List of Safe Countries of Origin]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)The Secretary of State shall by order prescribe a list of States to be known as the “European Common List of Safe Countries of Origin”.
(2)Subsections (3) and (4) apply where a person makes [a protection claim] or a human rights claim (or both) and that person is—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a national of a State which is listed in the European Common List of Safe Countries of Origin, or
(b)a Stateless person who was formerly habitually resident in such a State.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The Secretary of State shall consider the claim or claims mentioned in subsection (2) to be unfounded unless satisfied that there are serious grounds for considering that the State in question is not safe in the particular circumstances of the person mentioned in that subsection.
(4)The Secretary of State shall also certify the claim or claims mentioned in subsection (2) under section [94(1)] unless satisfied that the claim or claims is or are not clearly unfounded.
(5)An order under subsection (1)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)may be made only if the Secretary of State thinks it necessary for the purpose of complying with the United Kingdom’s obligations under [EU] law,
(b)may include transitional, consequential or incidental provision,
(c)shall be made by statutory instrument, and
(d)shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.]

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Appeal from within the United Kingdom: certification of human rights claims made by persons liable to deportation]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)This section applies where a human rights claim has been made by a person (“P”) who is liable to deportation under—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 3(5)(a) of the Immigration Act 1971 (Secretary of State deeming deportation conducive to public good), or
(b)section 3(6) of that Act (court recommending deportation following conviction).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State may certify the claim if the Secretary of State considers that, despite the appeals process not having been begun or not having been exhausted, removal of P to the country or territory to which P is proposed to be removed, pending the outcome of an appeal in relation to P’s claim, would not be unlawful under section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998 (public authority not to act contrary to Human Rights Convention).

(3)The grounds upon which the Secretary of State may certify a claim under subsection (2) include (in particular) that P would not, before the appeals process is exhausted, face a real risk of serious irreversible harm if removed to the country or territory to which P is proposed to be removed.]

core:comment.core:para: Inserted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 17(1), (3). Date in force: 28 July 2014: see SI 2014/1820, art 3(n).

Repealed by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 4, paras 30, 40. Date in force: 20 October 2014: see SI 2014/2771, art 2(d), (e); for transitional provisions and savings see arts 9–11 and SI 2014/2928, art 2.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Earlier right of appeal
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)[A person may not bring an appeal under section 82 against a decision (“the new decision”)] if the Secretary of State or an immigration officer certifies—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)that the person was notified of a right of appeal under that section against another . . . decision (“the old decision”) (whether or not an appeal was brought and whether or not any appeal brought has been determined),
(b)that the claim or application to which the new decision relates relies on a [ground] that could have been raised in an appeal against the old decision, and
(c)that, in the opinion of the Secretary of State or the immigration officer, there is no satisfactory reason for that [ground] not having been raised in an appeal against the old decision.]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(2)A person may not bring an appeal under section 82 if the Secretary of State or an immigration officer certifies—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)that the person has received a notice under section 120(2),
(b)that the appeal relies on a ground that should have been, but has not been, raised in a statement made under section 120(2) or (5), and
(c)that, in the opinion of the Secretary of State or the immigration officer, there is no satisfactory reason for that ground not having been raised in a statement under section 120(2) or (5).]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In subsection (1) “notified” means notified in accordance with regulations under section 105.

(5)[Subsections (1) and (2) apply to prevent] a person’s right of appeal whether or not he has been outside the United Kingdom since an earlier right of appeal arose or since a requirement under section 120 was imposed.

(6)In this section a reference to an appeal under section 82(1) includes a reference to an appeal under section 2 of the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997 (c 68) which is or could be brought by reference to an appeal under section 82(1).
[(7)A certificate under subsection (1) or (2) shall have no effect in relation to an appeal instituted before the certificate is issued.]

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: National security, &c
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)An appeal under section 82(1). . . against a decision in respect of a person may not be brought or continued if the Secretary of State certifies that the decision is or was taken—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)by the Secretary of State wholly or partly on a ground listed in subsection (2), or
(b)in accordance with a direction of the Secretary of State which identifies the person to whom the decision relates and which is given wholly or partly on a ground listed in subsection (2).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The grounds mentioned in subsection (1) are that the person’s exclusion or removal from the United Kingdom is—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in the interests of national security, or
(b)in the interests of the relationship between the United Kingdom and another country.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)An appeal under section 82(1). . . against a decision may not be brought or continued if the Secretary of State certifies that the decision is or was taken wholly or partly in reliance on information which in his opinion should not be made public—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in the interests of national security,
(b)in the interests of the relationship between the United Kingdom and another country, or
(c)otherwise in the public interest.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In subsections (1)(a) and (b) and (3) a reference to the Secretary of State is to the Secretary of State acting in person.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-s (1): words omitted repealed by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 4, paras 30, 42(a). lnb-leg:provision.core:title: National security: deportation]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)This section applies where the Secretary of State certifies that the decision to make a deportation order in respect of a person was taken on the grounds that his removal from the United Kingdom would be in the interests of national security.

[(1A)This section also applies where the Secretary of State certifies, in the case of a person in respect of whom a deportation order has been made which states that it is made in accordance with section 32(5) of the UK Borders Act 2007, that the person’s removal from the United Kingdom would be in the interests of national security.]
(2)Where this section applies—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 79 shall not apply,
(b)the Secretary of State shall be taken to have certified the decision to make the deportation order under section 97, and

[(c)section 2(5) of the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997 (whether appeals brought against decisions certified under section 97 may be brought from within the United Kingdom) does not apply, but see instead the following provisions of this section].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(2A)The person while in the United Kingdom may not bring or continue an appeal under section 2 of the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)against the decision to make the deportation order, or
(b)against any refusal to revoke the deportation order,
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: unless the person has made a human rights claim while in the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2B)Subsection (2A) does not allow the person while in the United Kingdom to bring or continue an appeal if the Secretary of State certifies that removal of the person—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)to the country or territory to which the person is proposed to be removed, and
(b)despite the appeals process not having been begun or not having been exhausted,
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: would not [be unlawful under section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998 (public authority not to act contrary to Human Rights Convention)].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2C)The grounds upon which a certificate may be given under subsection (2B) include (in particular)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)that the person would not, before the appeals process is exhausted, face a real risk of serious irreversible harm if removed to the country or territory to which the person is proposed to be removed;
(b)that the whole or part of any human rights claim made by the person is clearly unfounded.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2F)If a certificate in respect of a person is given under subsection (2B), the person may apply to the Special Immigration Appeals Commission to set aside the certificate.

(2G)If a person makes an application under subsection (2F) then the Commission, in determining whether the certificate should be set aside, must apply the principles that would be applied in judicial review proceedings.
(2H)The Commission’s determination of a review under subsection (2F) is final.

(2J)The Commission may direct that a person who has made and not withdrawn an application under subsection (2F) is not to be removed from the United Kingdom at a time when the review has not been finally determined by the Commission.

(2K)Sections 5 and 6 of the Special Immigration Appeals Commission Act 1997 apply in relation to reviews under subsection (2F) (and to applicants for such reviews) as they apply in relation to appeals under section 2 or 2B of that Act (and to persons bringing such appeals).

(2L)Any exercise of power to make rules under section 5 of that Act in relation to reviews under subsection (2F) is to be with a view to securing that proceedings on such reviews are handled expeditiously.]
(4)The Secretary of State may repeal this section by order.]

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: [Section 97]: appeal in progress
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies where a certificate is issued under section . . . 97 . . . in respect of a pending appeal.
(2)The appeal shall lapse.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Pending appeal
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)An appeal under section 82(1) is pending during the period—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)beginning when it is instituted, and
(b)ending when it is finally determined, withdrawn or abandoned (or when it lapses under section 99).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(2)An appeal under section 82(1) is not finally determined for the purpose of subsection (1)(b) while—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)an application for permission to appeal under section 11 or 13 of the Tribunals, Courts and Enforcement Act 2007 could be made or is awaiting determination,
(b)permission to appeal under either of those sections has been granted and the appeal is awaiting determination, or
(c)an appeal has been remitted under section 12 or 14 of that Act and is awaiting determination.]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4A)An appeal under section 82(1) brought by a person while he is in the United Kingdom shall be treated as abandoned if the appellant is granted leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom (subject to [subsection (4B)]).
(4B)Subsection (4A) shall not apply to an appeal in so far as it is brought on [a ground specified in section 84(1)(a) or (b) or 84(3) (asylum or humanitarian protection)] where the appellant—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (b)gives notice, in accordance with [Tribunal Procedure Rules], that he wishes to pursue the appeal in so far as it is brought on that ground.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Notice of immigration decision
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may make regulations requiring a person to be given written notice where an [appealable] decision is taken in respect of him.
(2)The regulations may, in particular, provide that a notice under subsection (1) of [an appealable decision] must state—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)that there is a right of appeal under [section 82], and
(b)how and when that right may be exercised.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)The regulations may make provision (which may include presumptions) about service.
[(4)In this section “appealable decision” means a decision mentioned in section 82(1).]

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)to give evidence, or
(b)to produce a document.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Forged document: proceedings in private
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies where it is alleged—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)that a document relied on by a party to an appeal under section 82. . . is a forgery, and
(b)that disclosure to that party of a matter relating to the detection of the forgery would be contrary to the public interest.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)[The Tribunal]—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must investigate the allegation in private, and
(b)may proceed in private so far as necessary to prevent disclosure of the matter referred to in subsection (1)(b).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Repeal
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Part IV of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (appeals) shall cease to have effect.
(2)Schedule 6 (which makes transitional provision in connection with the repeal of Part IV of that Act and its replacement by this Part) shall have effect.
(3)Schedule 7 (consequential amendments) shall have effect.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-ss (1), (2): 1 April 2003 (SI 2003/754); for transitional provisions see art 3, Sch 2, para 6(4) thereto. Sub-s (3): Appointment (for certain purposes): 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

Provision is made to repeal the whole of Pt 4 and Sch 2 to 4 of the IAA 1999. But see the somewhat confusing reference to repeal in Sch 9. There provision is made for the repeal of Sch 4 as a whole, but also for repeal of the provisions for manifestly unfounded claims contained in para 9 of the Schedule. There is no corresponding power of partial repeal in this section, but it might be possible to use Sch 9 of this Act to repeal the relevant sub-paragraphs of the 1999 Act before repealing the Schedule as a whole. While Sch 4 of the IAA 1999 remains in force, provision is made to amend it by para 29 of Sch 7 of this Act. See notes to Schs 6 and 7.

The effect of the repeal of Pt 4 of the IAA 1999 and of Sch 4 of that Act is that the accelerated procedure for which provision is made in para 9 of Sch 4 to that Act will be abolished and that cases there will no longer be powers to certify claims on the basis that the appellant did not possess a valid passport etc. The only certification procedures for which provision is made in this Act have to do with removing rights of appeal rather than subjecting appeals to an accelerated procedure. There is no provision in this Act for a truncated appeals procedure—all cases that go to the adjudicator are cases where an application can be made for leave to appeal to the IAT with a right of statutory review under s 101(2).

Repealed by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 4, paras 30, 54. Date in force: 20 October 2014: see SI 2014/2771, art 2(d), (e); for transitional provisions and savings see arts 9–11 and SI 2014/2928, art 2.

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: “(ha)the Special Immigration Appeals Commission,”.

core:comment.core:para: The effect of this section is to provide for the Community Legal Service to fund representation at hearings before SIAC (the Special Immigration Appeals Commission). Prior to the enactment of this section, funding had to be sought on an exceptional basis for each application.
