lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Application of this Part]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)This Part applies where a court or tribunal is required to determine whether a decision made under the Immigration Acts—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)breaches a person’s right to respect for private and family life under Article 8, and
(b)as a result would be unlawful under section 6 of the Human Rights Act 1998.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In considering the public interest question, the court or tribunal must (in particular) have regard—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in all cases, to the considerations listed in section 117B, and
(b)in cases concerning the deportation of foreign criminals, to the considerations listed in section 117C.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In subsection (2), “the public interest question” means the question of whether an interference with a person’s right to respect for private and family life is justified under Article 8(2).]

core:comment.core:para: Inserted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 19. Date in force: 28 July 2014: see SI 2014/1820, art 3(o).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Article 8: public interest considerations applicable in all cases]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)The maintenance of effective immigration controls is in the public interest.

(2)It is in the public interest, and in particular in the interests of the economic well-being of the United Kingdom, that persons who seek to enter or remain in the United Kingdom are able to speak English, because persons who can speak English—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)are less of a burden on taxpayers, and
(b)are better able to integrate into society.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)It is in the public interest, and in particular in the interests of the economic well-being of the United Kingdom, that persons who seek to enter or remain in the United Kingdom are financially independent, because such persons—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)are not a burden on taxpayers, and
(b)are better able to integrate into society.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Little weight should be given to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a private life, or
(b)a relationship formed with a qualifying partner,
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: that is established by a person at a time when the person is in the United Kingdom unlawfully.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)Little weight should be given to a private life established by a person at a time when the person’s immigration status is precarious.
(6)In the case of a person who is not liable to deportation, the public interest does not require the person’s removal where—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the person has a genuine and subsisting parental relationship with a qualifying child, and
(b)it would not be reasonable to expect the child to leave the United Kingdom.]

core:comment.core:para: Inserted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 19. Date in force: 28 July 2014: see SI 2014/1820, art 3(o).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Article 8: additional considerations in cases involving foreign criminals]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)The deportation of foreign criminals is in the public interest.
(2)The more serious the offence committed by a foreign criminal, the greater is the public interest in deportation of the criminal.

(3)In the case of a foreign criminal (“C”) who has not been sentenced to a period of imprisonment of four years or more, the public interest requires C’s deportation unless Exception 1 or Exception 2 applies.
(4)Exception 1 applies where—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)C has been lawfully resident in the United Kingdom for most of C’s life,
(b)C is socially and culturally integrated in the United Kingdom, and
(c)there would be very significant obstacles to C’s integration into the country to which C is proposed to be deported.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)Exception 2 applies where C has a genuine and subsisting relationship with a qualifying partner, or a genuine and subsisting parental relationship with a qualifying child, and the effect of C’s deportation on the partner or child would be unduly harsh.

(6)In the case of a foreign criminal who has been sentenced to a period of imprisonment of at least four years, the public interest requires deportation unless there are very compelling circumstances, over and above those described in Exceptions 1 and 2.

(7)The considerations in subsections (1) to (6) are to be taken into account where a court or tribunal is considering a decision to deport a foreign criminal only to the extent that the reason for the decision was the offence or offences for which the criminal has been convicted.]

core:comment.core:para: Inserted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 19. Date in force: 28 July 2014: see SI 2014/1820, art 3(o).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Interpretation of this Part]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)In this Part—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “Article 8” means Article 8 of the European Convention on Human Rights;
“qualifying child” means a person who is under the age of 18 and who—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (a)is a British citizen, or
(b)has lived in the United Kingdom for a continuous period of seven years or more;
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “qualifying partner” means a partner who—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (a)is a British citizen, or
(b)who is settled in the United Kingdom (within the meaning of the Immigration Act 1971—see section 33(2A) of that Act).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In this Part, “foreign criminal” means a person—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)who is not a British citizen,
(b)who has been convicted in the United Kingdom of an offence, and
(c)who—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)has been sentenced to a period of imprisonment of at least 12 months,
(ii)has been convicted of an offence that has caused serious harm, or
(iii)is a persistent offender.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)For the purposes of subsection (2)(b), a person subject to an order under—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 5 of the Criminal Procedure (Insanity) Act 1964 (insanity etc),
(b)section 57 of the Criminal Procedure (Scotland) Act 1995 (insanity etc), or
(c)Article 50A of the Mental Health (Northern Ireland) Order 1986 (insanity etc),
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: has not been convicted of an offence.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In this Part, references to a person who has been sentenced to a period of imprisonment of a certain length of time—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)do not include a person who has received a suspended sentence (unless a court subsequently orders that the sentence or any part of it (of whatever length) is to take effect);

(b)do not include a person who has been sentenced to a period of imprisonment of that length of time only by virtue of being sentenced to consecutive sentences amounting in aggregate to that length of time;

(c)include a person who is sentenced to detention, or ordered or directed to be detained, in an institution other than a prison (including, in particular, a hospital or an institution for young offenders) for that length of time; and
(d)include a person who is sentenced to imprisonment or detention, or ordered or directed to be detained, for an indeterminate period, provided that it may last for at least that length of time.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)If any question arises for the purposes of this Part as to whether a person is a British citizen, it is for the person asserting that fact to prove it.]

core:comment.core:para: Inserted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 19. Date in force: 28 July 2014: see SI 2014/1820, art 3(o).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Leave pending decision on variation application
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The following shall be substituted for section 3C of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (continuation of leave to enter or remain pending decision on application for variation)—

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Continuation of leave pending variation decision
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a person who has limited leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom applies to the Secretary of State for variation of the leave,
(b)the application for variation is made before the leave expires, and
(c)the leave expires without the application for variation having been decided.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The leave is extended by virtue of this section during any period when—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the application for variation is neither decided nor withdrawn,

(b)an appeal under section 82(1) of the Nationality, Asylum and Immigration Act 2002 could be brought against the decision on the application for variation (ignoring any possibility of an appeal out of time with permission), or
(c)an appeal under that section against that decision is pending (within the meaning of section 104 of that Act).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Leave extended by virtue of this section shall lapse if the applicant leaves the United Kingdom.
(4)A person may not make an application for variation of his leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom while that leave is extended by virtue of this section.
(5)But subsection (4) does not prevent the variation of the application mentioned in subsection (1)(a).

(6)In this section a reference to an application being decided is a reference to notice of the decision being given in accordance with regulations under section 105 of that Act (notice of immigration decision)”.

core:comment.core:para: 1 April 2003 (SI 2003/754); for transitional provisions see art 3(2), Sch 2, para 2(2) thereto (as amended by SI 2003/1040, art 2).
Definitions ‘pending’: s 104.

The new s 3C of the IA 1971 makes few changes from the old. Where a person make an application to vary their leave while they still have extant leave, but the extant leave expires before the variation application is decided the extant leave shall be deemed to continue until the application is decided. A new provision is the express requirement that the person remain in the UK (see s 3C(3)) until the application is decided. The new s 3C makes provision for circumstances in which an application is withdrawn and where there is no appeal against the decision.
In cases of non-suspensive appeals, see ss 94(9) and 115(5) which provide for these appeals to be considered as though the person had not left the UK.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Deemed leave on cancellation of notice
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: In paragraph 6(3) of Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (deemed leave on cancellation of notice of refusal) after “and the immigration officer does not at the same time give him indefinite or limited leave to enter” there shall be inserted “or require him to submit to further examination”.

core:comment.core:para: This section would be better entitled ‘no deemed leave on cancellation of notice’. Prior to amendment by this section, para 6(3) of Sch 2 to the IA 1971 provided that if a notice refusing leave to enter under that section were cancelled, then if at the time of cancellation the person was not given indefinite or limited leave to enter s/he would be deemed to have been given six months leave to enter, no employment permitted. The effect of this section is that the immigration officer can now require the person to submit to further examination. If this is done, no six-month leave is deemed to have been given.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Requirement to state additional grounds for application etc]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(1)Subsection (2) applies to a person (“P”) if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)P has made a protection claim or a human rights claim,
(b)P has made an application to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, or
(c)a decision to deport or remove P has been or may be taken.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The Secretary of State or an immigration officer may serve a notice on P requiring P to provide a statement setting out—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)P’s reasons for wishing to enter or remain in the United Kingdom,
(b)any grounds on which P should be permitted to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, and
(c)any grounds on which P should not be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A statement under subsection (2) need not repeat reasons or grounds set out in—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)P’s protection or human rights claim,
(b)the application mentioned in subsection (1)(b), or
(c)an application to which the decision mentioned in subsection (1)(c) relates.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Subsection (5) applies to a person (“P”) if P has previously been served with a notice under subsection (2) and—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)P requires leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom but does not have it, or
(b)P has leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom only by virtue of section 3C or 3D of the Immigration Act 1971 (continuation of leave pending decision or appeal).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)Where P’s circumstances have changed since the Secretary of State or an immigration officer was last made aware of them (whether in the application or claim mentioned in subsection (1) or in a statement under subsection (2) or this subsection) so that P has—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)additional reasons for wishing to enter or remain in the United Kingdom,
(b)additional grounds on which P should be permitted to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, or
(c)additional grounds on which P should not be removed from or required to leave the United Kingdom,
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: P must, as soon as reasonably practicable, provide a supplementary statement to the Secretary of State or an immigration officer setting out the new circumstances and the additional reasons or grounds.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “human rights claim” and “protection claim” have the same meanings as in Part 5;
references to “grounds” are to grounds on which an appeal under Part 5 may be brought (see section 84).]

core:comment.core:para: Substituted by the Immigration Act 2014, s 73(6), Sch 9, Pt 4, paras 30, 55. Date in force: 20 October 2014: see SI 2014/2771, art 2(d), (e); for transitional provisions and savings see arts 9–11 and SI 2014/2928, art 2.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Compliance with procedure
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The following shall be inserted after section 31A(3) of the Immigration Act 1971 (procedural requirements for application)—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(3A)Regulations under this section may provide that a failure to comply with a specified requirement of the regulations—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)invalidates an application,
(b)does not invalidate an application, or

(c)invalidates an application in specified circumstances (which may be described wholly or partly by reference to action by the applicant, the Secretary of State, an immigration officer or another person)”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

Section 31A of the Immigration Act 1971 was inserted by the IAA 1999. It did not set out the consequences of any failure to comply with procedural requirements for applications for leave to enter or remain. This section makes clear that such non-compliance could invalidate the application, but that the circumstances in which this will be the case will be set out in regulations.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Fee for work permit, &c
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may by regulations require an application for an immigration employment document to be accompanied by a fee prescribed in the regulations.
(2)In subsection (1) “immigration employment document” means—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a work permit, and
(b)any other document which relates to employment and is issued for a purpose of immigration rules or in connection with leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Regulations under subsection (1)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)may make provision which applies generally or only in specified cases or circumstances (or except in specified cases or circumstances), and
(b)may make different provision for different cases or circumstances.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In particular, regulations by virtue of subsection (3)(a) which create an exception may make provision by reference to an arrangement with the Secretary of State under which a payment is made in respect of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a specified number or class of applications, or
(b)a specified period of time.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)Regulations under subsection (1)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(b)shall be subject to annulment in pursuance of a resolution of either House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “immigration rules” has the meaning given by section 33(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (interpretation), and
“work permit” has the meaning given by that section.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

Repealed by the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006, ss 52(7), 61, Sch 2, para 5, Sch 3. Date in force (for certain purposes): 2 April 2007: see SI 2007/1109, arts 4, 5, Schedule; for savings see Schedule thereto. Date in force (for remaining purposes): to be appointed: see the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006, s 62(1).
Definition ‘immigration employment document’: sub-s (2). ‘Immigration rules’: sub-s (6); IA 1971, s 33(1). ‘Work permit’: subs (6); IA 1971, s 33(1).

This section gives the Secretary of State the power to levy a charge on applications (whether successful or not) for immigration employment documents, including work permits. The charging scheme can be set out in detail in regulations which, under sub-s (5), will be subject to the affirmative procedure in parliament.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Advice about work permit, etc
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Section 82 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (immigration advice and services: interpretation) shall be amended as follows.
(2)In the definition of “relevant matters” in subsection (1), after paragraph (b) there shall be inserted—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: “(ba)an application for an immigration employment document;”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)At the end of the section add—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(3)In the definition of “relevant matters” in subsection (1) ‘immigration employment document” means—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a work permit (within the meaning of section 33(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (interpretation)), and
(b)any other document which relates to employment and is issued for a purpose of immigration rules or in connection with leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom”.

core:comment.core:para: 1 April 2004 (SI 2003/754, as amended by SI 2003/1339 and SI 2003/2993).
Definition ‘immigration employment document’: s 122(2). ‘Relevant matters’: sub-s (2); IAA 1999 s 82(1). ‘Work permit’: IA 1971 s 33(1).

This section extends the regulatory powers of the Immigration Services Commissioner, established under Pt 5 of the IAA 1999, to cover applications for work permits. Those who provide advice and services relating to work permit or other employment applications ‘in the course of a business (whether or not for profit)’ (see IAA 1999, s 82(2)(b)), will need to apply for registration with the Commissioner, or for an exemption under the regulatory scheme. See also s 140.

lnb-leg:para1.core:emph: Regulations made by the Secretary of State may authorise him to require a person (a “carrier”) to pay a penalty if the carrier brings a passenger to the United Kingdom and—

lnb-leg:para2.core:emph: the carrier was required by an authority-to-carry scheme to seek authority under the scheme to carry the passenger, and
the carrier did not seek authority before the journey to the United Kingdom commenced or was refused authority under the scheme.

lnb-leg:para1.core:emph: An “authority-to-carry scheme” is a scheme operated by the Secretary of State which requires carriers to seek authority to bring passengers to the United Kingdom.

lnb-leg:para2.core:emph: the class of carrier to which it applies (which may be defined by reference to a method of transport or otherwise), and
the class of passenger to which it applies (which may be defined by reference to nationality, the possession of specified documents or otherwise).

lnb-leg:para1.core:emph: The Secretary of State may operate different authority-to-carry schemes for different purposes.
Where the Secretary of State makes regulations under subsection (1) he must—

lnb-leg:para2.core:emph: identify in the regulations the authority-to-carry scheme to which they refer, and
lay the authority-to-carry scheme before Parliament.

lnb-leg:para1.core:emph: Regulations under subsection (1) may, in particular—

lnb-leg:para2.core:emph: apply or make provision similar to a provision of sections 40 to 43 of and Schedule 1 to the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (charge for passenger without document);
do anything which may be done under a provision of any of those sections;

lnb-leg:para1.core:emph: Regulations by virtue of subsection (6)(a) may, in particular—

lnb-leg:para2.core:emph: apply a provision which confers power to make legislation.

lnb-leg:para1.core:emph: The grant or refusal of authority under an authority-to-carry scheme shall not be taken to determine whether a person is entitled or permitted to enter the United Kingdom.

lnb-leg:para2.core:emph: must be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.

core:listitem.core:para: Repealed by the Counter-Terrorism and Security Act 2015, s 22(10).
Date in force: to be appointed: see the Counter-Terrorism and Security Act 2015, s 52(3)(b).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Carriers’ liability
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: Schedule 8 (which amends Part II of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (carriers’ liability)) shall have effect.

core:comment.core:para: Appointment (for the purpose of enabling the Secretary of State to exercise the power to make subordinate legislation under the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, ss 32(2A), 35(5), (7), (9), (12), (13), 37(5B), (7) and 40A(4), (6)): 14 November 2002: see SI 2002/2811, art 2, Schedule; for transitional provisions see art 4 thereof. Appointment (for the purpose of enabling the Secretary of State to exercise the power under the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, s 32A(1), (3), (4) to lay a draft code of practice before Parliament and bring the code of practice into force): 14 November 2002: see SI 2002/2811, art 2, Schedule; for transitional provisions see art 4 thereof. Appointment (for the purposes of clandestine entrants (within the meaning of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, s 32(1)) who arrive in the United Kingdom concealed in a vehicle or a rail freight wagon): 8 December 2002: see SI 2002/2811, art 2, Schedule; for transitional provisions see art 4 thereof. Appointment (for certain purposes): 8 December 2002: see SI 2002/2811, art 2, Schedule; for transitional provisions see art 4 thereof. Appointment (for the purposes of clandestine entrants (within the meaning of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999, s 32(1)) who pass, or attempt to pass, through immigration control concealed in a vehicle, so far as not already in force for these purposes): 11 May 2012: see SI 2012/1263, art 2(1), (2)(a), (3).

See note to Sch 8, including notes on transitional provision. Sections 32 and 34–37 of the IAA 1999, as amended by this section and Sch 8, came into force on 8 December 2002 (see the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (Commencement No 11) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2815 (C.88)). See also the Carriers Liability (Clandestine Entrants) (Level of Penalty: Code of Practice) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2816) and the Carriers'' Liability Regulations 2002 (SI 2002/2817).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Physical data: compulsory provision
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may by regulations—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require an immigration application to be accompanied by specified [biometric information];
(b)enable an authorised person to require an individual who makes an immigration application to provide [biometric information];
(c)enable an authorised person to require an entrant to provide [biometric information].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In subsection (1) “immigration application” means an application for—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)entry clearance,
(b)leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom, . . .
(c)variation of leave to enter or remain in the United Kingdom[,
(d)a transit visa (within the meaning of section 41 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999), or

(e)a document issued as evidence that a person who is not a national of an EEA state or Switzerland is entitled to enter or remain in the United Kingdom by virtue of an enforceable EU right or of any provision made under section 2(2) of the European Communities Act 1972].
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)Regulations under subsection (1) may not—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)impose a requirement in respect of a person to whom section 141 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (fingerprinting) applies, during the relevant period within the meaning of that section, or
(b)enable a requirement to be imposed in respect of a person to whom that section applies, during the relevant period within the meaning of that section.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Regulations under subsection (1) may, in particular—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require, or enable an authorised person to require, the provision of [biometric] information in a specified form;
(b)require an individual to submit, or enable an authorised person to require an individual to submit, to a specified process by means of which [biometric] information is obtained or recorded;

(c)make provision about the effect of failure to provide [biometric] information or to submit to a process (which may, in particular, include provision for an application to be disregarded or dismissed if a requirement is not satisfied);
(d)confer a function (which may include the exercise of a discretion) on an authorised person;
(e)require an authorised person to have regard to a code (with or without modification);
(f)require an authorised person to have regard to such provisions of a code (with or without modification) as may be specified by direction of the Secretary of State;
[(fa)provide for biometric information to be recorded on any document issued as a result of the application in relation to which the information was provided;]
(h)make provision which applies generally or only in specified cases or circumstances;
(i)make different provision for different cases or circumstances.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)In so far as regulations under subsection (1) require an individual under the age of 16 to submit to a process, the regulations must make provision similar to section 141(3) to (5) and (13) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (fingerprints: children).

(7)In so far as regulations under subsection (1) enable an authorised person to require an individual under the age of 16 to submit to a process, the regulations must make provision similar to section 141(3) to (5), (12) and (13) of that Act (fingerprints: children).
(8)Regulations under subsection (1)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must be made by statutory instrument, and
(b)shall not be made unless a draft of the regulations has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: [(8A)Section 8 of the UK Borders Act 2007 (power to make regulations about use and retention of biometric information) applies to biometric information provided in accordance with regulations under subsection (1) as it applies to biometric information provided in accordance with regulations under section 5(1) of that Act.]
(9)In this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: “authorised person” has the meaning given by section 141(5) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (authority to take fingerprints),
[“biometric information” has the meaning given by section 15 of the UK Borders Act 2007,]
“code” has the meaning given by section 145(6) of that Act (code of practice),
[“document” includes a card or sticker and any other method of recording information (whether in writing or by the use of electronic or other technology or by a combination of methods),]
“entrant” has the meaning given by section 33(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (interpretation),
“entry clearance” has the meaning given by section 33(1) of that Act, . . .

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Physical data: voluntary provision
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may operate a scheme under which an individual may supply, or submit to the obtaining or recording of, [biometric information] to be used (wholly or partly) in connection with entry to the United Kingdom.
(2)In particular, the Secretary of State may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require an authorised person to use [biometric] information supplied under a scheme;
(b)make provision about the collection, use and retention of [biometric] information supplied under a scheme (which may include provision requiring an authorised person to have regard to a code);
(c)charge for participation in a scheme.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In this section the following expressions have the same meaning as in section 126—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)“authorised person”,
[(aa)“biometric information”, and]

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Data collection under Immigration and Asylum Act 1999
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The following shall be added at the end of section 144 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (collection of data about external physical characteristics) (which becomes subsection (1))—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(2)In subsection (1) “external physical characteristics” includes, in particular, features of the iris or any other part of the eye”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The following shall be inserted after section 145(2) of that Act (codes of practice)—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(2A)A person exercising a power under regulations made by virtue of section 144 must have regard to such provisions of a code as may be specified”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).
Definitions ‘external physical characteristics’: sub-s (1) amending IAA 1999, s 144(2); IA 1971, s 33(1).

Section 144 of the IAA 1999 provides a power to collect data on external physical characteristics supplementing the powers in s 141 of that Act to take fingerprints. Subsection (1) confirms, if confirmation be necessary, that the iris of the eye is an external physical characteristic. Subsection (2) echoes s 145 of the 1999 Act. Regulations made under that section have applied a modified version of the Police and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (PACE) Code D and the equivalent provisions for Northern Ireland.

lnb-leg:heading.core:title: Disclosure of information by public authority

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Local authority
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may require a local authority to supply information for the purpose of establishing where a person is if the Secretary of State reasonably suspects that—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the person has committed an offence under section 24(1)(a), (b), (c), (e) or (f), 24A(1) or 26(1)(c) or (d) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (illegal entry, deception, &c), and
(b)the person is or has been resident in the local authority''s area.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)A local authority shall comply with a requirement under this section.
(3)In the application of this section to England and Wales ‘local authority’ means—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a county council,
(b)a county borough council,
(c)a district council,
(d)a London borough council,
(e)the Common Council of the City of London, and
(f)the Council of the Isles of Scilly.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)In the application of this section to Scotland “local authority” means a council constituted under section 2 of the Local Government etc (Scotland) Act 1994 (c 39).
(5)In the application of this section to Northern Ireland—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a reference to a local authority shall be taken as a reference to the Northern Ireland Housing Executive, and
(b)the reference to a local authority''s area shall be taken as a reference to Northern Ireland.

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘local authority’: sub-ss (3) to (5).

Under this section local authorities have a duty to supply information to the Secretary of State. Such information is for a limited purpose: finding the person. Moreover, the requirement to provide information only exists where the person is suspected of a particular offence. The offences listed can be committed only by those who are not British citizens (see IA 1971, s 24(1)). The powers cannot be used to locate those who have failed to report to a medical officer under s 24(1)(d) of the Act, nor for the location of persons specified in orders in council made under s 3(7) of that Act (see s 24(1)(g) of that Act). Where a local authority has entered into a contract with the Secretary of State to provide support to a person, powers (rather than duties) to supply information already exist under s 20 of the IAA 1999.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Police, &c
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: Information may be supplied under section 20 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (supply of information to Secretary of State) for use for the purpose [—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)determining whether an applicant for naturalisation under the British Nationality Act 1981 is of good character;

[(b)determining whether, for the purposes of an application referred to in section 41A of the British Nationality Act 1981, the person for whose registration the application is made s of good character;

(ba)determining whether, for the purposes of an application under section 1 of the Hong Kong (War Wives and Widows) Act 1996, the woman for whose registration the application is made is of good character;

(bb)determining whether, for the purposes of an application under section 1 of the British Nationality (Hong Kong) Act 1997 for the registration of an adult or young person within the meaning of subsection (5A) of that section, the person is of good character;]
(c)determining whether to make an order in respect of a person under section 40 of the British Nationality Act 1981].

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

For amendments to s 20 of the IAA 1999, see s 132. The power to supply information in connection with the ‘good character’ test in naturalisation applications is in addition to the broad powers to supply information to the Secretary of State in immigration cases, as set out in that section. Note that despite its title, this section is not restricted to the police. All those listed in s 20, including those who have contracted with the Secretary of State to provide support under Pt 6 of the IAA 1999, can supply information for these purposes.

Paras (a)–(c) substituted by the UK Borders Act 2007, s 43. Date in force: 31 January 2008: see SI 2008/99, art 2(m). Para (b) further substituted, by subsequent paras (b), (ba), (bb), by the Borders, Citizenship and Immigration Act 2009, s 47(4). Date in force: 12 January 2010: see SI 2009/2731, art 4(f).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Supply of document, etc to Secretary of State
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Section 20 of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (supply of information to Secretary of State) shall be amended as follows.
(2)After subsection (1) insert—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(1A)This section also applies to a document or article which—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)comes into the possession of a person listed in subsection (1) or someone acting on his behalf, or
(b)is discovered by a person listed in subsection (1) or someone acting on his behalf”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In subsection (2) after “information” insert “, document or article”.
(4)After subsection (2) insert—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(2A)The Secretary of State may—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)retain for immigration purposes a document or article supplied to him under subsection (2), and
(b)dispose of a document or article supplied to him under subsection (2) in such manner as he thinks appropriate (and the reference to use in subsection (2) includes a reference to disposal)”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)In subsection (6) after “information” insert “, documents or articles”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).
Definitions ‘immigration purposes’: IAA 1999, s 20.

Amends s 20 of the IAA 1999 to ensure that not only information, but documents and articles, can be supplied to the Secretary of State, and that the Secretary of State may retain and dispose of the documents or articles so supplied.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Medical inspectors
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)This section applies to a person if an immigration officer acting under Schedule 2 to the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (control on entry, &c) has brought the person to the attention of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a medical inspector appointed under paragraph 1(2) of that Schedule, or
(b)a person working under the direction of a medical inspector appointed under that paragraph.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)A medical inspector may disclose to a health service body—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the name of a person to whom this section applies,
(b)his place of residence in the United Kingdom,
(c)his age,
(d)the language which he speaks,
(e)the nature of any disease with which the inspector thinks the person may be infected,
(f)relevant details of the person''s medical history,
(g)the grounds for an opinion mentioned in paragraph (e) (including the result of any test or examination which has been carried out), and
(h)the inspector''s opinion about action which the health service body should take.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A disclosure may be made under subsection (2) only if the medical inspector thinks it necessary for the purpose of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)preventative medicine,
(b)medical diagnosis,
(c)the provision of care or treatment, or
(d)the management of health care services.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)For the purposes of this section ‘health service body’ in relation to a person means a body which carries out functions in an area which includes his place of residence and which is—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in relation to England—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: [(ai)the Secretary of State,]
(i)a Primary Care Trust established under section 16A of the National Health Service Act 1977 (c 49),
(ii)a National Health Service Trust established under [section 25 of the National Health Service Act 2006 or section 18 of the National Health Service (Wales) Act 2006],
[(iia)an NHS foundation trust,]
(iii)a Strategic Health Authority established under [section 13 of the National Health Service Act 2006], [or]
(iv)a Special Health Authority established under [section 28 of that Act, or section 22 of the National Health Service (Wales) Act 2006], …
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (b)in relation to Wales—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: [(i)a Local Health Board established under section 11 of the National Health Service (Wales) Act 2006,]] [or]
(ii)a National Health Service Trust established under [section 25 of the National Health Service Act 2006 or section 18 of the National Health Service (Wales) Act 2006], …
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (c)in relation to Scotland—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: [(ai)the Secretary of State,]
(i)a Health Board, Special Health Board or National Health Service Trust established under section 2 or 12A of the National Health Service (Scotland) Act 1978 (c 29), . . .
(ii)the Common Services Agency for the Scottish Health Service established under section 10 of that Act, or
[(iia)Healthcare Improvement Scotland established under section 10A of the 1978 Act,]
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (d)in relation to Northern Ireland—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)a Health and Social Services Board established under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1972 (SI 1972/1265 (NI 14)),
(ii)a Health and Social Services trust established under the Health and Personal Social Services (Northern Ireland) Order 1991 (SI 1991/194 (NI 1)), …
(iii)the Department of Health, Social Services and Public Safety, [...

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

See paras 1, 2 and 7 of Sch 2 to the IA 1971 for powers of medical inspectors to examine passengers on or after entry. This section allows port medical inspectors to disclose information to local NHS bodies about passengers referred to them by immigration officers. The purposes for which information may be disclosed all relate to health. Within that sector they are broad; information can be disclosed for the purpose of ‘preventative medicine’ (sub-s (3)(a)) and ‘the management of health care services’ (sub-s (3)(d)). However, there are no powers for medical inspectors to disclose information other than for health purposes.

lnb-leg:heading.core:title: Disclosure of information by private person

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Employer
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may require an employer to supply information about an employee whom the Secretary of State reasonably suspects of having committed an offence under—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 24(1)(a), (b), (c), (e) or (f), 24A(1) or 26(1)(c) or (d) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (illegal entry, deception, &c),
(b)section 105(1)(a), (b) or (c) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (support for asylum-seeker: fraud), or
(c)section 106(1)(a), (b) or (c) of that Act (support for asylum-seeker: fraud).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The power under subsection (1) may be exercised to require information about an employee only if the information—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)is required for the purpose of establishing where the employee is, or
(b)relates to the employee’s earnings or to the history of his employment.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In this section a reference to an employer or employee—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)includes a reference to a former employer or employee, and
(b)shall be construed in accordance with section 8(8) of the Asylum and Immigration Act 1996 (c 49) (restrictions on employment).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Where—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a business (the “employment agency”) arranges for one person (the ‘worker’) to provide services to another (the “client”), and
(b)the worker is not employed by the employment agency or the client,
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para-continued1: this section shall apply as if the employment agency were the worker''s employer while he provides services to the client.

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘client’: sub-s (4). ‘Employee’: subs (3), by reference to Asylum and Immigration Act 1996, s 8(8). ‘Employer’: subs (3), by reference to Asylum and Immigration Act 1996, s 8(8). ‘Worker’: sub-s (4).

Imposes duties on employers and former employers to disclose information to the Secretary of State in order to find a person, or to obtain information about his/her earnings and employment history, where that person is suspected of having committed an offence, including offences in relation to asylum support. Employment agencies are within the scope of the provision, even where the worker is self-employed. See ss 136–139.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Financial institution
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may require a financial institution to supply information about a person if the Secretary of State reasonably suspects that—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the person has committed an offence under section 105(1)(a), (b) or (c) or 106(1)(a), (b) or (c) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (c 33) (support for asylum-seeker: fraud),
(b)the information is relevant to the offence, and
(c)the institution has the information.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In this section “financial institution” means—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a person who has permission under [Part 4A] of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (c 8) to accept deposits, and
(b)a building society (within the meaning given by the Building Societies Act 1986 (c 53)).

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘building society’: Building Societies Act 1986. ‘Financial institution’: sub-s (2).

The obligation imposed upon financial institutions to provide information to the Secretary of State relates only to offences in connection with support; those contained in the ‘Offences’ section of Pt 6 of the IAA 1999. Banks and building societies can be required to provide information under this section. See ss 136 to 139.

Sub-s (2): in para (a) words “Part 4A” in square brackets substituted by the Financial Services Act 2012, s 114(1), Sch 18, Pt 2, para 96. Date in force: 1 April 2013: see SI 2013/423, art 3, Schedule.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Notice
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A requirement to provide information under section 134 or 135 must be imposed by notice in writing specifying—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the information,
(b)the manner in which it is to be provided, and
(c)the period of time within which it is to be provided.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)A period of time specified in a notice under subsection (1)(c)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must begin with the date of receipt of the notice, and
(b)must not be less than ten working days.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A person on whom a notice is served under subsection (1) must provide the Secretary of State with the information specified in the notice.
(4)Information provided under subsection (3) must be provided—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)in the manner specified under subsection (1)(b), and
(b)within the time specified under subsection (1)(c).
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)In this section “working day” means a day which is not—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)Saturday,
(b)Sunday,
(c)Christmas Day,
(d)Good Friday, or
(e)a day which is a bank holiday under the Banking and Financial Dealings Act 1971 (c 80) in any part of the United Kingdom.

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘working day’: sub-s (5).

(3) The Explanatory Notes to the Bill that became this Act (HL Bill 89–EN 13 June 2002) state ‘271. [...] Within the time limit, the person on whom the notice is served must provide the information or make a declaration to say that he does not have the information’. However, the Explanatory Notes to the Act simply state, at para 338, ‘within that time limit, the person on whom the notice is served must provide the information’.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Disclosure of information: offences
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A person commits an offence if without reasonable excuse he fails to comply with section 136(3).
(2)A person who is guilty of an offence under subsection (1) shall be liable on summary conviction to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months,
(b)a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or
(c)both.

core:comment.core:para: It is an offence for employers or financial institutions not to supply the information requested, in the form and within the time specified, but see note to s 136(3). See notes to ss 138 and 139.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Offence by body
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Subsection (2) applies where an offence under section 137 is committed by a body corporate and it is proved that the offence—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)was committed with the consent or connivance of an officer of the body, or
(b)was attributable to neglect on the part of an officer of the body.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The officer, as well as the body, shall be guilty of the offence.
(3)In this section a reference to an officer of a body corporate includes a reference to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a director, manager or secretary,
(b)a person purporting to act as a director, manager or secretary, and
(c)if the affairs of the body are managed by its members, a member.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)Where an offence under section 137 is committed by a partnership (other than a limited partnership), each partner shall be guilty of the offence.
(5)Subsection (1) shall have effect in relation to a limited partnership as if—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a reference to a body corporate were a reference to a limited partnership, and
(b)a reference to an officer of the body were a reference to a partner.

core:comment.core:para: Employers and financial institutions can be guilty of an offence under s 138.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Privilege against self-incrimination
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Information provided by a person pursuant to a requirement under section 134 or 135 shall not be admissible in evidence in criminal proceedings against that person.
(2)This section shall not apply to proceedings for an offence under section 137.

core:comment.core:para: (2) The section is most likely to be relied upon by employers, who are revealing in the s 136(3) notice that they have employed a person illegally. This section does not protect them from prosecution, nor from the notice being used as the starting point for a criminal investigation, but would prevent information provided in the notice from being used as evidence.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Immigration Services Commissioner
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)(Paragraph (1A) inserted after paragraph 7(1) of Sch 5 to the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 by this subsection).
(2)(Paragraph 3A of Sch 6 to the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 inserted by this subsection).
(3)(Section 87(3)(ea) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 inserted by this subsection).

core:comment.core:para: 8 January 2003 (SI 2002/2811). See note on transitional provision below.
Definitions ‘the Commissioner’: IAA 1999, s 82(1). ‘Immigration advice’: IAA 1999, s 82(1) and (2). ‘Immigration services’: IAA 1999, s 82(1) and (2). ‘Registered person’: IAA 1999, s 82(1).

See also s 123, extending the Commissioner''s powers. This section effects two different changes to the Commissioner''s powers, as detailed below. See the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (Part V Exemption: Relevant Employers) Order 2002 (SI 2002/3025). This replaces SI 2002/9 which expired on 31 December 2002 and continues, until 31 December 2003, the exemption for ‘relevant employers’, those providing advice or services to their own employees or prospective employees and their immediate family where the employee is the subject of an application for a work permit, has been granted such a permit or does not require one. The protection afforded by the order will continue to protect ‘relevant employers’ despite the amendments effected by this section.

Transitional provision See The Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act (Commencement No 1 Order) 2002 (SI 2002/2811), para 5, which provides that the amendment to the IAA 1999 effected by subs (1) shall not apply in respect of an investigation begun by the Commissioner under para 5 (5) of Sch 5 to the 1999 Act before the commencement of s 140(1).

(1) The existing para 7 of Sch 5 to the IAA 1999 gives the Commissioner to power to enter premises when investigating a complaint made by a third party. The amendments effected by this subsection give the Commissioner the same powers of entry in cases where he is investigating pursuant to his own suspicions.

(2) and (3) New para 3A, inserted into Sch 6 of the IAA 1999 by this section, gives the Commissioner power to vary a person''s registration other than at the time of dealing with an application for continued registration under para 3 of that Schedule. Paragraph 2(2) of the Schedule provides for registration to be varied so that advice may only be given on particular issues, to particular persons or in particular circumstances. Sub paragraph (3) allows a person to appeal a decision to vary registration to the Immigration Services Tribunal.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: EEA ports: juxtaposed controls
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may by order make provision for the purpose of giving effect to an international agreement which concerns immigration control at an EEA port (whether or not it also concerns other aspects of frontier control at the port).
(2)An order under this section may make any provision which appears to the Secretary of State—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)likely to facilitate implementation of the international agreement (including those aspects of the agreement which relate to frontier control other than immigration control), or
(b)appropriate as a consequence of provision made for the purpose of facilitating implementation of the agreement.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)In particular, an order under this section may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)provide for a law of England and Wales to have effect, with or without modification, in relation to a person in a specified area or anything done in a specified area;
(b)provide for a law of England and Wales not to have effect in relation to a person in a specified area or anything done in a specified area;
(c)provide for a law of England and Wales to be modified in its effect in relation to a person in a specified area or anything done in a specified area;
(d)disapply or modify an enactment in relation to a person who has undergone a process in a specified area;
(e)disapply or modify an enactment otherwise than under paragraph (b), (c) or (d);
(f)make provision conferring a function (which may include—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)provision conferring a discretionary function;
(ii)provision conferring a function on a servant or agent of the government of a State other than the United Kingdom);
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (g)create or extend the application of an offence;
(h)impose or permit the imposition of a penalty;
(i)require the payment of, or enable a person to require the payment of, a charge or fee;
(j)make provision about enforcement (which may include—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para3: (i)provision conferring a power of arrest, detention or removal from or to any place;
(ii)provision for the purpose of enforcing the law of a State other than the United Kingdom);
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (k)confer jurisdiction on a court or tribunal;
(l)confer immunity or provide for indemnity;
(m)make provision about compensation;

(n)impose a requirement, or enable a requirement to be imposed, for a person to co-operate with or to provide facilities for the use of another person who is performing a function under the order or under the international agreement (which may include a requirement to provide facilities without charge);
(o)make provision about the disclosure of information.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)An order under this section may—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)make provision which applies generally or only in specified circumstances;
(b)make different provision for different circumstances;
(c)amend an enactment.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (5)An order under this section—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)must be made by statutory instrument,
(b)may not be made unless the Secretary of State has consulted with such persons as appear to him to be appropriate, and
(c)may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (6)In this section—

lnb-leg:definition.lnb-leg:para2: “EEA port” means a port in an EEA State from which passengers are commonly carried by sea to or from the United Kingdom,
“EEA State” means a State which is a contracting party to the Agreement on the European Economic Area signed at Oporto on 2nd May 1992 (as it has effect from time to time),
“frontier control” means the enforcement of law which relates to, or in so far as it relates to, the movement of persons or goods into or out of the United Kingdom or another State,
“immigration control” means arrangements made in connection with the movement of persons into or out of the United Kingdom or another State,
“international agreement” means an agreement made between Her Majesty''s Government and the government of another State, and
“specified area” means an area (whether of the United Kingdom or of another State) specified in an international agreement.

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘EEA Port’: sub-s (6). ‘EEA State’ : subs (6). ‘Frontier control’: sub-s (6). ‘Immigration control’: sub-s (6). ‘International agreement’: sub-s (6). ‘Specified area’: sub-s (6).

This section would allow the Secretary of State to provide by order, subject to the affirmative procedure in parliament (see sub-s (5)) for UK immigration and other controls to operate at EEA ports outside the UK. The order must be made to give effect to an international agreement which ‘concerns’ immigration control (see sub-s (1)), but neither the agreement nor the provisions of the order need be related to immigration control. The section appears to envisage that the person at the overseas control could be subject to UK law, but provides for that law to be disapplied (see sub-ss (3)(a) to (e)). The Explanatory Notes to the Acts state, at para 346, that an order made under sub-s (3) ‘may specify that particular laws of England and Wales have effect (with or without modification) in that part of the EEA where immigration and other frontier controls are being carried out by UK officials. An order may also modify or even disapply UK legislation in order to allow officers form other countries to carry out their functions on UK territory’.

The powers are broad and general. They include (see sub-s (3)(j)) powers of detention and removal. See s 80, inserting a new s 11 into the IAA 1999. ‘Standing arrangements’ under the new s 11, which can include bilateral agreements between member States, could be used to pass those stopped at the controls envisaged by this section to the authorities of the State in which the controls were based. Thus for example, a person stopped at these controls could be identified as a person whose asylum claim should be made in a third country, for example the country in which the control was based, and the person could be handed over to the authorities of that country under a bilateral agreement.
Repealed by the UK Borders Act 2007, ss 54(d), 58, Schedule. Date in force: 1 April 2008: see SI 2008/309, art 4(e), (h).
Definitions ‘Advisory Panel on Country Information’: subs (1). ‘Country information’: sub-s (2).

Very broad and general provision is made in this section for the Panel. The Country Information and Policy Unit (CIPU) of the Home Office prepares reports on the situations in a number of countries, together with occasional supplementary material. These are used primarily in asylum cases, or for determining where it is appropriate to grant Exceptional Leave to Remain, and are often put in evidence before the Immigration Appellate Authorities. The reports are available on the Home Office website www.homeoffice.gov.uk

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Assisting unlawful immigration, etc
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 25, 25A, 25B and 25C to the Immigration Act 1971 is substituted by this section.)

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

Definitions ‘aircraft’: IA 1971, s 33(1). ‘Asylum-seeker’: sub-s (2). ‘British overseas territories citizen’: British Overseas Territories Act 2002 ss 1 and 2; BNA 1981, s 50(1) and Sch 6 as amended by that Act; Interpretation Act 1978, Sch 1. ‘British Overseas citizen’: BNA 1981, s 50(1). ‘British National (Overseas)’: BNA 1951, s 50(1). ‘British protected person’: BNA 1951, s 50(1). ‘British subject’: BNA 1981, s 51 and see BNA 1981 Pt 4. ‘Human Rights Convention’: subs (2)(b); IAA 1999, s 167(1). ‘Immigration law’: subs (2). ‘Refugee Convention’: subs (2)(a); IAA 1999, s 167(1). ‘Ship’: IA 1971, s 33(1).

Section 25 of the IA 1971, is replaced by new ss 25, 25A, 25B and 25C. The new s 25 broadens the ambit of the offence of assisting unlawful immigration. Unlawful immigration to all EU member States now falls within the ambit of the section, whereas the original s 25 dealt with immigration into the UK only. The maximum term of imprisonment on indictment is increased from 10 to 14 years.
The separate offence of ‘harbouring’ previously contained in s 25(2) is now subsumed into the main s 25 offence.

The extension of the offence to British Nationals (Overseas) by new s 25(5)(c) is new. This form of British nationality was created by the Hong Kong Act 1995. Until 1997, British Nationals (Overseas) were also British Dependant Territories Citizens and as such could be prosecuted for assistance given outside the UK. In 1997 this status as British Dependant Territories Citizens was lost, and with it went the power to prosecute. This section restores the liability to prosecution.

The laws of other EU states are matters of fact before the UK court. Under new s 25(3) the government of an EU state may issue a document attesting to their laws. The document is to be regarded as conclusive. Ministers stated during the passage of the Act ‘No judgment would be made about the individual, because the certificate would simply state what is an offence in that country. It would be for the court to decide whether the person committed that offence’ (Hansard Standing Committee E, 16 May 2002, col 336, Rosie Winterton MP, Parliamentary Secretary, Lord Chancellor''s Department).
New s 25A replaces the offence previously contained in the old s 25(1)(b).
New s 25B creates the new offence of assisting the entry of a European citizen to the UK in breach of a deportation or exclusion order.

The powers contained in s 25C were previously found in the old s 25(6), but the cases in which they can be used extend to all the offences in new ss 25 to 25C, and also to the offence of traffic in prostitution under s 145.

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(1A)A reference to being an owner of a vehicle, ship or aircraft includes a reference to being any of a number of persons who jointly own it”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

See note to s 143. These provisions make consequential amendments taking account of the substitution of the old s 25 of the IA 1971 by four new subsections, including giving immigration officers the ancillary powers they previously held in relation to the old s 25 offences, in relation to all the new offences: the power of arrest without warrant and powers of entry and search, both with and without warrants.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Employment
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Section 8 of the Asylum and Immigration Act 1996 (c 49) (employment: offence) shall be amended as follows.
(2)For subsection (2) (defence) substitute—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(2)It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under this section to prove that before the employment began any relevant requirement of an order of the Secretary of State under subsection (2A) was complied with.
(2A)An order under this subsection may—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)require the production to an employer of a document of a specified description;
(b)require the production to an employer of one document of each of a number of specified descriptions;
(c)require an employer to take specified steps to retain, copy or record the content of a document produced to him in accordance with the order;
(d)make provision which applies generally or only in specified circumstances;
(e)make different provision for different circumstances”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)After subsection (6) insert—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(6A)Where an offence under this section is committed by a partnership (other than a limited partnership) each partner shall be guilty of the offence and shall be liable to be proceeded against and punished accordingly.
(6B)Subsection (5) shall have effect in relation to a limited partnership as if—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a reference to a body corporate were a reference to a limited partnership, and

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (4)At the end of the section add—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(9)Section 28(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (extended time limit for prosecution) shall apply in relation to an offence under this section.
(10)An offence under this section shall be treated as—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)a relevant offence for the purpose of sections 28B and 28D of that Act (search, entry and arrest), and
(b)an offence under Part III of that Act (criminal proceedings) for the purposes of sections 28E, 28G and 28H (search after arrest)”.

core:comment.core:para: Sub-ss (1), (3), (4): 1 April 2003 (SI 2003/754). Sub-s (2): 1 April 2003 (for the purpose of enabling subordinate legislation to be made) (SI 2003/754).

Definitions ‘employee’: Asylum and Immigration Act 1996, s 8(1). ‘Employer’: Asylum and Immigration Act 1996, s 8(1). ‘Person subject to immigration control’: Asylum and Immigration Act 1996, s 13(2).

The existing statutory defence provided in s 8(2) of the AIA 1996is amended so that the Secretary of State can by order require an employer to have sight of, and retain records of, more than one document. New sub-ss 8(2A)(d) and (e) provide some scope for imposing further obligations on employers.
(4) Provides new powers of entry, search and arrest in connection with an offence under s 8 of the 1996 Act.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Registration card
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 26A of Immigration Act 1971 inserted by this section).

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

Definitions ‘claim for asylum’: s 18 (IA 1971, s 26A(2) inserted by this section). ‘False registration card’: IA 1971, s 26(4) inserted by this section. ‘Registration card’: IA 1971, s 26(4) inserted by this section.

Although this section creates a statutory definition of a registration card, it does so in order to make provision for forgery and fraud offences in connection with such a card, the card having been instituted without the need for specific statutory provision. The statutory definition can be amended (see new s 26A(7)), but amending orders are subject to the affirmative procedure in parliament (new s 26(8)). See note to s 150.
(2) A claim for asylum under this definition includes a claim relying on Article 3 of the ECHR.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Immigration stamp
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 26B of Immigration Act 1971 inserted by this section).

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

Definitions ‘immigration function’: IA 1971, s 26B(3)(c) inserted by this section. ‘Immigration stamp’: IA 1971, s 26B(3)(a) inserted by this section. ‘Replica immigration stamp’: s 26B(3)(b) of the IA 1971, as inserted by this section.
The section, creating a new criminal offence, is concerned with the device used to endorse documents, not with the impressions made by use of such a device. See note to s 150.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Sections 148 and 149: consequential amendments
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The following shall be inserted after section 28A(9) of the Immigration Act 1971 (arrest without warrant)—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(9A)A constable or immigration officer may arrest without warrant a person—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)who has committed an offence under section 26A or 26B; or
(b)whom he has reasonable grounds for suspecting has committed an offence under section 26A or 26B”.

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)In section 28B(5) of that Act (search and arrest by warrant) after “, 24A” there shall be inserted “, 26A or 26B.”.
(3)In section 28D(4) of that Act (search of premises) after “, 25B” there shall be inserted “, 26A or 26B”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).
The amendments make provision for ancillary powers in connection with the new offences set out in ss 148 and 149, including powers to arrest without warrant, and powers of entry and search.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: False information
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: In section 26(3) of the Immigration Act 1971 (general offences: “relevant enactment”)—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)the word “or” after paragraph (c) shall cease to have effect, and
(b)after paragraph (d) there shall be inserted—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: “; or
(e)the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (apart from Part 5)”.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 2003/1).

The amendment effected by this section ensures that the making of false returns, statements or representations to a person lawfully acting in the execution of this Act is made a criminal offence. Part 5 (appeals) is not included.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Arrest by immigration officer
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 28AA of Immigration Act 1971 inserted by this section).

core:comment.core:para: New s 28AA(1)(a) provides a power of arrest in connection with failure to comply with a requirement to report to, attend or submit to a medical examination. Section 28B of the Immigration Act 1971 provides a power to enter premises, with a warrant, search for and arrest a person for the s 24(1)(d) offence. This new subsection complements that power with a free-standing power of arrest. Under new s 28AA(1)(b), for the first time, the employment offence under s 8 of the Asylum and Immigration Act 1996 carries a specific power of arrest. Prior to the enactment of this section, it was necessary to rely on the general powers of arrest contained in the PACE 1984. These did not extend to immigration officers. Immigration officers are given their own power of arrest, with warrant.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Power of entry
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 28CA of the Immigration Act 1971 inserted by this subsection).
(2)The following shall be substituted for section 146(2) of the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (use of force)—

lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para1: “(2)A person exercising a power under any of the following may if necessary use reasonable force—
lnb-leg:amending-text.lnb-leg:para2: (a)section 28CA, 28FA or 28FB of the 1971 Act (business premises: entry to arrest or search),
(b)section 141 or 142 of this Act, and
(c)regulations under section 144 of this Act”.

core:comment.core:para: Definitions ‘business premises’: IA 1971, s 28L(2) amended by s 155 of this Act. ‘Detainee custody officer’: subs (7); IAA 1999, s 154. ‘Employee records’: IA 1971, s 28L(3) amended by s 155 of this Act. ‘Premises’: IA 1971, s 28L. ‘Search’: sub-s (7).

Gives a constable or an immigration officer power to enter and search business premises, without a warrant, to arrest a person whom they have reasonable grounds for believing is on the premises, for an offence of illegal entry, deception or where the person is liable to detention under para 16 of Sch 2 to the IA 1971. See also ss 154 and 155 and in particular s 28L(4) of the IA 1971 as amended by s 155 of this Act.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Power to search for evidence
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (Section 28FA and 28FB of theImmigration Act 1971 inserted by this section).

core:comment.core:para: 8 January 2003 (SI 2002/2811), see note on transitional provision below.

Definitions ‘business premises’: IA 1971, s 28L(2) amended by s 155 of this Act. ‘Employee records’: IA 1971, s 28L(3) amended by s 155 of this Act. ‘Immigration employment offence’: IA 1971, s 28FA(7) inserted by this section. ‘Items subject to legal privilege’: IA 1971, s 28L. ‘Premises’: IA 1971, s 28L.

The powers of entry and search without warrant in new s 28FA relate specifically to employee or personnel records. New sub-s 28FA(1)(c) and (d) mean that no arrest need have been made for the powers in this new section to be triggered.

New s 28FA(2) requires that the arrest under s 24(1) or 24A(1) of the IA 1971 has been made on the business premises, or that the person liable to arrest is on the premises for the power to be triggered. This is not a freestanding power to search business premises.

The trigger for the search is the reasonable belief that an offence under s 8 of the Asylum and Immigration Act 1996 has been committed in relation to the person arrested or liable to arrest (sub-s (2)). However, the power of seizure of documents under sub-s (3) extends to documents that may assist in prove a fraud offence in relation to asylum support. Moreover, nothing in subs (3), with its reference to ‘an’ offence, prevents the seizure and retention of documents relating to offences other than offences by the person whose arrest or liability to arrest triggered the search.

New s 28FB is a power of search of business premises with a warrant where an immigration officer convinces a justice of the peace that there are reasonable grounds for believing that an employer has failed to comply with s 134 and it is not practicable to obtain employee records in any other way. The records must contain, or lead to the obtaining of, the information required by s 134. There is no requirement for any prior arrest under this section. Subsection (4) imports a power to read the reference to a justice of the peace as a reference to a sheriff where appropriate. Once again, having gained entry, the power of search can be used for wider purposes, namely to obtain evidence of fraud of the asylum support system (see new subs (5)(b)).

Transitional provision See The Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act (Commencement No 1 Order) 2002 (SI 2002/2811), para 6 which provides that until s 134 comes into force the new s 28FB inserted by this section shall take effect as if s 28FB were not in force.
See also ss 153 and 155.
