Sub-section 28L(4), s 28CA is inserted into the IA 1971 by s 153 of this Act, the nomenclature in question being that of ranks within the civil service.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Time limit on prosecution
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)In section 28(1) of the Immigration Act 1971 (c 77) (extended time limit for prosecution) the words “, 24A, 25” shall cease to have effect.
(2)Section 24A(4) of that Act (deception: application of extended time limit) shall cease to have effect.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 1/2003).

Proceedings for a summary offence must generally be brought within six months of commission of the offence. Section of the IA 1971 provides for an extended time limit: up to three years from the date of commission of the offence, provided that proceedings are brought within two months of the date certified as the date on which there was evidence sufficient to bring proceedings. There is no time limit on indictable offences. Since the offences in both ss 24A and 25 (replaced under s 143 of this Act by new ss 25 to 25C) can be tried either way, there is no need to use the provisions of s 28 to extend time, and therefore they are removed from s 28 by this section.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Consequential and incidental provision
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)The Secretary of State may by order make consequential or incidental provision in connection with a provision of this Act.
(2)An order under this section may, in particular—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)amend an enactment;
(b)modify the effect of an enactment.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)An order under this section must be made by statutory instrument.
(4)An order under this section which amends an enactment shall not be made unless a draft has been laid before and approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
(5)Any other order under this section shall be subject to annulment pursuant to a resolution of either House of Parliament.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(x)). NB provision is also made for the commencement of this section in SI 2811/2002, where the commencement date is stated to be 8 January 2002. The provision appears to have been commenced twice.

This section caused some controversy during the passage of the Act, although similar provisions are found in a number of statutes. The section includes the power to amend primary legislation by order (sub-s (2)(a)), although where primary legislation is to be amended the order is subject to the affirmative procedure in parliament (sub-s (3)). Ministers emphasised during debates that the section will allow ‘tidying up’, not the introduction of new provisions or policy initiatives.

Repealed by the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006, ss 61, 64(3)(c), Sch 3. Date in force: this repeal came into force on 30 March 2006 (date of the Royal Assent of the Immigration, Asylum and Nationality Act 2006) in the absence of any specific commencement provision.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Applied provision
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Subsection (2) applies where this Act amends or refers to a provision which is applied by, under or for purposes of—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)another provision of the Act which contains the provision, or
(b)another Act.
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (2)The amendment or reference shall have effect in relation to the provision as applied.
(3)Where this Act applies a provision of another Act, a reference to that provision in any enactment includes a reference to the provision as applied by this Act.

core:comment.core:para: 10 February 2003 (SI 1/2003).

The obscure wording means simply that where for example, there is a reference in s 1 of an Act to s 2 of that Act, and s 2 has been replaced or modified by this Act, the reference in s 1 will apply to s 2 as substituted or amended.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Money
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)Expenditure of the Secretary of State or the Lord Chancellor in connection with a provision of this Act shall be paid out of money provided by Parliament.
(2)An increase attributable to this Act in the amount payable out of money provided by Parliament under another enactment shall be paid out of money provided by Parliament.
(3)A sum received by the Secretary of State or the Lord Chancellor in connection with a provision of this Act shall be paid into the Consolidated Fund.

core:comment.core:para: 7 November 2002, on Royal Assent (s 162(2)(y)).

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Repeals
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: The provisions listed in Schedule 9 are hereby repealed to the extent specified.

core:comment.core:para: 8 December 2002, for the purpose of the entries relating to ss 33(2)(b), 34(3)(c) and (5), 36(1), 37(3)(c), 39, 42 and 43 of the IAA 1999 (SI 2811/2002); 10 February 2003 for the purposes of the entries relating to ss 7(1)(a), 24A(4), 25A(7), 26(3), 28(1) and 28A of the IA 1971, and ss 10(1)(c), 44 to 52, 53(5), 55 and 147 of the IAA 1999 (SI 1/2003).

However, the wording ‘the preceding sections’ in sub-s (1) appears to indicate that ss 162 to 164 came into force on Royal Assent. There is also provision in sub-s (6) to commence a section for a specified purpose or in relation to, for example, a specific geographical area. Nothing on the face of this section bars that partial commencement being used, for example, for the offences provisions of Pt 7.

This Act amends provisions of the IAA 1999 which were not in force at the time of Royal Assent of this Act. Therefore it is important to make reference to commencement orders under the 1999 Act, bringing provisions amended by this Act into force. See the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (Commencement No 11) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2816) and the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (Commencement No 12) Order 2003 (SI 2003/2). The following commencement orders have been made under this section:

The Nationality Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (Commencement No 1) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2811)) and the Nationality Immigration and Asylum Act 2002 (Commencement No 3) Order 2003 (SI 1/2003). Both orders include transitional provisions.

lnb-leg:provision.core:title: Extent
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (1)A provision of this Act which amends or repeals a provision of another Act or inserts a provision into another Act has the same extent as the provision amended or repealed or as the Act into which the insertion is made (ignoring, in any case, extent by virtue of an Order in Council).

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)England and Wales, and

lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para1: (3)A provision of this Act to which neither subsection (1) nor subsection (2) applies extends to—
lnb-leg:provision.lnb-leg:para2: (a)England and Wales,

The intention is to confer British Citizenship at a public ceremony, to be conducted by a registrar. Note that it is proposed that registrars become local authority employees, giving local authorities overall responsibility for delivering the ceremonies (see para 5, inserting a new sub-s 41(3A) into the BNA 1981).

The provisions of the Schedule will apply both to those who obtain their British citizenship by registration and those who obtain it by naturalisation, but note that under the new s 42 of the BNA 1981 (inserted by para 1 of this Schedule) the making of the oath and pledge at a citizenship ceremony is only made a requirement for adults. There is however no express bar in the Schedule to a child obtaining British Citizenship participating in a ceremony, although there may be issues over competence to take the oath and make the pledge.

Nothing in this Act or in the BNA 1981 as amended would prevent the new ceremonies being introduced prior to the coming into force of s 1 of this Act (new test of sufficient knowledge of life in the United Kingdom).
Paragraph 1 The wording of new s 42(6) derives from s 4(4) of the BNA 1981. Section 50(11) of the BNA 1981 defines a person of full age as a person over 18.

New s 42(7) of the BNA 1981 ensures that a person can affirm rather than take the Oath as set out in the new Sch 5 to the BNA 1981 inserted by para 2 of this Schedule, which would require them to ‘swear by Almighty God’.
Paragraph 2 The Oath is the historic Oath of Allegiance (see note to para 1 on new s 42(7) which makes provision for affirmations). The pledge is new.

Definitions ‘aircraft’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Rail freight wagon’, ‘Charge notice’: para 13; IAA 1999, s 40(2). ‘Clandestine entrant’: IAA 1999, s 32(2). ‘Concealed’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘The court’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(2). ‘Detached trailer’: IAA 1999 s 43(1). ‘Equipment’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Freight shuttle wagon’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Freight train’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Immigration document’: para 13; IAA 1999, s 40(9). ‘Hirer’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Locomotive’: para 15, IAA 1999, s 43(1); Railways Act 1993, s 83. ‘Owner’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Penalty notice’: IAA 1999, s 35(2); s 43(1). ‘Rail freight wagon’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Responsible person’: IAA 1999, s 32(5). ‘Rolling stock’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1); Railways Act 1993, s 83. ‘Senior officer’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Ship’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Small aircraft’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Small ship’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Shuttle train’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1); Channel Tunnel Act 1987 s 1(9). ‘Train’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Train operator’: IAA 1999, s 43(1). ‘Transporter’: para 15; IAA 1999, s 43(1) ‘Vehicle’: IAA 1999, s 43(1).

This Schedule makes extensive amendments to the carriers liability provisions of the IAA 1999. One purpose of these is to seek to ensure that the provisions comply with the requirements of art 6 of the ECtHR and address the issues identified in International Transport Roth Gmbh v Secretary of State for the Home Department [2002] EWCA Civ 158 , [2003] QB 728 .

Sections 32 and 34–37 of the IAA 1999, as amended by s 125 and this schedule, came into force on 8 December 2002 (see the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999 (Commencement No 11) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2815). See also the Carriers Liability (Clandestine Entrants) (Level of Penalty: Code of Practice) Order 2002 (SI 2002/2816) and the Carriers'' Liability Regulations 2002 (SI 2817/2002).

Transitional Provision See the Nationality, Immigration and Asylum Act (Commencement No 1 Order) 2002 (SI 2002/2811), para 4. The amendments to the IAA 1999 effected by paras 1 to 13 and 15 to 17 of this Schedule shall not apply in respect of a penalty notice, as defined in s 35(2) of the IAA 1999) which was issued to a person before the commencement of those paragraphs. See note on commencement, above. The limitations on the commencement of paras 1 to 12, 16 and 17 are because Pt 2 of the IAA 1999 has not yet been brought into force in respect of clandestine entrants who arrive concealed in a ship or aircraft.

Paragraphs 2(2) and 2(6) The issues covered by provisions inserted into the IAA 1999 Act by this subparagraph were previously dealt with in the Carriers Liability (Clandestine Entrants) (application to Rail Freight) Regulations 2001 (SI 2001/280). These, the name suggests, extended the carriers liability regime to rail freight carriers.

Paragraphs 2(3) and (4) Under the IAA 1999 those defined as ‘responsible persons’ were held jointly and severally liable for the penalty imposed. The amendment effected by this paragraph means that each person will be liable for his/her own penalty. However, the amendments effected by sub-s (4) provide for a driver''s employer who is the owner or hirer of the vehicle to be liable for payment of the penalty imposed on the driver.
Paragraph 2(8) Where a person is responsible in more than one capacity (see note to sub-ss (2)(3) and (2)(4), a penalty may be imposed in respect of each capacity.

Paragraph 3 This paragraph, inserting a new s 32A into the IAA 1999, requires the Secretary of State to issue a Code of Practice to which reference will be made in determining the amount of penalty to be levied under s 32. The draft code is to be laid before parliament.

Paragraph 4 This para amends s 34 of the IAA 1999 to extend the defences available to a carrier. New s 34(3A) will give rail freight operators who knew that there were clandestine entrants concealed in their rail freight wagon access to a defence. A significant change is the omission of the original s 34(5) and the replacement of s 34(6) so that where one responsible person has a defence, all responsible persons are entitled to the benefit of that defence.

Paragraph 7 Provision is made for a person upon whom a penalty notice is served to object to the level, as well as to the imposition, of the penalty. Provisions in the 1999 Act providing for service on one responsible person to be deemed service on all, have been repealed.
Paragraph 8 Section 35A of the IAA 1999 inserted by this paragraph provides for a new statutory right of appeal against both the imposition and the level of a penalty.

Paragraph 9 The amendments effected to s 36 of the IAA 1999 by this paragraph provide a new power to detain a vehicle, small ship small aircraft or rail freight wagon for a maximum of 24 hours pending the decision as to whether to issue a penalty notice. The court can cancel the penalty or reduce it.

Paragraph 10 New s 36A of the IAA 1999, inserted by this paragraph, provides a new power of detention in default of payment. The power only comes into effect once the time for appealing has expired, or, if an appeal is brought, after the appeal is determined.

Paragraph 11 The amendments effected by this section remove the need for a person applying to a court to show a compelling need for the release for the transporter. New sub-ss 37(5A) and (5B) mean that the power of sale cannot be exercised while any appeal is pending or while an appeal can brought.

Paragraph 13 In the new s 40 inserted by this section the power to levy charges is restricted to those arriving by ship or aircraft. Owners and operators of road passenger vehicles will no longer be liable to the £2,000 charge. However, under sub-s (7) there is power to extend the levying of the charges to cases where the person arrives by train. Procedures for notification and objection, are set out in new s 40A. New s 40B provides for a new right of appeal against the imposition of a charge under s 40.
(14) This removes the power to detain a vehicle in connection with charges levied under s 40.
